750ml bottle poured into a glass. This is massive. Got some soy sauce on the nose at first that mellowed into strong coffee aroma. Deep black with a tan head that dissipates slowly. Dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, roasted malt. HUGE mouthfeel. Long finish. Just drink it. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours black with tan head that dissipates. Sweet cherry/raisin aromas with little carbonation. Coffee flavors with a bit of sweetness but not overwhelming. Nice complexity without boozy flavors. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good stout but for those who mention this beer in the same conversation as KBS you are wayyy out of line, this is a rich deep coffee stout not much more. Not comparable to KBS in any way shape or form. KBS much smoother chocolate notes wayyy smoother. Really bad comparison to KBS.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Really liked it. Had a Mellon aftertaste. High ABV, but not overly strong to the taste.

750ml Flasche. Tiefschwarzes Imperial Stout mit mit sehr schöner braunen Schaumkrone. Geruch nach dunkler Schokolade, Kaffee, Vanille, alkoholisch. Geschmack intensiv nach dunkler Schokolade, gerösteter Kaffee. Klasse!

Dark, black pour with a dark brown head. Coffee on the nose, in the mouth, in the beginning, middle, and end. Maybe some malty undertone but buried by the coffee. Strong alcohol nose and burn all the way down. Not bad, but very one dimensional. I just dont see what others appear to with the high ratings, this is a one trick pony. So much alcohol makes for not a lot of tasting. Would I drink again? Not likely. Would I order again? No.

The Sampler, Brooklyn tap: Pours black with a beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate, a heeping of ground coffee, and a veritable whiff of booze. Taste is burnt, with some dark chocolate, coupled with more coffee than you would want. Caramel and fruit make their way in their, along with some alcohol burn. Texture aint so bad though. Even though there is the burn, it comes off pretty smooth. Complex, but I cannot say that is balanced.

Bought this a few months ago but just popped it open. Poured into a snifter. Malt, vanilla, roast and slight chocolate. Taste follows. Malt and coffee dominate with a bitter dark chocolate finish with a slight alcohol burn.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2015 Bottle from Brewdog online shop. Pours opaque very dark brown to black with a brown tan chocolatey medium head. Looks great in the glass. Nose is promising. Rich black fresh coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, roasted malt, alcohol, liquid caramel, little bit of sweet coffee liqueur like Kahlua, hint of wood barrel, which is weird because this isnt barrel aged? Taste is a slight disappointment. Theres rich black coffee, dark chocolate, a slight minerally flintiness, slight earthiness, roasted malt, burnt toast, but also a distinctive acidic wood barrel tang, with a hint of pine and green hop. The acidicness means its not smooth. Still very good, but no way a Top 50 for me.

Bottle poured into a Belgian Snifter. Pours jet black with two finger tan head, slowly recedes leaving pretty nice lacing behind. Aromas of coffee, cream, vanilla, caramel. On the taste, big notes of coffee with dark chocolate, caramel, roast, just a hint of booze.Very smooth for 12% ABV. Medium to full body with a nice creamy mouthfeel and a slightly warm finish A very nice imperial stout, Id love to try some of the variants!

Drank many times, the most memorable of which was chugging a (very cold) full pint for RBSH. Pours a inky black with small head. Aromas of roasted malt, medium coffee, dark caramel, slight ash. The palate is medium-full, with flavors of acidic coffee, bitter chocolate, warming alcohol, roast, and some coffee creamer.
Chocolatey creamy aroma. Pours impenetrable black with an active brown head. Deep complex flavors, coffee and cocoa with a lingering sweetness.

Bottle kindly shared by Cuso, thank you! Aroma heavy chocolate, ash, roasted. Pitch black colour, oily texture. Taste is mostly roasted, burnt, ash, light chocolate. Mostly bitter, only light sweetness. Light light fruits. Nice experience, but over the top with ash/burnt flavours. Full body. Alcohol hidden well. Great beer, though still not amongst the best of the best (which is a little thing to say)

Pours a pitch black brew wih a medium brown head with regular retention, aro.a is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with cofee, dark chocolate, caramel and dark fruits, full bodied, initial flavor is heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter, final flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long and bitter aftertaste. Complex and delicious
Full of rich complex flavors that develop over each sip. Pours dark with a full tan head.
Heavy coffee taste and aroma. Bitter, dark chocolate notes. Dry finish. Warm feel from high abv.

Near black pour with a chocolate milk coloured head that is quite mountainous for the style. Lace all down the glass. I get a significant amount of smoke over espresso roastiness on the nose. Theres something vegetal in there as well...and something musty. This bottle may be fucked. If not Im very underwhelmed. Theres also a kerosene thing going on.

Nice fat body with a warming finish that shows the ABV a little. Heavy loads of coffee up front with a really papery oxidized note...I think. Now Im second guessing myself. It also leaves a weird tingle on the front left quadrant of my tongue.

750 ml bottle into a big snifter, opened on New Years. ABV 12%
Totally black in colour, with one finger of deep brown head, thick enough and steady, with good retention and light lacing left around the glass after it collapses and after every swirl of the glass.
Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, light alcohol notes, hints of aromatic hops as well.
Taste has lots of coffee upfront, roasted malts, vanilla, fruits, toffee. The alcohol very well hidden. Light bitterness and again coffee on the aftertaste.
Medium thick body, good amount of carbonation. Sticky palate.
Great Imperial Stout, great beer in general. Silky abd smooth on the tongue, it drinks so easily, really fantastic.
Black pour with creamy brown head. Coffee and licorice on the nose. Sweet chocolate and coffee with some hop resins poking through as well. Finish is lingering bitter chocolate. Creamy, thick body.

Early on 31st Dec 13, usual 0.75 litre bottle poured into a pint pot and the remainder into a Gordons badged thistle shaped glass. One of two bought for me by a brother on my 60th Birthday earlier in December.

Jet black with a thick coffee like foaming head on both glasses.

You cant miss the coffee and dark chocolate in the nose or taste but below those two powerhouses there are more subtle flavours and aromas to find. A strong vanilla flavour arrives and then leaves: but a pod or two stay behind to dance with some hedgerow berries and a bag of toffees. This gets more complex as it warms too: each malty molasse playing with your taste buds and nasal senses.

Rich, smooth and very drinkable: most enjoyable, pity I had to share it with my son and son-in-law (the wife insisted).

(#700). Bottle, 2012 version. Pours black with a dense brown Aroma has coffee, roasted malt, bitter chocolate, vanilla. Taste is mid sweet, roasted coffee, bitter chocolate and slight alcohol finish. Medium sticky body, soft carbonation.

Bottle. Pours black with fast dissipating tan head. Smells roasty, vanilla. Has a very smooth taste, lots of coffee, really not much else. Honestly, its good but highly overrated! Its not bad, just overrated. There is very little finish...its really not too impressive. Id buy it if it was a $7.99- 6pk. :)

Absolute world class stout. One of my favorite regular imperial stouts; up there with Oak Aged Yeti. Big, bold, HUGE malt character. Coffee, chocolate, sweetness but not overly so. It is very full bodied, viscous, you get a short dying head emerging from the bowels of darkness. Its just a massive, decadent, delicious treat. Well worth the hype!
Bottle. Black with a medium head.Full bodied with a creamy chocolate presence. A big hitter that was dangerously easy to drink
Pitch black colour, dark brown foam. Oily and syrupy. Full body. Very well balanced beer, aroma of coffee, dark fruit and dark chocolate. Sweet and bitter. Very good!

Pours deep brown with a fluffy tan head. Coffee and alcohol on the nose. Astringent smell. Drinks smoothly with lingering bitterness and astringency. Tastes of toffee, coffee, and dried fruit. Flavors marry very well.

This was easily the star on the top of the tree during our night before Christmas beer expedition. Even though it is one of the heaviest stouts Ive encountered, it was not overly filling (although it was enjoyed at a slow pace because it is so worthy of savoring). Equal parts sweet, nutty and roasty coffee, Speedway Stout is a total delight. And, as the marketing language tells us, it is indeed HUGE.

Appearance: Black as the deepest dungeon. A nice big beige head that leaves a fine lacing.Aroma: Coffee, chocolate, toffee and mild roasted dark malt.Palate: Full body. Tad sweet with an ok bitterness. Soft to average carbonation.Taste: A really lovely smooth caramel/toffee back! Lots of coffee, roasted malt and chocolate. Dangerously well hidden alcohol.Overall impression: Soild stuff. Very pleasant and balanced. My mothers new favourite ale! Mine also.Personal stats: Bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika in Oslo, Norway241213
Pitch black with a thick tan head and great retention. Soft fruity esters, big coffee character, roasted malt, and some caramel malt.

Very nice. Huge roast malt, coffee, dark chocolate and even a light hint of licorice. Pours jet black with initial mocha head and good lacing. Finishes very bitter. Thick and creamy palate. Soft carbonation. Big, well put together and beautiful. Some prune and raisin even. Bottle from Premier Gourmet.

Yeast infection? Aroma of apples, citrus, yeast. None of the normal imp stout flavours like roast, coffee, chocolate etc. 
Palate was fine, not the same problems with the flavour. Nice and worm. Cofee. 
With the flavor problems the beer stroke me as unbalanced. Hope to re rate this next year

Bottle. Shared this jewel with family members on Christmas eve. What can I say it is every bit as good as advertised. Probably the darkest beer Ive ever had. Light would not penetrate it. Aroma was over whelmingly coffee. Taste was extremely complex with mostly coffee but undertones of chocolate and caramel, but whats really surprising about it is the creamy texture. Its excellent.
This is a winner for the price, dark, rich, roasty, and full. Alcohol is not all that strong for being a 12%. Could be an everyday treat!
Syrupy, bitter, strong. Drank a few months ago, but remember lots of coffee and liquorice. Very roasty.

Really big taste...coffee, dark chocolate and licorice. A sip of this beer and it hits your mouth on several levels. This is a great stout ...lives up to it reputation. Deserving of its ranking. Need to get more ...I would love to age some for a few years.

A perfect score! The vanilla in the aftertaste was never overboard, but always more pronounced with every sip. This is an outstanding imperial stout, a best in class to be sure. To compare, only a few beers come to mind...and none with the sexy aftertaste of this beautiful beer. Its one of the best stouts of all time, in my humble opinion.

Bomber to pint, pours midnight black with a dense head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and a hint of dark fruit. Big taste, dark chocolate and coffee, boozy yet super smooth and quite thick. Drank at near room temp which really brought the flavors out. Highly recommended.

Bottled: unk

A: black, opaque. Oddly, no foam on pour, but a few seconds later, a sheet of mocha foam, then falls to a really cool surface foam that is really interesting to me - like globs of pain on a canvas that were allowed to slowly run together.
S: coffee, smoke, leather, licorice, some dates. Rich nose here.
T: Coffee, cocoa, leather, umami, licorice, molasses, raisin. I dig it.
M: medium bodied with lower carb and an overall velvety feel, not as dry as I would anticipate. 
O: a sincerely good stout with surprising characteristics. Next time Im in CA, I will need to snatch up a few bottles.

Serving type: bottle

12-10-2011

Pours thick like a a syrup with a frothy milk chocolate head that releases strong dark roasted coffee upon the nose. The color is above 40 srm completely opaque, This beer has excellent mouth feel a hearty big imperial beer that warms the tongue. Initial flavor notes are of strong black coffee that gives way to subtle dark chocolate, raisin with a slight smokey caramel and alcohol finish. This beer has the perfect amount of astringency which is a hard flavo noter to perfect making it one ot the best stouts i have eve tried. hats off to alesmith for this masterpiece. Now, I just have cellar age a couple of bottles and taste them over the next couple of years

Pitch black colour with a good brown head that disappears quite fast. Loads of espresso in the aroma, together with some licorice. Taste is as adverted; coffee to the maximum, together with a sourness I cant name. Full bodied, with average carbonation. In my opinion is a fantastic beer, but I would love to try one that has been stored a couple of years, would like it a bit mellower and rounder maybe. But, still, a awesome beer.

Somehow cellared one since 2008: this one only gets better. The smell is espresso, chocolate, and malt with a touch of nuttiness. The alcohol bite goes away with age and the heavy malt and coffee characters come through. This is the thickest beer when you pour it. Like used motor oil. Coats your mouth and the taste lingers for a while. Hide one from yourself if a cool dark space. You will thank yourself later. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from my Secret Santa in summer 2013.  Almost black colored beer with medium beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, dark berries. Taste, roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, caramel hint of licorice. Alcohol is present by warming. Long coffee bitter finish. Extremely tasty beer.

750 bottle pour at porter/stout tasting..glug glug pour from bottle..motor oil thick..jet black..nose is pleasing with noticeable espresso beans..nuts..pecans..chocolate..brown caramel head with a substantial amount of carbonation..mouthfeel is amazingly light to medium bodied with a hint of the high abv hit on the finish..leaves a lingering bitter chocolate coffee taste..very tasty..great example of the style..worthy of the reputation..would love to try the barrel version...

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2013 My 100th rating. Tasted from bottle. Pours black with thick brown head. Great lacing on sides. Aroma is huge amounts of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts with hints of caramel. Excellent robust aroma! Taste definitely does not disappoint. Strong coffee and chocolate flavors. Lots of roasted malts with some caramel sweetness. Ends with mild bitterness. Alcohol very well hidden with just a faint burn at the end. Huge full bodied beer. Moderately sticky mouthfeel with some dryness in aftertaste. Just a incredible stout! Tasted it blind against Bells Expedition Stout and thought Bells was just a hair better but both exceptional beers.

Why is this getting such high ratings? This beer tastes like coffee, chocolate and alcohol, thats it! No complexity, just straight kick your ass. Maybe too many drunks on ratebeer but the fact is just because its strong does not make it good. Speeding towards drunkness stout. I grew hair in regions I didnt even know I had drinking this beer. My car can be fueled by this beer.
Bottle by Cuso, many thanks! This RIS has it all! Overall excellent! The coffee flavor is present, no doubt. The alcohol is hidden, but comes forth after a while and is warming.

Poured from bottle. Dark brown color with big lacing beige head. Aroma: prunes, coffee. Full bodied, oily texture, medium carbonation. Beginning is malty sweet, followed by bitterness which is not just hoppy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, courtesy of Cuso, many thanks. Pours dark brown/black with brown huge stable head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, alcohol, dark berries, roasted malt. Taste is bittersweet, alcohol, hoppy, chocolate, coffee, some caramel, roasted malt. Very nice!
beige head disappears without lacing. coffee coloured. aroma boozy, hazelnut, porto, madeira (oxidized?). taste like aroma aftertaste coffee, bitter. quite dense mouthfeel, medium carbonation.
12/8/2013. 750 ml. bottle. Black licorice, dark roasted malt, chocolate, coffee. Thick and complex, long bitter finish. Awesome.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 coffe,chocolate roasty aroma..jet black..dry finish,but smooth for 12%ABV..a great Imperial Stout
Strong coffee aroma, almost a burnt odor. Very dark color with a nice lasting head. Bitter coffee / dark chocolate taste. Very dry, long aftertaste. Full body.

FROM NOTES: October 16, 13. Poured from a 750ml bottle into a chalice.

A: Freshly ground, roasted coffee up front, with strong raisin notes that compliment the coffee without over-powering it. Subdued black licorice lingers behind the other aromas.
A: Pours a deep, dark black with a slight mocha colored head along the sides of the glass.
T: The coffee jumps out initially, but notes of dark chocolate and dark fruits are also present. An underlying level of tartness balances out the rest of the bold flavors with a finish of dry malts and coffee and appropriate warming while going down.
P: Thick, creamy, full body. Soft finish.
O: Probably the greatest widely-available Imperial Stout around. Might also be one of the better coffee stouts around. This is one IMPRESSIVE World Class beer!

750 ml bottle. Pours a jet black color with a massive creamy, rocky brown head. Rich, earthy roasted malt aroma has notes of smoke, coffee and bittersweet cocoa truffles. Upfront flavor is rich roasted malt, with hints of black licorice, dark chocolate, coffee and burnt caramel. Wow! Mid taste brings flavors of chocolate covered espresso beans, charcoal, dark fruits and peppery hops. Finish is smoked malt, light resiny hops and black currants. This is a big, complex Imperial Stout with lots of flavor and character. Luxuriously smooth and menacingly potent at the same time. One of the best American Imperial Stouts I have tasted. Outstanding.

Bottle. Jet black. Generous toffee colored foam. Nose - toffee, coffee, hint of alcohol. Palate - coffee, coffee. Smooth. Finish - mild bitterness, burnt sugar. 
Delicious.

Black with a creamy chocolate colored head. Smells of coffee, dark cherries and chocolate, minimal booze noticeable. Much lighter in body than I would suspect. Great coffee on the taste, with malt and coffee bitters developing as you wait. Paired with a creamy desert (pumpkin and cream roll for thanksgiving) was phenomenal.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bottle @Lúpulo Feroz, Oviedo. Coffee, roasty, liquor and nuts aromas. Pours black with nice frothy tan head, some lacing, persistent. Full bodied, silky texture, soft carbonation. Taste is creamy rich, mild biterrness, coffee, dark chocolate, liquor. Really well balanced, smooth, dry finish. Very enjoyable, amazing one.

Catching up on old ratings. 

One of the best stouts, Ive had. Straightforward, seriously delicious.
Dark as night pour little bit of khaki head. Not much lacing. Nose hits you with a wonderful coffee aroma. Some dark chocolate and vanilla. The taste was a smooth espresso flavor with bittersweet of cocoa nibs. So sweetness, vanilla and dark fruits. The mouthfeel was especially crisp for a 12 abv. dry and smooth, covering the tongue. Excellent.

Sweet fruit and coffee with thick coffee and complex. The high abv is noticeable but not overbearing. The finish had dark fruit almost like a belgian quad. Overall very chewy and sweet with complex flavors.

Bomber. Opaque dark brown with a dark brown head. Laces down the sides and lasting head on the edges. Aromas of espresso, caramel, dark fruits, and roasted malt. Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, espresso, dark fruits and a light roasted malt. Velvety smooth and deceptive. Hardly tastes like it is that heavy.

Bomber pours a very dark brown with a thick foamy dark tan head. The aroma is rich with coffee and chocolate. The taste is very full bodied and leaves a wet finish. I get a lot of chocolate and coffee in the finish. This beer is very rich and sweet.
UPDATED: FEB 25, 2014 Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with toffee colored head. Aroma of intense coffee and roastiness. Taste of roasted coffee and dark chocolates.

Bottle from sonnycheeba. Pours opaque dark brown with a bubbly frothy light brown head and lots of lacing. Smells like coffee, chocolate, and subtle alcohol. Smells slightly sweet and very delicious. Smooth feel, tastes roasted, like bitter coffee, chocolate, and syrup.

On draft during the grand prix event. Dark black pour with a small tan head. Strong strong coffee, espresso, heavy roast, light milk chocolate, and bitter roast. This is in the runnings for the strongest coffee speedway. Heavily roasted and mostly dry. Pretty good cup of coffee.Earlier Rating: 11/23/2013 Total Score: 3.9This will probably be aliased, but I will rate anyway. Draft sample at the speedway grand prix 2013. Black pour, with a tan head and nice lacing. Roasted malt, smooth earthy coffee, fruity coffee beans, chocolate, and a bit of alcohol. Great coffee flavor - not overly roasty, and not as potent as the hammerhead.Earlier Rating: 11/11/2012 Total Score: 3.7Draft at night off a million zillion speedways 2012 at obriens. This will probably end up merged with regular speedway. -kauai reserve coffeeEarlier Rating: 8/16/2012 Total Score: 4Tap at the brewery.  Standard black pour, tan head. Nice, as expected.Earlier Rating: 7/25/2012 Total Score: 3.9Draft at the brewery.  Pitch black pour, thin tan head. Really nice, but there are better speedways.Earlier Rating: 11/15/2011 Total Score: 3.9Pitch black with a swirly tan head. Earlier Rating: 12/17/2006 Total Score: 4.2Pours a pitch black with fairly large tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, toffee, coffee, roasted malt, alcohol, and some dark fruit.  The flavor is absolutely wonderful.  Chocolate, lots of coffee, roasty, sweet caramel, and a little bit of hops.  Some alcohol comes through, but it is very warming.  Creamy mouthfeel.Earlier Rating: 11/8/2010 Total Score: 4.2Draft at OBriens.  Black pour, tan head, standard Speedway appearance.  Chocolate, dark roasted malts, nice smooth coffee blend, and a little bit of vanilla.  The coffee is really good, but it lacks the rich roasted coffee complexities of the kopi. Still excellent, better then the regular version.  From talking to Peter, it sounded like the bourbon has more to do with the variety of coffee blend, not in reference to the bourbon alcohol, which is why it lacks this aspect.

750ml bottle thanks to Stevepsycho! Rate 1200. Pours a thick pitch black color with a big 2.5 finger of rocky mocha head. Aroma of rich dark chocolate, fresh ground coffee beans, burnt sugar, and vanilla beans. Taste is awesome! Been craving a nice coffee stout, and boy am I glad I'm drinkin the whole 750 by myself!! Thick rich creamy mouthfeel. Tons of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, sweet dark fruit, vanilla cream, and burnt toast. Awesome!
What a beer. Pours black with light brown head. Coffee, cream, Strawberry, and bubblegum. flavors are coffee and sweet cream. Also red berries and and sweetness. An awesome beer.

Bottle shared between 3 at BrewDog, Bristol. Pours out a lucious black colour with a small creamy brown head. Complex aroma of roasted coffee and dark chocolate, with a hint of vanilla. Very smooth, thick texture, full body. Roasted coffee finish. Expensive but very good.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2013 Botella de 75 cl. en el Lupulo Feroz . Alucinante imperial stout probada en el mes de junio de 2013, una de las mejores imperial stout americanas que he probado hasta ahora. Intenso aroma y gran cuerpo. Espuma poco persistente que desaparece a mitad de vaso. Se asemeja a un licor, con toques a pasas añejas. Toques a caramelo, café y chocolate al final muy débiles. Amargor bien compensado que no destaca en exceso sobre el conjunto.  Predominio del alcohol. Imprescindible tomar una tercera vez para apreciar y definir un poco mas todos sus matices.

Inköpt okt 2012. Helt svart öl med ett kraftigt, gräddigt mörkbrunt skum. Mängder av kaffe, choklad, rostad malt och mörka bär i doften. Ännu mer av allt detta i smaken tillsammans med kola och aningen vanilj. En mjuk imperial stout på samma gång som den är fullmatad med smaker.

On tap at Palm Tavern. Dark brown with a thin brown crown. Aroma is big and sweet with plenty of coffee. Roasted malt, alcohol, oak and some chocolate lurk in the background. Taste is awfully sweet with chocolate, coffee, cocoa powder, roasted malts and a sweet and boozy finish.

Pitch black colour with a medium-sized, creamy, brown head. The aroma consists of coffee, chocolate, liqourice, vanilla, alcohol as well as roasted and sweet malt notes. The initial flavour is very sweet, medium bitter and lightly sour, which evolves into a dry, bitter finish. It is full bodied and has a thich oily texture. Soft carbonation. An exceptional beer that Id love to enjoy again in the future!

Black, foamy, brown head. Alcohol overpowers nose, some coffee. Medium bitter and sweet. Dry afterfeel, thick, carbonation on rhe lower side, but suits this beer. Warming. Alcohol, roasted malt, coffee, hint of red fruit, dark chocolate aroma. Needs to be served quite warm! Too much alcohol, but good.

75cl bottle, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: pitch black beer, nice stable beige head.
NOSE: coffee, chocolate, alcohol.
TASTE: coffee, bitter, chocolate.
Was rather disappointed about this beer in general. I generally love Imperials Stouts, but thought this would be more...

750 ml bottle bought at Quality Liquor in Waukesha. Pours jet black with a thick and rich toast brown head resembling melted ice cream. Coffee hits the palate and transitions into dark molasses, raisins and I taste overripe peaches. Finish is dry and the alcohol is balanced. You know your drinking a big beer but it's not overpowering. Excellent RIS that is a top 5 but not one of my top 3 imperial stouts. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Extremely dark brown with medium small brown head. Aroma roasted malt, coffee, caramel. Full body. Not really a lot of alcohol. Roasted malt flavors, chocolate and coffee, somewhat sweet. Rich and intense. Pretty much exactly as expected and done very well.

Very delicious and smooth. Heavy and strong. Similar to very dark chocolate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2015 regular Speedway 750mL bottle many times, pours black with a tan head. Aroma is HUGE on espresso beans. Flavour of potent espresso, roasted malts, burnt caramel and light velvety chocolate undertones. Wonderfully rich and thick texture. Most delicious stuff. Rating: 4.4/5 
Single Variety Speedway at AleSmith for Speedway Grand Prix 2013. On tap at AleSmith, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out potent coffee and heavy roast. Flavour brings out complex coffee notes, a little bit of spice, and roast. Very complex and coffee-dominated. Very little residual sweetness, with a very roasted and coffee centric finish. Excellent stuff.  Rating: 4.4/5 11/9/2013. 
Hammerhead Speedway at AleSmith for Speedway Grand Prix 2013. On tap at AleSmith, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out loads of coffee, and subtler roast - quite potent coffee but not as much as the Kopi Luwak version. Flavour isnt as roasted as the other alternate coffee versions of Speedway, but is more spicy and earthy coffee. Great stuff, but inferior to the other coffee Speedways, including the regular. Rating: 3.8/5 11/9/2013.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2014 Had this on tap during the Speedway craziness going on, this time had the Hammerhead version. The rating here is for Hammerhead.  Unfortunately walked in unknowingly that they had 12 Speedway varieties on tap. Because I didnt pre register, was only allowed to have regular or the new "Hammerhead" with no explanation as to wtf Hammerhead was. Once I took a sip, it was obvious to me it must be some coffee. Also I would like to note that I was very sad I could not try the others :-(

Pours pitch black with a small mocha head on top, looking super creamy. Aroma of huge acidic earthy coffee, a hint of chocolate, and just more huge coffee and espresso. Flavor follows with massive espresso, earthy and spicy, lightly acidic, with some hints of chocolate fudge in the background. Slight warming alcohol and lingering espresso. This really highlights the huge amounts of coffee here. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Honestly, this blew me away. One of the best coffee stouts I have ever had.

Earlier Rating: 11/11/2012 Total Score: 4.1This is my bottled, regular Speedway version rating.  Pours black with frothy brown head. Aromas of bitter coffee, some hops, very roasty grains. Hint of chocolate. Smells more like a bold porter. Was hoping for more on the aroma (the only knock here and it is minor). Huge coffee flavor with a nice bitterness. A bit of a cocoa powder lingering on the palate. Another sip reveals a bit of dark fruit. Medium mouthfeel, lighter than I had expected but still pretty chewy. Love this because it doesnt go all syrupy like some others. Really coffee forward with the right carbonation. Alcohol hidden but leaves a lingering warmth. Heavy lacing as it goes. Very nice. Really want to try the BA version.

Pitch black pour. Stout the way stout is supposed to be. Chocolate, roasty malt and coffee. Not sure I can say I pick out the added coffee, but a great beer. Great balance and drink ability for the high abv.

Pours an awesome pitchblack with slowly fading beige, purple even head. Coffee and bitter chocolate, red fruits in the nose. Can?t wait to dive in! Oh man, boom!! Explosion of flavors, sweet chocolate, espresso, fruits, bourbon whiskey and a lovely bitter. Nice warm alcohol feeling going down the throat. Thick full creamy mouthfeel. This is one amazing strong stout. From a trade with Jimsal27, thanks for this one and might have to hit you up for more of these.

Big mouthful of flavour to match the big chocolate/coffee nose. Deep black with a decent foamy head. Might have been a little too sweet for me at the end of the all of it, but a cracking good beer.  This might be regarded as one of the best beers in the world, and it sets a really high bar, and woe betide the pretenders
0.75l bottle. Pitch black body, light brown head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, figs and brandy. Taste of ripe plums, coffee, chocolate and sour cherry. Thick body, creamy texture. Awesome beer.
Lots of coffee on nose. Was surprised by how balanced this was. Mellow coffee and chocolate notes with a pleasant smooth finish. Alcohol was hidden really well. So good

Pours black in the glass with some weak carbonation. Aroma is straight up coffee with some alcohol notes as well. Sweet coffee flavors followed by a nutty peanut butter aftertaste. Overall, this is awesome! Thanks to BarZigKin for his generosity.
En af de bedste stouter jeg har smagt. Massere af kaffe smag,en smule alkohol, ristede noter, chokolade ..

This is my 900th rating. I hoped to choose a great brew for this occasion and I had the chance to get this bottle. Speedway stout has its reputation and I think there are just few beers like that.
75cl bottle. Black with medium to big head. head is tanned and thick.
NOSE : The beer has a huge coffee aromas, strong lactic notes, nuts and black chocolate. Hop aromas are well present with dominating orange zest. Strong toffee. 
SIP : thick body with oily texture. The carbonation is moderate. Mouth feel is amazing. The beer starts with sweet flavors of toffee and black chocolate. It develops more roasted malt aromas that mingle with warming booze. The booze aroma is reminding a good whisky since it reveals some wood notes. Wow. What a complex start. Lactic and toffee notes play well in the background. Further on the hop aromas are making the surface. The beer is getting more bitter but mostly reminding a coffee and black chocolate. Usually I would expect sour or dry notes but not in this beer ; it mixes well burned, sweet, booze and bitter together. No wonder its considered one of the best stouts in the world. 
OVERALL : Wow. I knew its gonna be a good stout but I was still surprised how much. The beer is perfectly well balanced with warming booze and black chocolate finish. I will surely come back to this brew.

Served from the 22oz. bottle into a globe glass...

Pours a opaque black with purplish brown edges, with a head that will build quick if poured too aggressive. Tan foam that drops off to sticky foam on the sides of the glass, a foam layer and a nice ring around the glass. So far, so good.

Smells of dark chocolate, roasted grains, coffee and a little alcohol. As with some other beers Ive tried, Im surprised by the lack of aromatics sometimes but I know that doesnt always mean something bad.

The first sip is dark chocolate, roasted grains, mocha, maybe some vanilla, a little hop presence and the alcohol at the end.

Smooth mouthfeel, medium to thick body that I loved just moving around as I tasted. Not much carbonation, which is fine. Finish is a little on the dry side, with the chocolate, roasted grains, mocha and the alcohol burn at the end.

Overall, this is one damn fine stout and I will definitely pony up the $$$ for more. While I still have a lot to learn about this style, this stout in particular is currently in my top spot and Alesmiths reputation is safe on my account.

Cheers

Bottle. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, coffee, and roasted barley. Appearance is completely black with a thin off white head. Taste is chocolate, coffee, toast, vanilla, caramel. Good carbonation for a stout. Full bodied. Just a great beer.

Top notch. Great coffee aroma with some chocolate. Very black with a full brown head. Smooth and full palate but not too heavy. The primary taste is coffee followed by chocolate and roasted malts. Not much sweetness but with a little hops bitterness at the back. I could not taste the alcohol. It was amazing how well the flavors were blended. Superb stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2013 Pitch Black with a creamy & filmy brown head that has some great retention. Nose is chocolate nibs, cocoa, licorice, coffee, roasted barley/malts, and some vanilla. Taste has a strong coffee and chocolate flavor along with roasted malts and roasted barley; Bit of booziness to the flavor. Very roasted coffee/malty aftertaste. Body is quite heavy and the carbonation is between mild and moderate. Very tasty Imperial Stout!
One of the best things I had in my mouth. Would recommend ta add in TO DO list before dying. The aroma is so tempting, but it does not prepare you for emotion blast when tasting it.
Coffee flavor with dark chocolate in the back. Nice roasted malt without any burnt taste

Pours a beautiful black beer with a good tan head. Smells coffee, dark fruits, roasted and chocolate. Tastes chocolate, coffee, vanilla and roasty. Damn good. Nice fruity and bitter aftertaste. Thick body and a sticky texture with a low carbo.

Diepe zwarte kleur met een volle bruine kraag. Mooie dikke structuur. Volle geur van koffie, vanille, fruit. Erg goede geur. Volle smaak. Smaakt naar vanille, koffie. Toch ook iets fruitigs. Iets bitter in de nasmaak. Lekkere dikke structuur.

Bomber bottle. Aroma is dry coffee and some sweetness. Appearance is black with a tan head. Taste s coffee and dark malt that is sweet and dry bitterness at the same time. Palate is dry and leaves the coffee flavor aftertaste. Overall, a great stout. Would like to try a bottle with sone age on it. I bet it is fantastic bourbon barreled.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a stout glass. Pleasant aroma and pours a dark opaque brown with a full tan head. Spicy up front with flavors of dark chocolate and coffee. Exceptionally smooth finish for a stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. An intense alcohol aroma, coffee, roastyness. Taste is delicious coffee, some sweetness, a nice balance between bitterness and sweetness - mostly bitter, obviously. Mouthfeel is as it should be, and lingers very well. A great stout, but a little surprised how much alcohol the aroma has.

How: Bottle.
Where: SBWF 2013.
Appearance: Black colour with a brown head.
Aroma: Coffee, chocolate, liquorice, alcohol.
Body: Full body, medium carbonation.
Flavour: Alcohol, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, liquorice, roasted malt.
Obviously coffee, however I enjoyed the big cocoa aroma, along with heavy roasted flavors, and slight caramels. Not a massive beer, just a nice Imperial Stout.

This is a hefty stout! Loads of complex aromas such as caramel, coffee, chocolate, smoke. Heavy mouthfeel. The coffee flavors werent as strong as I had anticipated, although those aromas definitely come out more in the aftertaste. Great beer!

750mL Champagne bottle
A seriously sinister looking beer sits in front of me. Pretty much solid jet black, sump-oil-like liquid with a dense thick creamy light brown head, that would put most brown ales to shame, sits proudly atop...mocking me!
Intoxicating aroma assaults me with rich dark chocolate, molasses, cocoa, dark roast espresso grounds, earthy spice, roasted cashew, with a faint whaft of fortifying booze.
It;s thick. Its really thick! Viscous, oily, sticky on the palate - youd need degreaser to clean it off something! Really long on the tongue, low carbonation exacerbates this all.
Explodes on the body, just when I thought the aroma was intense enough...Cocoa, strong espresso, charred nuts, toffee, dark chocolate, black fruits, touch of citrus with Port-like rancio developing. Warming booze and firm but balanced bitterness on a very looong lingering, satisfying finish.
Wow...yeah, its good. Get some more...

A massive bottle of black chocolatey velvet, from The Local Pub in Athens. This is one for sharing, for sure. (Even then, it hides its alcohol so well it kind of sneaks up on you afterwards.) Amazing aroma of chocolate and burnt caramel. Complex chocolate malty tastes keep on delivering. Rich, full and creamy on the palate. A perfect example of an Imperial Stout. Thank heavens winter is coming.
One of the best Imperial Stout I have had the pleasure to enjoy. Smooth, creamy, expresso, and very much well balanced beer. This is a must for any beer enthusiasts. Well done.

750 ml bottle from Coconuts. Black with a light brown head and moderate lacing. Aroma is rich with coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts. Similar flavor with light caramel and toasted malts. Medium sweetness, light to medium bitterness. Full body with a soft, clean feel and a smooth, sweet finish.

Bottle aged for one year. Tar black pour, small brown head. Whiskey-like colour at the very edge of the glass. Aroma of dark coffee and espresso, chocolate, vanilla, smoke. Taste is a roasty coffee bomb. Wow. Booze not noticeable other than a warm lingering finish. Mouthfeel is silky, almost feels like the beer is gliding in your mouth. A huge beer, but everything melds together perfectly. Wonderful.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2016 Appearance: Pitch black body with a dense and tall dark tan head.
Aroma: Coffee and char, light chocolate and underlying caramel. Smells very nice.
Taste: Caramel forefront with some chocolate. Roast hits the back of the mid with lactose showing. Nice stout, shows no alcohol. Lingers caramel.
Palate: Thick, full bodied.
Overall: Damn good coffee stout, nothing is overbearing.

Sehr dunkel mit hellbraunem/braunem schaum. Malzbetont und schönes kaffearoma. Leichte rezenz. Feinherb und "kafig" im abgang.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The best stout Ive had to date. Dark color with tan creamy good sized head. Lots of roasted malts, chocolates, a touch of coffee, and hides the alcohol in both the nose and the palate. Fantastic stout. From now on the one Ill judge them all by.

Very nice stout. Easy to drink. It doesnt kick you in the mouth. No burn. Sweet, a little bitter, hints of coffee and chocolate. Goes great with cheese snacks or chocolate. Roasted flavor with great aftertaste.

750 ml bottle, no date on the bottle, but it has been sitting in my cellar for almost a year and a half, 1300th rating- Pours pitch black with a one finger dark tan head that sticks around for awhile. Aroma is coffee, licorice, chocolate and leather, moderately boozy. The taste is velvety chocolate, coffee, not too sweet which is nice, in fact it leaves a nice dry cocoa powder flavor in the finish, the coffee beans used here are obviously of high quality, not overbearing either, all blended wonderfully. Body is obviously huge, the beer coats the mouth long after the swallow, carbonation is medium. In love with this beer, a true masterpiece, I really wish I could get my hands on a barrel aged version now!
Great Arona. Roasted malt, coffee and caramel. Deep roasted malt and coffee flavor. Some vanilla in the finish. Outstanding!

Draught sampler flight at Sugar Maple, Milwaukee 23/viii/13. Vanilla & plum aroma, coffee bean, roast malt bitter, medium bodied. Could be fuller for its unnoticeable big ABV, but tasty and smooth fruity ImpStout. Maybe more impressive bottled?
Bomber. Black with a nice tan head. Chocolate, coffee, dried fruit. Very smooth with nice body.
Bomber split three ways. Near black with a tight, dark tan head. Mineraly, plums and chocolate. Smooth, creamy, earthy and boozy.

Pours an opaque black with a luscious coffee head into a snifter. Dissolves into a thin layer shortly after the aggressive pour.

Aroma is strong of coffee with some roasted malts, oak and a little earthiness.

Coffee plays the leading role in the flavor. The initial palate hit is of strong bitter coffee rounding into an earthy hop bitterness. Presence of oak and a slight bit of vanilla I also detect.

Mouthfeel is good and creamy. This is a coffee stout no doubt about it. Not even remotely close to too sweet. Low carbonation levels and it got better as it warmed.

I dont like a whole lot of AleSmith brews with the exception of this. Always glad when a bottle of Speedway comes my way as its way way too drinkable for a 12% big stout. It tastes better than the coffee I have every morning, but would probably get me fired from work if I make it my normal go to beverage.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2014 Bottle: Deep, dark - black with dark brown tints at the edges when held to the light. Creamy, small, fine light-tan head caps it off. Smooth, sweet aroma; roasted coffee beans, sweet, creamy, and milky as well with chocolate, light char, and even some marshmallow notes. The flavor is a delicious coffee bean attack; oily, roasted, charred, nearly burnt, and offset by a beautiful creamy and milky sweetness. Cocoa, fudge, and marshmallow make up the back-end, with more coffee in the finish. Heavy, oily, silky body and mouth feel... A masterpiece stout that never disappoints.

Well, got to do something nice for the 1000th. Aroma of coffee and cherries, beautiful. Hits you something like an Irish coffee, rich espresso, some chocolate, a pleasant sweet alcohol kick, with hints of caramel and vanilla. Really thick texture to it, a pleasure to drink. Excellent beer.
Bottle at kaisla, helsinki. Pitch black color, fantastic brown head. Aroma is coffee, roasty, sweet, vanilla. Full balanced body, sweet notes, roasty, coffee, wood, vanilla. Balanced and tasty.

(1/11/13) A - Pours with a nice thickness and a "glug glug" as it leaves the bottle. Single finger head dissipates quickly to a small tan ring. Decent carbonation. No light comes through when held up to the light.

S - Roast maltiness and coffee, as you would expect. However, the coffee is more sweet/fruity and light as opposed to an espresso or dark roast than many coffee stouts seem to use. Some nice dark fruit undertones. A little bit of alcohol too.

T - Roastiness and dark chocolate abound. Not too terribly coffee forward, likely due to what smelled like a lighter roast. There is a nice depth to the roastiness with notes of both dark chocolate bitterness and dark fruit sweetness.

M - Thick and chewy, almost syrupy but not quite. Little to no alcohol burn. The 12% is hidden well.

O - Loved the depths to the roastiness. Fairly straight forward coffee stout, but the complexities of the roastiness set it apart.

Bottle from a gypsy. Pours opaque black, thick mocha head that is diminishing and beautiful seafoam lace. Nose of roasted malt, bitter dark chocolate, prunes, caramel, figs, licorice, booze. This in a young bottle - 4/6/13 so its a little hot. Full body, bitter finish, lots of roast a little astringent.

This is a big beer. 750ml Bottle from 9/6/2013. This one should have settled a bit with age. Huge hints of coffee and vanilla and a ton of hottness on the back end. Still extremely drinkable for the ABV and would do better in the cellar to take off the bite.

Pours jet black with nice tan head. Aromas of roasted malt and coffee. Taste of espresso, caramel and chocolate. Hint of bitterness balances nicely.smooth easy drinking. Alcohol almost non existent for a 12 % abv. Very good. Will be on my list of must haves.
great beer, overall very smooth and balanced for its higher abv, predominant notes are of chocolate and a roasted coffee. will try again.

Some coffee, astringent roast, burnt sugar in the aroma. Pours thick black color with a mocha head and good lacing. Great mouthfeel nice thick and creamy coffee, caramel, dark chocolate awesome stuff.
This is one of the best stouts Ive ever had. Great color n taste. This is a classic brew. Dont pass on this if u can get it.

Small pour in a local San Diego bar. Wish I could have tried more! Aroma was great. Lots of malts, caramel, and coffee. Then more malts. Pours a typical brown expected from a stout with a nice medium head. Flavor is very unique and the palate just dances with flavors ranging from all kinds of malt, to coffee, chocolate and then a distinct malt finish. Really incredible considering I had such a small pour. A definite must try!
(bottle 28 /09-2013) Low brown head, black color, roasted aroma, smooth taste, roasted taste, very smooth taste, soft co2, full body.

Big thanks to richthevillan for sharing this big want. Black beer with medium tan head. Aroma of cocoa, coffee and hops. Taste is chocolate, hops, vanilla and licorice lacing. Slight oil slick on the palate. This is an excellent beer.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Aroma is roasted coffee, appearance is dark black, taste is very similar to smell, overall very good but expected more

On tap at brewery. Black with a creamy light brown head. Sweet chocolate, vanilla, and lightly vegetal drip coffee aroma. Thick creamy but sticky palate. Tastes of sugar, milk chocolate, roasty drip coffee, and finishing with bitter sweet dark chocolate and vanilla flavors. Earlier Rating: 6/13/2008 Total Score: 4.9Tasted at the Real Ale VIP Session.  Black with a dark brown head.  Dark chocolate and coffee aroma.  Roasty chocolate and coffee taste with a robust espresso finish.  All the goodness of speedway with more coffee flavor at every point.  I really liked this one.Earlier Rating: 5/2/2007 Total Score: 4.8750 mL bottle.  Roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Very smooth, velvety full bodied palate.  Intense coffee and chocolate flavor with a thick bitter finish.

750 ml bottle, bottled on 9/3/13. Pours dark brown black with a medium creamy brown head that retains well and laces the glass some.

The aroma is roasted, grainy, fudgy, chocolate with a little coffee.

The flavor is bitter roast, grains, chocolate, black licorice, a little dark fruit and some light roast coffee. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, solid imperial stout. This bottle seems lighter on the coffee than other samples Ive had.

2013: Strangely buttery nose, thats the first smell I get; something like burnt butter or butter melted or cooked in a pan blackened from cooking ground beef... the chocolate / cocoa character in the aroma has a mask of insufferable banana esters and a coating of lactose. Honestly, this is a simple aroma in a simple beer, the only malt play is like generic dark caramel extract syrup... theres no aroma hops and the coffee seems non-existent. Full body with noticeable alcohol (absent in the aroma, which is nice). Not hot or boozy but present. Syrupy (dark caramel malt syrup again), some sort of chocolate and coffee mixture noticeable. Bitterness noticeable in the aftertaste, otherwise muted. Mostly sweet with medium to low acid. While the aroma is mostly garbage I can enjoy the flavor and body enough to not pour it down the drain. But at $12 for a 750ml this will be another one-time purchase from AleSmith. Maybe this was 4.5-5.0 level back in the day, but objectively in 2013 this is a one-dimensional generic coffee stout, and if this is what the brewer(s) think it should smell like then I have to say they are off their rockers.


2003 (big grain of salt here, a 10 year old rating): Draft and bottle, multiple times each. Rating is from draft. Nice robust coffee and milk aroma. Rich, smokey, nutty, woody, and every other word you can think of... incredibly impressive beer. Has a rich fruit and licorice flavor backed up by smokey coffee and cream. I hate to describe it in terms of other beers, but it combines the dark fruit flavors of Expedition Stout with the roasted coffee richness of Old Rasputin.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2013 Fresh bottle. Black pour minimal head. This is a really good american imperial stout. Dark malty, touch of sweetness, chocolate coffee, very carbonated but dies down as it warms. Thick and creamy. Good but nothing really stands out, and nothing really sets it apart from the pack.  But nothing wrong with it either.

Black beer with a brown head which dissolves into a permanent ring on top of the beer and leaves a little drops of lacing on the glass. The aroma has chocolate, burned sugar, vanilla, liqueur, coffee, red wine and tiramisu cake. The taste is roasted or even burned, chocolaty and liqueury sweet, and licoricy salty. The mouthfeel is really thick and oily. The finish is pretty long and bitter with the alcohol warming up. Towards the end of the glass the alcohol starts coming up a bit more in the flavor, cutting off one overall point I almost gave it. Its still a really great imperial stout, and the bottle was big enough to be split between four persons as a dessert.

Pour is midnight black with a thin tan head. Nose is coffee, cocoa and roasted malt. Taste is lovely with notes of coffee and dark chocolate. Malt notes are present with hops for balance though this is a sweeter stout. Mouthfeel is thick though not oily. Overall very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bold rich coffee flavor that is smoother than most stouts I have drank. Its easy to drink and worth the price.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2013 11/24/13:
Pours a very dark brown with pillowy light brown head. Good retention and thin lacing. Aroma is roasted, dark malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is even richer, dark malt, roasted, dark chocolate, with a sweet alcohol finish. Medium body, soft carbonation and smooth texture. Better and much richer than I recall. 

9/17/13:
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with big light brown head. Settles in minutes with a little stringy lacing. Aroma is surprisingly sweet, roasted, chocolate. Flavor is sweet up front, fading into moderate roast and coffee tones, dark chocolate. The alcohol comes across surprisingly sweet and fruity. Actually not as dark and roasted as I had imagined. Soft carbonation, medium to full body, and very smooth texture. A good imperial stout, though I would prefer something a little less sweet.

Sort skum brun 
Kaffe lakrids chokolade tømmer 
Bitter moderat sød modrate 
Cremet flad 
@ F1

Bottle, Brew Dog Manchester. Prior to Black Crowes gig, March 2013. Id been wanting to try this mutha for some time. Poured Black as a Crowes wing with a plump tan head. A fine snout of chocolate, roast, coffee.. Thick, smooth and rich flavour with big roast, coffee and dark fruit alongside a slab of bitter chocolate. Skillfully smothered booze. Definitely some big nuts on show here.

Frothy-milk texture.
Hidden ABV. 
Booze milkshake? 
Great full body 
Bought from Wayne Whole Foods
Bottle @ home. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, anise, carmel, toffee. Flavor is coffee, caramel, toffee, mild anise. Very nice.
Pours a dark black with a thick brown head. Has a heavy dark chocolate espresso aroma. Has a sweet chocolate, coffee, caramel, and dark malt flavor. Thick but sweet beer.

Rating #2000 Pitch black appearance with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and raisins. Flavor is chocolate covered raisins, coffee, and caramel. Very complex and rich. This is one amazing stout deserving of its reputation

The race is over. Alesmith wins. The aroma is off the hook: thick, rich, and malty with some chocolate undertones. The taste even better: rich and chocolate with a roasted character. The finish is the best part smooth and inviting. How do they hide the 12%? Unbelievable!
Draft at Bier Stein, Eugene. Pours an opaque dark color, decent amount of tan head. Aroma roasty, coffee-forward. Body, full, roasty, with lingering alcohol notes. Just as lovely as in the bottle.

750ml bottle, poured into tulip (in stages obviously). Bottle looks a bit naff, hopefully the contents are a lot better. No date on the bottle - I bought it about 2 months ago. Pours quite thick black, big tan head forms but dissipates quite quickly. Initial sweet coffee smell, dark chocolate and sharp yeast. Body is medium to full, slightly foamy. Slightly over-carbonated for my liking. Coffee is subtle in taste, roasted barley, slight nail varnish/bourbon later on along with some muted caramel, finish is quite smooth. Alcohol is noticeable. Decent beer. I think that these coffee impys should be drunk as fresh as possible. Looking forward to a fresher one in the future.

Aroma: charred coffee, vanilla, worn leather and alcohol. Appearance: jet black body, beige and creamy head. Taste: mildly sweet cocoa, vanilla, bourbon give way to dark roasted and bitter coffee. Reminiscient of charbucks. Palate: surprisingly light body with creamy and soft mouthfeel. Finishes bitter but doesnt linger too terribly long.

This stout always impresses me because its opening notes are as smooth as many bourbon barrel aged stouts. Impressive work here, Alesmith, though I wonder if you used a lighter roast coffee if that would make this an even better beer.

Wow. This smells just fantastical, lots of chocolate, mild coffee, and caramel. Your immediately hit by heavy hitting chocolate and robust caramels. A mld third taste is bitter coffee. This pours deep oily and dark with a velvety tan head of an inch or so. Super viscous and pleasant on the palate. Overall, this is freaking amazing. Just damn awesome!

So good. Pours like motor oil and pitch black and tan head. Aroma coffee and chocolate. Thick body but doesnt leave that sticky feeling. Huge chocolate and coffee, them some toastyness in the end. Very good.
All around amazing beer. Its about as close to perfection as one can ever hour to achieve

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2014 Very dark with brown / beige head. Looks stunning. Malty strong dark chocolate and coffee, toffee. Taste is sweet with medium bitterness. Very strong and complex. This one you definitely need to take down slowly.

Pours pitch black with a nice tan head. Aroma is heavy in coffee with some chocolate scents and slight liquorice notes; very nice roasted malt backbone as well. Taste is an amazing balance between sweetness and bitterness, the finish is really nice. Full body, creamy mouth feel, and lively carbonation. The best imperial stout I have had to date.

Poured deep, dark brown with a small, frothy beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel, roast malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Full body, flavour of the aroma, dry, bitter chocolate, a little lcoholic heat in it.

Bottle purchased a year ago at City Beer. I could barely speak. Everything that others have said, this beer still lived up to expectations. Velvet smoothness. Coffee, Roasted malt, dark chocolate. There was a sweet hint of caramel, or was it black cherry? The details dont matter. Powerful and smooth. The flavours evolve on the palate in waves. No shit this stuff is huge. I think I saw through time. A beer I will not forget, and hopefully have again.
On tap at City Beer, july 2013. Jet black. Served quite cold. Lots of coffe and burned malt in the aroma. Taste is dark coffee, chocolate and bitter liquorice. Good stuff - as expected.

Cloy, malty aroma; black appearance with light brown head; chocolate and malty with strong alcohol taste; creamy with a light fizz on the palate; overall, a solid imperial stout but too heavy on the malty alcohol flavor for my taste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Red House, Newcastle on 28 July 2013.
Poured a sumptuous pitch black with a thick brown head. Aroma of dark coffee, roasted malt, liquorice, rum, dark fruit... so much! Flavour came in three bursts, it started with big burnt malt and coffee bitterness before moving to cappuccino, cocoa and caramel sweetness, which was perfectly balanced and did not outstay its welcome. It then had a consuming, wonderful bitterness of the roasted flavours and some warming, rounded alcohol. Slight whisky notes, oaky and the mouth feel is pure velvet; thick and so smooth. As close to beer perfection as is gets!
Chocolate on chocolate on chocolate. Holy richness. Not so much a beer as an after dinner treat. I can feel my stomach expanding by the second, but thats ok. Lives up to the reputation.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines, Birmingham. Its what I was led to expect. Its as good as I hoped. Its exactly what other people have told you.

75cl bottle. Pours black with a brown head. Coffee, roasted malt, licorice, sweetness, molasses in aroma. Very smooth mouthfeel.full bodied, oily. Roasted malt, salty licorice, sweet strong coffee in flavor. Wow, so balanced, so smooth. Still has so much flavor despite being in storage for a year. Long coffee, licorice finish. Lives up to the hype.-- bb/wp7

Pours motor oil black with a broen head that fades to a halo. Aromas of espresso and malt. Flavors of coffee, bit of chocolate in the end with a bitbof alcohol burn at the very end. Flavors of tobaccoand molases interslresed throughout. A very complex stout with many delicious layers, well worth the wait. I would recommend this beer to everyone.

Very dark pour, used motor oil black. Nice khaki head. Notes of coffee, chocolate and tobacco. Taste is amazing. Starts out coffee ends chocolate with a slight alcohol burn. Very smooth, very good. Get it.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2014 Oerhört elegant stout. Kjellander slänger upp en flaska på midsommar hos Wallén. Tungt. Precis lagom tryck i kaffe och rostade toner. Ingen vansinnessötma. Men vad gör Kjellander? Han häller halva flarran över ryggen på sig själv. Inget ombyte har han heller och får gå runt men en gigantisk speedwayfläck på tröjan resten av helgen.
     
     ---------      

Drar en 2012 parallellt mot en Speedway BA. Så oerhört balanserad och elegant. Helt fantastisk imp-stout. Dock svårt att fatta att Speedway-BA är samma öl i grunden. Snacka om att fatet har bidragit med smak och doft!

 --- 
Troligen 2012, möjligen 13 (inget datum på flaskan). Bra balans. inte ett spår av askfat. Drar mot 4 andra speedways. Snacka om ett bryggeri som sätter ribban.

Bottle shared with work colleagues. Thick viscous caramel brown ruby red colour pour with a dark tan loose head that fades quickly to a halo. Aroma is choc roast booze. As the beer opens up I get more sweet brown sugar a Belgian dried fruits. Palate is thick full bodied and velvet. Flavour is bold choc caramel warming alcohol. Finish is bitter roast that mellows as the beer opens up. The next bottle I get Im not going to be as generous.

Pours deep dark tree bark brown. Zero opacity even when held in front of a light. Nice slow viscosity for a beer. Nose is a beautiful rich, espresso and malty chocolate. Palate has a surprising bitter almost hoppy bite with deep toffee, coffee and burnt hot cocoa. Long finish that stays in the nasal and back of throat with lingering malt. Delicious stout indeed. My wife reviewed it as follows: I taste a good beer. Well said.

750ml bottle was the only beer I purchased on a recent vacation to Rancho Cucamonga, CA. Pours a thick black with decent mocha head and some lacing. Aroma is full of coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate. Flavor might also have some dried fruits and definitely some alcohol. Taste is slightly sweet in the middle, but bitter and boozy at start and finish. Body is full with a smooth mouthfeel and minimal carbonation. This is my idea of what an Imperial Stout should be. Over-the-top may not be for everyone, but it was exactly what I had hoped for, once I finally found it.
Bottle. Pours dark black, great coffee and roasted malt aroma. nice tan head, terrific cream and loads of coffee. malts and some chocolate

Bottle. Very dark body, almost black. Tan head. Aroma has coffee and some alcohol sharpness but its mostly well hidden. Smooth and oily mouthfeel. Taste has roast and coffee... rich but somewhat simplistic. The alcohol sharpness and big roast are supporting each other. I dont get licorice or dried fruit that would add something to the character. This is just very big and bold but in terms of complexity it doesnt do much for me. Pretty nice but it is certainly overrated here. Gets cloying after drinking 200 ml or so. As it warms up the alcohol starts to sting...

Aroma of coffee, chocolate, oak and alcohol. Coffee colored and thickly viscous. Not much head but dark cream colored foam. Taste of coffee, chocolate, tobacco, leather, port. You can feel the alcohol in the finish. Heavy body that's very smooth, like good chocolate milk. Low carbonation. Overall, the best stout I've had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 Coffee and chocolate nose. Thick black pour and a nice tan head. Roasted malt, bitter chocolate and slightly boozy with coffee on the finish. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2016 Pours black with tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee, with burnt malt.  Roasted chocolatey-coffee flavor,, with bitter burnt malts. A little bit of smokiness. Alcohol hidden well, but otherwise this beer is pretty potent.  Robust flavor, I guess you could say. But the brew remains drinkable, despite the seeming harshness and 12% abv.  Probably one of the best standard imperial stouts in existence.

750 ml - pours black with huge brown head and decent lacing. Nose is milk chocolate and roast. Flavor adds coffee and licorice for the lack of a better term. dry to the lips. slight alcohol burn. Bitter like dark coffee. I was hoping for more a fruit presence as it warmed, because the coffee does really dominate, making it rather unidirectional. Woody aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2014 Bottle - poured black with hints of ruby on edges. Aroma is smokey charred wood scent. Texture is silky and somewhat thin. Taste is boozey and charred smokey tastes are dominant. Coffee and chocolate tastes are minimal. Finish is smooth and dry with definite alcohol taste. Excellent tasting RIP, was expecting more coffee taste but overall great beer.rerating 8/17/14 : aged 2 bottles from last year july. Ageing is a must! This beer is amazing! Boozey taste mellowed and coffee/chocolate flavors really stand out. Original rating was a 4.2 fresh but age definetly improves this beer!

Bottle from mane liquor. Jet black pour with a nice tanned head. Good lacing on the glass. Nose is powdered milk chocolate, vanilla and roasted coffee. Taste is pretty smooth with more of the same coming from the aroma. Too be honest I'm not certain what the hype is. I'd prefer batch 18 over this. Still pretty decent stout none the less!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 750ml at C&G with Taylor and everyone else. Pours black small disappearing head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate,  malt, vanilla. Taste is chocolate, big savory malt, coffee. Amazing beer. Awesome.

inky black with a tan head and spotty lacing. rich, bitter-sweet aroma with notes of coffee and anise. taste has notes of coffee, licorice, and even a strong hop presence that shines through the thick, dark malt taste. finish is long and leaves a similar sensation as that of a dry red wine. a beautiful beer.

Pours super dark, with a long lasting brownish tan head. Aroma is strong, of malt, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is complex and strong: coffee, malt and hops, chocolate, and the alcohol kick is there too. A very good imperial stout. Thumbs up!
Shared with ABL. Treacle poor with hot chocolate noise. Toxicology good. Enjoy danyul.

1 pint 9.4 fl oz (750ml) bottle. Pours jet black with a foamy brown head and aroma of roast malt, dark fruits, coffee, boozy. Taste is slightly sweetish roasted malt with dark chocolate, coffee, smoke & alcohol plus some caramel notes. Nicely smooth mouthfeel, full bodied, soft but crisp carbonation, clean warming finish. Very drinkable!
Wow. Share with ABL. Lovely treat. Black as the surroundings, went down a treat, rich and warming but not overpowering. Yeah baby, beer highlight of a most enjoyable evening.

Una de las mejores cervezas que he probado: Todos los aspectos son buenos!
Sabor, color, aroma, retrogusto, cuerpo, espuma,....,todo es màs que destacable. Nadie puede decir que es una gaseosa de 12°!.
Única pega: 16 pavos la botella!, pero sin duda, dinero bien empleado si disfrutas con una buena cerveza.

Bottled in April, tasted in August. Thick black pour. Nice boozy aroma. Exceptionally made with a great, crisp carbonated mouthfeel that never feels overdone. Flavor is strong but smooth. Never taste the abv. Coffee is subtle and well integrated (all the flavors are). It's straightforward, but beautifully so. Everything working together toward a coherent flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Lovely full bodied stout - a warm recommendation. This stout should be a staple in every well-assorted beer shop or bar.

Growler. Pours a clear dark brown. Perfect imperial stout nose of bakers chocolate, roasted malt, light anise and cinnamon, and a touch of balsamic vinegar. Divine taste of smooth house-blend coffee and roasted malt with a light, hot, mocha finish; a slight woody spice emerges late. Just awesome.

Amazing Stout, pours like motor oil, black with two finger mocha head. Smells of big coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. Tastes up front of coffee, bakers chocolate, a little dark fruit and nice roasted malts. Hides ABV very well. Smooth Stout. Thick chewy beer, overall the the best stout I have had yet.

750 ml bottle shared with dad bought at Winooski Beverage. A: chocolate, roasty/coffee, some caramel. App: pitch black beige head. Good lacing T/p: full body with roasty/ sweet and long finish. A little heat from the alcohol. O: amazing brew like the maltiness and overall balance. Good job.
This is crazy strong, thick, dark and rich. Oh my God is it strong but you just cant stop drinking it

Bottle. Phenomenal. Fig, raisin, plum on nose. Finishes nice and dry with burnt dark chocolate and espresso hints. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 On tap at rock n brews el segundo served in a tulip. Coffee, bourbon, vanilla aroma. Smooth malty carmel flavors accompany what was on the nose. Sneaky booze heat.
Pours a black color with red/tan head. Aromas of coffee and chocolate. There is a heat up front from the alcohol that settles into favors of chocolate and coffee.

7/28/13. Big bottle from CBO $16.99. Shared with Luke and Doug at crabapalooza13. Absolutely a top 10 beer for me. Unbelievable taste and smell. Perfect

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2013 22 oz bottle from total wine. Pours pitch black with with dark tan head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Consistency is like butter. Taste is coffee, chocolate, caramel, with a hint of the 12 abv. A beast of a beer, absolutely loved it.
Opaque black with khaki head. Alcohol and dark chocolate aroma. Dry, bitter finish. Alcohol is very present with a nutty warm finish.
Bomber poured into a snifter. Strong dark chocolate and alcohol smell. Tastes of dark chocolate and coffee. Alcohol is well hidden. Dangerously smooth beer. Incredible.
So chocolatey while cold. As it warms bourbon chocolate nose, caramel foam, super balanced. Tart but not super boozy. Not super warming either. If you wanted to, you could slam it down...just dont.
Mmm, very nice, if huge, imperial stout. Slightly run of the mill, but delicious. Of the greats, I prefer KBS, but I have no complaints here. :-)
UPDATED: OCT 25, 2013 The aroma is full of chocolate and coffee. This beer is ridiculously smooth. Full of creamy chocolate (almost like chocolate milk) and coffee. Amazing beer.

pours a pitch black with a khaki head with very nice lacing. Aroma is of roasted malts, bakers coco, gourmet coffee, licorice, molasses, and some vanilla. Taste is similar to the aroma but also has some nice oak and tobacco notes. Has a full body with a super creamy mouthfeel and a semi bitter, long finish. Overall, a amazing imp. stout that all others should look to for a textbook example of the style.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2014 (#500) Black, rich creamy brown head, lasting with lace. Aroma is roasty, chocolate, coffee, some vanilla. Flavor much the same. Full, soft, velvety body. Rich and creamy. Nice alcohol warming. Semi sweet, good bitterness, giving way to an Amazing finish; roasty, chocolate coffee with long duration. The total package. Top notch. UPDATE: even better fresh at the brewpub. I could have had it all day. So smooth and delicious. Just awesome.

coffee, sweet dark fruit. medium body aroma. 
coffee, dark chocolate, malty, roasty taste. fairly smooth, medium body. A little drying at the end, but not too bad, a little biter, a little alcohol as well..but again, nothing overpowering.

Appearance: Black with two finger thick tan head.
Aroma: Chocolate, coffee, slight roast/smoky notes, pine, yogurty, bread and caramel.
Taste: Chocolate, vanilla, roast coffee flavour, treacle, vinous/cognac, medium sweetness, medium/high bitterness and medium sourness.
Palate: Smooth thin texture, medium body, prickly carbonation. The aftertaste lingers with an intense sweetness and bitterness, these qualities are not as noticeable at the start but grow in the finish. There is also an alcohol warmth in the ending.
Comments: Amazing. Left a glass lace.

Seriously the most the overrated beer out there. Let me start by saying I do have a fondness for stouts and everything about this spoke to me - the promises of coffee, chocolate and roasted sensations throughout. Im not adverse to a really dark, rich stout - in fact, I love them. This, however, is a mess. A clumsy combination of overly sweet coffee and poorly masked alcohol made this almost undrinkable after the first glass. I tried so hard to keep an open mind given the great reputation it has but in the end Im just left completely baffled as to why this is held in such high esteem. Even if you happen to like this formula, I have to believe anybody would agree that theres better stouts out there, for half the price too. A bizarre anomaly. 

I gave it a 2.8 because it does look fabulous, it smells rather nice, and it isnt completely horrible - its just a huge let down.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2014 A really good beer, lots of coffee in aroma. Taste has lot of coffee as well, with a soft mouthfeel. Good beer, but nevertheless I expected more from it due to the extremely high ratings.

On nitro @ the brewery. Pours super thick dead black with heavy viscous mocha head. Aroma is rich milk chocolate, light roasted espresso beans, and just a bit of roasty malt behind all of that. Taste is incredibly smooth dark roasted malts - not a hint of charring which you often see in imperial stouts. Coffee, chocolate, syrupy port flavors on the finish. The nitro only makes this beer smoother than it was before. There are a couple that may be the equal of this beer (Abyss, Ten Fidy, Parabola...) but theyre not better.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 rated from backlog. Smells banana, chocolate, coffee. Full bodied, Nice carbonation. Nice round finish. Overall: Very Nice sipper.

750ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a medium tan head, which lasts well and leaves good lacing. Creamy dark chocolate and bitter, slightly fruity coffee mix with praline, herbal hops and a touch of alcoholic warmth to create the aroma. Bittersweet herbal hops up front mix with smooth, nutty praline. Bitter dark chocolate and dark, bittersweet coffee combine with more praline in a silky smooth mid-palate. Hazelnut, Irish cream and bittersweet coffee come through in a smooth finish, which leaves a lingering warmth. This is a beer as excellent as its reputation suggests, with a level of restraint and subtlety not common in imperial stouts. Its coffee and dark chocolate flavours are nicely unified by the nutty praline flavour that runs through it and gives it weight and line. A lovely imperial stout indeed.

As far as my stout contest this weekend, Speedway wins by about a full car length. If I took the best of @foundersbrewing #kbs and @bellsbrewery #expeditionstout #speedwaystout is the answer! This beer is such a beauty from initial pour and appearance to the pleasant aroma of chocolate cherries covered in smoke to the euphoric creamy vanilla coffee char taste. Its to believe this stout is 12% now I need to try BA Speedway Stout and Dark Lord.

750 mL bottle. Black pour, with a medium, bubbly, tan head and thin lacing. The aroma is very strong coffee and chocolate, molasses, and light orange rinds. Very sweet flavor, with a light roasted bitterness. Very heavy body. The mouthfeel is very thick, syrupy, and velvety. A huge, syrupy beer. The aroma is immense, and the mouthfeel is perfect.

Big incredible beer. Pours black with tsn head and some lacing. Nose is espresso and bitter chocolate. Aromas of espresso, bitter chocolate, burnt toast, some dark fruit. Tastes big sweet and medium bitter. Cremy body with lively carbonation.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a finger thick, creamy mocha head. Aroma is roasted malts with oak barrels, leather, tobacco and some rubbery whiffs, as well as dark berries and coffee. Full oily body with soft carbonation. Flavour is sweet malts with tobacco and vanilla, as well as deep dark notes of tar, oil and coffee with coffee and wood in the finish.
Mørk svart farve med beige skum. Lukt av kaffe, bek og sjokolade. Smak av kaffe, sjokolade, bek og frukt. Cardinal.
Lite skum. Herlig lukt av bek, kaffe, sjokolade, katamell og krydder. En god munnfølelse av kaffe, pepper og sjokolade. Smaken var herlig balansert av kaffe, sjokolade og krydder.

I don't drink a lot of stouts... and that probably affects my rating of this beer. I wasn't able to resolve much coffee aroma or flavor which was quite disappointing to me. The alcohol was extremely well hidden. I just didn't particularly like this beer.

65 cl bottle @ home. Pours black with a little sediment and a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and liquorice. Flavour is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, and some warming alcohol  with a bitter finish.

[US West Coast Trip 2013] Jaha, innan jag skriver något om ölen bör det tilläggas att detta blir no #100 denna månaden, tyvärr är inte alla 100 druckna i USA men men. Aroman, här hittar man mycket. Choklad, sötma, KAFFE, mandelmassa ;) jag har ju inte riktigt blivit en stout-man så kan tyvärr inte höja den till skyn. Men Aroman är kalas, tjockleken och "rundigheten" är fantastisk. Färgen och smaken har jag dessvärre lite svårare för ;(

Flaske fra Vinmonopolet. Sort, oljeaktig viskositet, lysebrunt skum. Fløyelsmyk, litt kremete konsistens i munnen. Kaffe, brent malt, lakris, sjokolade, tjære, vanilje, humle. Denne innfridde til forventningene
