S - Probably the best part of this beer. Huge coffee/espresso presence. Roasted malts, vanilla and milk chocolate. Slight hint of alcohol.

T - Very smooth mouth feel. Roasted malts, smooth coffee, and chocolate. Not very bitter or alcoholic. 

O - A good coffee stout, but certainly not the best out there. The smell was fantastic, but the taste really didnt stand out. Perhaps I should have had this when it was fresher and the coffee was more prevalent. Will seek out again next year!

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2012 
75 cl bottle @ Delirium Café Hoppy Loft, Brussels. Rated on 20.07.2010
Aroma has coffee, cocoa and dark chocolate. Flavour has lots of coffee, some dark chocolate and cocoa. Thick, but smooth palate. Some warming alcohol at the end of the glass. Balanced and very good! 9-4-9-4-17=43

75 cl bottle @ OConnells. "193 11 08 19 L" on bottle neck,
Aroma is rather intensive with slightly sweet dark chocolate and cocoa. Flavour is dry with roasted coffee, some slightly stinging and warming alcohol, and very dark chocolate. Some licorice notes as this warms up. Very nice, although the presence of alcohol disturbs me a bit. 8-5-9-4-17=43

2009 bottle, Pours jet black with some head and lacing. Nose is this amazing mix of black malt, molasses with slight candy sugar. First sip is a lovely combination of bittersweet chocolate, coffee and black malt. Finish is amazing for an Imp. Stout. Lingers just right with a quick vinous quality. This beer is awesome!?

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 Bottle at tasting, side by side with the BA speedway. Black pour, thin tan head. Aroma of freshly ground coffee, roasty malts, chocolate and caramel. Flavor is bitter roasted coffee, wonderful balance with sweet and bitter and loads of coffee. Very nice brew.

750mL corked bottle poured almost black into glass with big beige head with plenty of retention and lots of lacing.  Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee.  Taste is strong coffee up front which mellows to chocolate and roasted malts and finishes with some more coffee and ends with some hoppy bitterness and more coffee.  Very complex beer with a great balance between malty sweetness and coffee-hop bitterness.
Dark brown with a thick brown head. Roasted with coffee tones. Malt, coffee an bitterness. Full body with a long bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 Rerate 121007
This is an absolute masterpiece!
Perfectly fine tuned palate. Coffee, chocolates, dark fruits, tar you name it. It has it almost all!

On bottle at Öl&Whiskymässan
Pours black with low head. Aromas of coffe and oak/wood. Creamy round and bitter. Very good beer with no highs or lows.
Sampled at SB & WF 2011. Pitch black with a small brown head. Smells chocolate and smoky. Tastes chocolate, smoky and abit barry with a similar finish.

Sample @ SBWF 2011. Pours deep redish deep dark brown with a small tanned head. Aroma is fullbodied vinous madeira dark fruits raisns vanilla.  Flavor is fullbodied malty roasted bitter sweet warming alcohol dark fruits. Finishes longlived sweet and bitter.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2012 Sample @ SBWF on September 29. Pours black with a small mocha head. Smell is quite subtle which I didnt expect and has hints of coffee and chocolate. Taste is sweet and malty. Theres roasted malts and lots of coffee. There a warm tingling alcohol sensation and you can also find some dark fudge in there. Very nice.Re-rate. Bottle @ The Rover. Pitch black with small dark mocha head. Intense smell of dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, alcohol and wood. Big taste similar to the smell. Long lived coffee as chocolate finish. Very tasty!Another re-rate. Have had this almost 10 times now and it deserves a better rating. Very good beer. Always want to drink this.

Gift from Kevin and Deb at Grape and Gourmet in Va Beach, VA.  Pours a very dark brown/black with a small tan head.  Aroma and flavor of coffee with a sweet finish.  A great beer.  Thanks Kevin and Deb.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2012 This is one of the most beautiful beers Ive ever seen. Its thick and pitch black with a dark head, like coffe with lots of cream. It reeks of roasted malts and alcohol, with some dark chocolate and coffee, but it isnt as impressive a nose as I was hoping, mainly due to a medicinal touch the alcohol confers to it. Upon taking a sip, however, my opinion changed completely. The taste is SPECTACULAR, with the coffee and dark chocolate notes being much more noticeable and impressive here. Whats more impressive is that it manages to be absolutely drinkable, much more so than other coffee-infused stouts, and yet the coffee is so strong and elegant that you dont have to actively seek it out to know its there. The palate is creamy, elegantly and sufficiently carbonated, and not oily at all. This isnt the most complex stout Ive had, but its definitely one of the tastiest and most balanced. And, as a rule, I love coffee stouts, so Im in love with this.
UPDATED: SEP 29, 2011 Bottle. Dark brown colour with off white head. Clear coffee and chocolate aromas. Some caramel in the flavour. Tasty stuff. Abv is completely hidden. Impressive.

Bottle. Pours pretty much pitch black with a lasting foamy tan head. Aroma is very roasty with notes of coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, raisins and salty liquorice. Flavour is like the aroma, roasty with lots of coffee, reasonably sweet but perfectly balanced and with a hint of saltiness. Hardly any noticeable alcohol. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation and a lingering roasty finish. This is an outstanding Imperial Stout, very hard to fault and one of the best I have tried in a very long while.

750 bottle thanks to weihenweizen, huge thanks!  Pours pitch black with a nice light brown head with great lacing through out the entire the snifter, aroma is huge with tons of coffee and chocolate, there is a touch of booze on the nose as well, the flavor has an awesome chocolate front end with a finish of coffee, toffee and burnt toast.  The mouthfeel is nearly perfect, so smooth, all around awesome brew.

Pours black and syrupy.  The caramel colored head gives a great appearance, but vanishes rather quickly.  No lacing worth mentioning.  The nose is of strong coffee and dark fruits.  The same flavors come through with a slight saltiness. Some bitterness coming through at the end.  The alcohol is present but subdued; I would not guess 12% ABV if I didnt have prior knowledge.  A fair amount of carbonation is present.  Id like a little less; but this is one hell of an imperial stout.

Rating #631, bottle from Toft Vin Islands Brygge  

Udseende: 4/5 
Til at starte med ikke noget specielt, og skummet former sig næsten helt cola-agtigt indtil man hælder hårdt, hvorefter et pænt og stabilt skum med en ganske acceptabel holdbarhed dog opstår.
Øllen er naturligvis helt brunsort med beige skum som forventet. Der opstår de eftertragtede "lacings" når den bliver drukket, hvilket lige hiver øllen op på 4 point i udseende.
 
Duft: 8/10 
Absolut kraftig aroma da øllen kan duftes så snart kapslen er fjernet fra flasken. Især da vi taler om en stout, en øltype hvor duften nogle gange kan være en anelse undertrykt i sammenligning med IPAer eller andre typer med fokus på aromahumlen, er dette bemærkelsesværdigt og et rigtig godt tegn. På 40 centimeters afstand fra glas og flaske former sig ikke de store detaljer af aromaen, men med næsen tættere på glasset afsløres lakrids, til dels noget engelsk lakrids, nybrygget sort kaffe, søde kaffegrums, brændte og ristede malte, lidt flydende chokolade og noget krydret humle.  

Smag: 8/10 
Udover at chokoladen er tydeligere til stede, vil jeg ikke mene at smagen er synderligt overraskende i forhold til duften. Det vil dermed sige at smagen først og fremmest består af en lækker chokoladesmag, lakrids, en anelse af søde kaffegrums, brændte og ristede malte, og en let antydning af træ blandet med nogen alcohol. Kaffenoterne er mig noget utydelige i forhold til hvad jeg havde forventet, og alkoholen bliver lidt for tydelig til min smag. Jeg tør næsten ikke skrive det om sådan et velrennomeret bryg, men alkoholen bringer øllen en smule ud af balance, og den ville have haft godt af en anelse mere sødme. Chokoladen er godt til stede i forvejen, men man kunne måske have leget lidt med noget ekstra kaffesmag og en gang søde chokolademalte til at afbalancere det hele.  

Mundfornemmelse: 5/5 
Utrolig blød og cremet bryg der nærmest føles som silke i munden. Jeg har kun stiftet bekendtskab med én anden øl der slår denne mundfølelse, og det var Mikkellers Beer Geek Weasel.
Jeg fristes nærmest til at sige at den er blødere end silke, men den lidt kradse alkohol trækker i anden retning. Karboneringen er ganske mild, hvilket efter min mening er optimalt for denne øltype.  

Alt i alt: 17/20

Bottle. Pours jet black with creamy dark tan coloured head. Big aromas of dark roasted grain, coffee and bitter chocoltae. Flavours are much the same with creamy chocolate followed by some roasted grain bitterness. Fullish creamy mouthfeel. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 Kindly shared by motortoddhead.  Deep black with dark khaki head.  Fresh roasted coffee, dark malt/fruit, cream.  Great use of the coffee with a very green, earthy taste to the roast.  Bittersweet chocolate, toffee.  Great roasted finish with mild acid on the finish.  Re-rate:  definitely needs some age.  Fresh has too much hot licorice/hop presence.  Wish coffee was more prevalent.  Reality rate -0.4

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Sampled at the brewery In August 2011.  Nice chocolate and coffee aroma.  Taste is excellent. Really excellent blend of coffee and chocolate. Goes down smooth.   Well balanced.   Update.  Bottle on Feb 23, 2012.  Aroma is roasted malts,  some vinous character, coffee, toffee and burnt sugar.  Taste is roasted malts and a bittersweet flavor.   The level of carbonation is low and the body is medium.  Bottle again on 12/27/12.  Should have aged this one a little.

750 bottle at least 3 years old. Pours oil black with no head-flat.  Nose is super roasty, with hints of chocolate and coffee. Taste is just a bit sharp, with some sweetness, bitter roastiness, some coffee. Super thick and chewy. Alcohol is there but not overwhelming for such a strong beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 28, 2011 This is a stout that looks, smells, and tastes big. Pours a jet black with an beige to tan head. The nose is of coffee, coco nibs or dark chocolate, roasted caramel malts, and a touch of a dark fruit, maybe over ripe fig. This is an extremely well balanced stout that I could drink all day. For being 12% I found the alcohol to be very well hidden with this beer showing me no real heat. One of the best IS available for my money.

Bottle generously shared by Clyx. Gothenburg, September 2011

Pours ink black with a creamy brown foam. The nose is rich but not too heavy and overpowering. Deep aromas of roasted coffee, dark bitter chocolate, vanilla and small fruity fragrances of berries. Perfect subtle sweetness in the aroma. The taste is very balanced and not the least bit straggly. Lots of wonderful chocolate and coffee flavours covers the alcohol superbly. I could never have imagined this being 12%. Such a smooth beer doing everything perfect - honestly, its almost too perfect.

Bottle bought from brewdog.com. Stunning, just stunning, its hard to pick any fault with this beer. It is MASSIVE in every way. Bucket loads of coffee aroma and chocolate taste. Great texture and perfectly balanced, it never feels to sweet. Probably the best beer I have ever had.

Aroma: Chocolate, coffe, raisins.
Taste: Coffe, chocolate, raisins, karamell, grapefruit.
Mouthfeel: Balanced, begins sweet and finish dry and finish of quickly.
Notes: A very dangerous beer, never would guessed it was 12 %. Great balance and great.
What can I say great high gravity beer. Pete has a great thing. Sad no pints but I understand. One on my favorites!

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2011 On tap @ the brewery.Pitch black pour, lasting tan head - looks just like an Imperial Stout should.  Lots of coffee in the aroma and flavor, roasted malt and dark chocolate as well.  Became more intense and flavorful as it warmed.  This is an exceptional brew.

2009 bottle poured into a tulip glass.

A - Pours dark as night black with a nice one and a half finger tall tan head, dissipating down to a light film, leaving webs of lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of chocolate malt, rich espresso, molasses, dark fruits, and a faint hint of booze. Very complex yet enjoyable nose.

T - Plenty of rich coffee right off the bat slowly giving way to a sweet mix of chocolate and molasses. The feel is very creamy, how all stouts should be in my opinion. The finish is a mix of sweetness and dark roast. This is one awesome beer.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth feel with a rich, bold, body. The finish is all sweet roast, lingering for some time.

O - I love this beer. It is complex yet easy to drink. I can only imagine what the BA version tastes like. Someday I will get one!!

Pours black with a one-finger brown head. Epic! Huge aroma of chocolate, roast malt, alcohol and light coffee. Flavor is big on the milk chocolate, with a strong alcohol presence that warms you up.  Wonderfully creamy mouthfeel. Absolutely delicious - I would love to have this one aged a few years.
Pitch black body with mild tan head. A big beer in every sense. Colossal flavours and mouthfeel without losing balance. The usual suspects of RIS ingredients are all present here. Fantastic.

Pours a deep mahogany with deep head.  Nose is alive with chocolate, burnt malt and alcohol.  Full in the mouth bursting with elements of chocolate, fig, hazelnut, and sweet burnt malt.  Finishes with a puckering alcohol burn.

Oily, pitch black pour with a very thin head that dissipates quickly. Huge roasty aroma. Ripe with coffee, dark chocolate, dark malts, currants, licorice, and a little alcohol. Flavor is not quite as coffee-forward as I expected, though Ive been sitting on the bottle for several months and Im not sure how old it was when I bought it.The primary flavor is dark roasted malts, as youd expect with a stout this big, with notes of licorice, toffee, and a very light bitterness on the finish.Body is soft and chewy, and extremely satisfying. A mild alcohol burn lingers, but its not bad considering the ABV. Really a delicious stout and deservedly one of the top ranked, though Id like to try it fresh to get some more coffee flavors.

Poured from a bottle into a chalice.
Aroma- Coffee, chocolate, with a hint of alcohol
Appearance- Perfect looking stout, pitch black with a healthy amount of fluffy tan head, great lacing.
Taste- Coffee up front, backed up by roasted malts and chocolate, very nice!
Palate- Great carbonation for the style. Flavors linger on the palate.
Overall- One of the best coffee forward stouts out there! Very deserving of its reputation.

Poured pitch black with a milk chocolate head. The head dissipated in less than a minute. Smells primarily of dark chocolate; with secondary notes of vanilla, and coffee.   Tastes the same, but with an alcoholic burn. I wish this were a 12 oz bottle or that I had shared with a friend. The 750 ml bomber was too much for 1 person, but Im not really complaining.

Dark brown to black with a dense greyish head. Huge aroma of cofee, liqourice, caffe latte and citric hops. Begins medium sweet and finishes nice and bitter. Excellent palate, creamy with low carbonation and a loooong finish. Masterclass.

Really great stout! Pours dark with a light brown head. Aromas of coffee and chocolate. Although Im not a fan of actual coffee, I found that it was a coffee aroma than actual coffee flavor. Incredibly smooth for the alcohol content!

Lets get down to business. 750ml bottle. pours opaque black with big tan lace and resilient tan head. light mocha, caramel, grain, dark choc, coffee bean, citrusy grassy hops, anise, roast, smoke and wood. Full-med body, nice caramel rounding out a complex roast, rich  dark malt backbone. Big chocolate lingering through with a genuine hop flavour and bitterness working with the roast for a lingering impression. Big beer. Big Character. A Must have.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Rapes Peche Mortel. Great coffee beer that is just on the line of going overboard with coffee but doesnt really cross it. Chocolate covered coffee beans. So smooth.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2012 Black with a huge tan head.  Aroma of coffee, dark malts and dark chocolate.  Flavor starts off with dark malt bitterness followed by dark roast coffee, dark chocolate, and a hint of alcohol.  Very well balanced.  Med/full body with more carbonation than expected( but not an innapropriate amount).  excellent beer.  I would like a little more depth in the middle of the sip, but its a nice beer overall.

Richmond Gathering. This is seldom seen in my area so thanks to the person who brought this: Charred oak and bakers chocolate nose. Black pour, medium tan head, good lacing. Tar, charred oak, bakers chocolate flavor. Finishes with dark chocolate. Viscous, full body. Alcohol well concealed. This is definitely my type of imperial stout.

Bottle, pours black with very nice fluffy creamy light brown head... nose..coffee, notes of chocolate, roasted malt and licorice.... the flavor is very nice with taste of espresso, dark chocolate, roasted malt...the mouthfeel is coffee,cream, sweet, orange chocolate...... :)...... love this!...
C: Very opague black. S: Coffe, roasty, malt. T: Roasty, chocolate, coffee. P: very full body.
Really solid stout. Taste, aroma, mouthfeel, appearance all fantastic. Finish is delicious and really lingers

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2016 Re-rate October 5th 2016. This beer badly needs a rerate from me I feel, so here we go. Bottle @ home. Opaque pitch black color, full sized long lasting dark brown head that leaves fair lacing. Aroma is malts, dark malts, coffee, a hint of liquorice and dark chocolate. Actually the dark chocolate is way stronger in the flavor. Malts, dark malts, dark chocolate, coffee and slight roast with a moderate bitter finish, coffee and dark chocolate lingering finish. Full body, thick texture, suitable quite soft carbonation. Lovely beer. -- Original rating: Opaque black with a brown creamy head. Little sweet, roasted, coffee and dark malts in the smell. Taste a little sweet, little bitter but very good. Very nice full body and nice carbo. Very good beer! 8-3-8-4-15=3.8.

Bottle:
Small light brown tan head on the top top of a black colored beer.
Smell coffee, espresso, sweets, light creamy.
Taste coffee, espresso, coffee beans, dark chocolate, bitter, dark spices, roasted grains and fruit.
Nice bitter light coffee-ish aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a light creamy texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
Bottle 750ml
Pours pitch black with a creamy tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and licorice. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light to medium bitter. Body is full, texture is sticky, carbonation is soft.

07/07/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (750ml bottle). Nera densa, intensa, liquorosa, con riflessi color caffè, schiuma modesta, appena persistente, color cappuccino. Aroma intenso di malti tostati, caffè, liquirizia, vaniglia, cioccolato, con note alcoliche evidentissime. In bocca è meravigliosamente bilanciata, cioccolatosa, caffettosa, con note di liquirizia e spezie, liquorosa, alcolica. Corpo pieno, consistenza oleosa, vellutata, carbonazione soft. Imperial stout meravigliosa.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2015 750ml bottle shared @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Rated 31.7.2010 - Extremely well balanced imperial stout. Massive roasty aroma, pours pitch black with a small beige head. Smooth, heavy taste with nice bitter and roasty finish. World class.

Re-rated on 29.5.2012 @ Treffipub, Helsinki (7? for a 750ml bottle!). Wow, still just as good as before. Much hoppier than I remembered, probably this bottle is quite fresh. Nom nom.

Re-rated on tap at AleSmith observation room. Vertical with BA SS. Wow, so much coffee here. Super fresh and roasty. Awesome.
. Bottle. Pitch black. Smells of coffee, roast and malt. Tastes sweet and smokey with slight abv presence. Really balanced. Really good.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2013 Date: July 3, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Beer Tasting, Bloomington, MN Appearance: Opaque black with a medium amount of head Aroma: Chocolate Flavor: Strong coffee start with a slight dry bitter finish Other: A very good beer at a tasting with some other amazing beers.

June 14, 2013, bottle shared by Brandon.  Black pour with some head.  Just a bit too much dry roast for me, though this is still solid.  Took down the aroma by 1 and overall by 1 to get to a 4.0.

Somewhat disappointed with this one. Has the body and mouthfeel of a big beer but failed to deliver on the taste. Pours very thick black with little carbonation. Not a huge amount of coffee on the nose. Not a huge amount of coffee on the taste either but  is deffinately present. Very sweet and syrupy. A good imperial stout but not the coffee explosion I was hoping for.

Pours a jet black with a very dark head.  that laces the glass.  Strong molasses, caramel and coffee with hops aroma.  Creamy mouthfeel with a bitter initial bite that warms to a coffee and alcohol finish.  Very big beer.  

Id say the closest thing Ive ever had is the Bells Expedition Stout (which itself is a very excellent beer), but it doesnt have quite as much coffee as Speedway, but you would be very close.

750 mL bottle.  Pours black with a sizeable tan brown head.  Thick coffee aroma with cocoa, roast, bits of smoke, molasses.  Flavor has lots of coffee, blending well with syrupy cocoa, molasses, roasty, ashy tones.  Great, complex, full-bodied imperial stout.

750 mL 2010 bottle. Pours a thick dark brown/black with a thick brown head. Coffee and bourbon aromas with hints of chocolate. Complex tastes abound, including coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and probably a host of others I was too transfixed to isolate. Given 12% ABV, this was shockingly smooth. Incredibly thick and sludgy. No exaggeration - this beer put me right into a food coma; passed out within minutes of finishing. Next time I will split this bottle with more than one other person... utterly dominated.

Pours motor oil thick, near sludgy, and jet black in color. Bubbly dark brown head. The aroma of coffee fills the room as soon as you open the bottle. Sweet dark chocolate notes complement the coffee. Just screams "drink me." Well-balanced imperial with a smooth finish. Alcohol is very hidden. This bottle was about a year old and I enjoyed the freshness of the flavors.

Initial reaction: wow. Pours oily black with a tan head that will hang around for a bit if you can get it. The coffee is immediate, but silky chocolate is right behind it and lasts. The alcohol is surprisingly almost non-existant - at 12%, youd expect much more. This is a dangerous beer.

Bottle shared at CL Rosso release. Pours black with a foamy brown head. Very strong aroma with loads of coffee, espresso, and chocolate. Very smooth, full bodied, more coffee flavor along with some bitter chocolate and roasted malts. So much coffee. This was delicious.

750ml bottle.  Poured jet black and thick.  Aroma was licorice, coffee, roasty.  The taste is very big.  It made the Black Xantus that I drank this along with taste watery in comparison.  Strong notes of licorice and roasty sweetness.  The finish is balanced nicely with quite a bit of bitterness.  I think this could use a bit of cellaring to smooth out some of the boozyness but still a very good beer.
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2012 Huge huge huge beer. Big beer with some coffee added not really a coffee stout. Very rich and complex. Complexity gains as it warms.
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2011 75 cl bottle. caramel, coffee, licorice are the first impression when drinking this imperial stout. Nice body, very alcoholic, but its worth!

Tap at OBriens (Night of a Million Zillion Speedways) during the second annual San Diego Beer Week in November 2010.  This was my second (annual) attempt to go to OBriens to get the Kopi Luwak Speedway.  And just as at the first attempt at the first SDBW in November 2009, I went to OBriens and the line was way out the door.  So I went to Downtown Johnny Browns instead and returned to OBriens on my way home.  Fortunately, there was no line and I got to enjoy several of the rare Speedways that were left (but the Kopi Luwak was finished, of course).  ANYWAY, this pours the usual tarry thick black and has a nice head for a rather small sample.  Aroma is excellent fresh roasted earthy coffee with nuts.  Flavor is sharp roasted coffee, like just cracked open roasted coffee beans.  Also a nice nuttiness, some rich chocolate, and hints of bourbon.  The bittersweet coffee flavor is really standout here...probably my favorite of the five sample Speedways I tried this night.  (5, 568)Earlier Rating: 6/1/2009 Total Score: 4.4Have had this many times in San Diego.  This rating based on a growler fill from brewery.  Pours a thick black tar with no light penetration and a small brown head.  Aroma of roasted coffee and toasty chocolate malt.  Tastes of (quality) coffee and smooth chocolate.  Nice mellow sweetness (hints of chocolate-covered cherries) and theres also a slight note of sourness in the taste.  Full bodied with a lingering coffee taste.  The magnitude of the ABV is almost completely hidden, so need to be careful.  But got the rest of the growler left and its oh so good...

Not nearly as fresh as I last had it. Coffee flavors have dropped off. Damned Grey Market. 

Well hidden ABV and still even a bit muted one of the best Stouts I have encountered. Not sold on the cellaring prospects of this as the coffee is the best part of this.

750ml bottle. Dark brown with a brown head. Coffee, chocolate, malts, some caramel and a roasted aroma; very smooth, velvet, starts slightly sweet but then the hops and coffee bitterness kick - delicious taste, finish keeps on going with a bit of booze and great balanced bitterness. Great beer.

On tap @ Stone.  This is a very good stout.  Pours thick with a one and a half finger dark tan head.  Smell is coffee-chocolate, hint of grassy spice.  Taste is malt-heavy.  Drinks thick, heavy on the senses.  Lots of body, umami throughout.  As it warms, flavors become more rich and play together better and better.  The last half of the glass went down very easy.

Thanks to the efforts of Adam at Platinum Cellars we are now able to experience some of the delightful beers that we could only dream of. Cost is irrelevant even though there is a serious kick to the kredit kard every time I visit. I enjoyed this with Dave and Steve, my two mates who now bow their heads and admit tht they too, are beer nerds. This was our last beer of the night where there were many great beers supped before this. But still a beautiful beer. Great coffee aromas with roasted malt and caramel. Thick as a triple espresso with a similarly coloured crema. A delighful blend of coffee flavours and well hopped bittereness being supported by a great malt roastiness. A fantastic nightcap.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: 750ml bottle split graciously (on my part) with mcberko. Pungent aromas of dark coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruits. Flavour is dominated with coffee and a boozy quality. A beautiful Imperial Stout. Very satisfying and enjoyable. Very complex layers of flavour. Amazing.

On tap at Churchills and tons of other places in Southern Cali, pour is midnight black with creamy small brown head. Very impressive lacing that is extremely random. Aromas are amazing graham crackers, nesquick, cinnamon, marshmallow. Taste is tons of fruity hops, dark fruit, coffee, bitter chocolate, vanilla, caramel. Finishes nice and warming. Delicious sugary Russian imperial stout.

Ive had this several times, but just now got around to reviewing it. This latest bottle courtesy of TexIndy, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a solid black with a good sized creamy tan head that has some staying power. Nostrils are filled with scents of coffee in the foreground, with wisps of brown sugar, dark fruits, and caramel. My pallet is filled with tastes of milk chocolate, cherries, other dark fruits, lots of coffee and a touch of alcohol. Mouthfeel is creamy/slightly acridic, carbonation is medium, body is full. Great stout! I dont seem as blown away by this as I have been in the past. Recipe change? My perception? Id still happily drink it.

Bottle, 11C. Black with a fading tan head. Aroma of coffee, singed toffee, alcohol, vanilla, grass. Slippery mouthfeel. Taste has coffee, toffee, a moderate amount of heavy roast malt, some hop bitterness along with the coffee and roast at the end. Hides the alcohol pretty well - alarmingly drinkable. Complex, but all the complexity works as aspects of the main flavours. Coffee flavours are good but not that flash. Really good balance - theres lots of sweetness but its very well held in check; big flavours are well-integrated and dont crowd each other. Great beer.

Aroma is full of coffee, cocoa, roast malts, dark and milk chocolate, caramel, dark sugars, and ripe dark fruits.  Very enticing aroma, and no real perceptible booze in the nose.  Pours an oily pitch black, thick and syrupy, minimal tan head which has poor retention, slight spotty lacing.  Huge and complex flavor; coffee and chocolate come in strong, substantial roast character, sweet caramel malt profile, toffee, dark sugar, mid-range bitterness and a bit of hop flavor.  There is definitely some booze in the flavor, and its slightly hot in the finish, but much less so that would be expected for a 12% abv beer.  Full body, chewy and syrupy palate, carbonation is fairly low.  Nice stout, very complex and interesting while hiding the alcohol enough to enjoy a glass full.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2011 Fairly fresh bottle, less than 2 months.  Agressive pour into snifter.  Big 3 finger head, wasnt expecting that with such high ABV.  Taste is typical imperial stout (think founders Imp Stout) with decent amount of coffee.  This was a huge let down for being so high on the top 50 beers, I was expecting a lot more.  Pretty good though.

plastic cup taster at alesmith.  Dark brown coffee looking head.  Very dark brown look not quite black.  Lots of chocolate and roasty dark sweet malts on smell.  Smooth chocolate and dark malts and lots of coffee on taste.  A bit of alc on taste but small for how much is in it.  A bit of citrus and grapefruit but not too bitter.  A bit of a light sour aftertaste that is alright.  Pretty good lacing for a taster.  overall 8 of 10.

Pours a black color with mocha head and average lacing.   Aromas of dark  chocolate, caramels, and coffee with notes of berry or cherry and licorice.   Sweet taste at first but bitterness at the end.   A full bodied beer with a thick palate, flat carbonation.  Finish is dry and  bitter.  Overall, a nice brew with the alcohol nicely hidden, and great flavor.

Bottle from liqourama.net. This beer pours black with no head.  The aromas are roasted coffee, chocolate.  The mouthfeel is bitter, roasty, silky smooth with a heavy oily like body.  Thus was a phenomenal beer.  Really liked it!  Cheers!

UPDATED: APR 18, 2012 Opened on April 18, 2011. The last day of classes for the year.

Black, with a large four finger tan head. Recedes to a finger of froth. Thick lacing.

Edit: PZ sent me a replacement bottle, which was very in line with my expectations.  A great, creamy coffee stout.

Bottle thanks to MesandSim. A real treat, thank you. Poured black as night with a lovely thick rocky tan head. Massive lovely coffee aroma with lots of chocolate malt without being overly chocolatey. Coffee, dark chocolate some smoked and roasted notes. Alcohol is perfectly hidden and just adds to the pleasure that this was to drink.
Bottle. Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is coffee, toffee, licorice, and chocolate. Flavor is coffee, ash, toffee, chocolate. Full body and super silky, nice heat as well. Amazing beer.

Bottle. Pours with a bubbly tan head that takes a vigorous pour; completely black body, and very thick and dense.  Lots of coffee and smoky roast in the aroma, faint whiff of booze, dark very bitter chocolate.  Flavor is very roasty, and almost catch some earthy notes, bit of soy sauce, mineral, bitter dark chocolate, and of course dark coffee.  Body is very thick, subtler carbonation.  Almost velvety in texture.  Just great stuff, and always delivers for me.
Bottle shared at Flossmore pre party. Thanks to the guys for the share. Poured dark black with little head. Not exactly full of flavour as I expected but still very good.
Bottle @ BrewDog Bar, Edinburgh. Hoppy chocolate aroma. Almost black colour, no head. Strong hoppy chocolate flavour. Smooth with sweet aftertaste. Sorry it doesnt do it for me.
Bottle shared at Mikkeller Bar.  A good beer but not as great as I would have expected.  A little lacking in rich flavors I would expect from the style.

Surprised by the taste of this one. I was really expecting more of a bam and in your face kind of beer. I found it quite weak in flavour. It was good but not my favorite stout I have had. It gives off a nice roasty coffee and coco aroma, Taste is consistent. Interested in having again. thanks for sharing

Black pour. Big tan head that leaves plenty of lacing as it slowly falls down. Not much of a coffee aroma. More of a malty alcohol scent. But that is beautifully melded with chocolate and roasted grains. Smooth velvety chocolate milky taste. Seriously this is so smooth it is sick. The alcohol is really only apparent in the nose. It is a well balanced beer. I dont get any coffee however, which is surprising. But I cant detract anything from this one for that. Awesome!

Complex aroma of burning malt and yeast, some minerals in taste and palate, all a Imperial Stout must be.

Alesmith just make good beers, this is it, just only perfect.

Ganska diskret doft, men en otrolig len och fyllig smak av kaffe, choklad, härliga rostade toner och lite lakrits.
Lång och god eftersmak.
plums, toffee, chocolate,coffee.  black with a nice cream head.  caramel, coffee, chocolate, dark fruits.  silky bold mouth feeling.

Bottle bought at Kihoskh, Copenhagen April 2011. The cost was 125 DKK, which is about 24 USD. 

Truly an excellent beer with lots of coffee and roasted malt in both the aroma and taste. Smooth mouth feel with a great body. Well widden alcohol but it gives a warming feeling. Im so glad that I finally got to drink this beer.

Pours a dark jet black with a lot of tan head. Retains head. Aroma is strong coffee, toffee, chocolate.roasty. strong coffee flavor. Roasted caramel. Toasted. Palate is good with a heavy mouthfeel. Overall a really excellent stout

Bottle from Phaleslu. Pours black with a medium sized creamy brown head that fades leaving all kinds of weird shapes on the side of the glass. Aroma of molasses, tobacco, woody earthiness, light soy, leather, not a ton of coffee but just a hint of roast bean, some vanilla. Taste is more roasty with some smoke, leather and light bitter ashy finish all with a thick creamy sweet body, oily texture, very soft carbonation. The alcohol is barely noticeable on the finish. This is a damn good beer, Im glad I got to try it. Thanks again Peter!!! I need another one of these for breakfast tomorrow.
Bomber.  Pours black with thin tan head.  Aroma is roasty chocolate.  Flavor is dark chocolate and coffee with a fair deal of roastiness.  Very good stout.

Black.  Weird head.  Lots of big bubbles rather than the usual foamy head.

Smells like dark roast coffee, black licorice, and overripe dark berries.

Taste is a little disappointing.  A lot of coffee and thin.  As it warms, the licorice and fruit come through more.  But something seems off.  Just not quite balanced right and too much alcohol without the body to support it.  Still good and enjoyable but its good parts dont add up to be the greatness it could be.
UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 75cl, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex Stout, heavily roasted, yet balanced, hazy, small head, very good brew, yet expensive!
750ml, thanks Coleman! Roasty, very dry. Not a dominate off flavor. Combination of coffee, cocoa, and brown sugar. Delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2013 75cl bottle shared with friends at ABCBeers, the Hague.
Nice dark colour.  Not much head.  A lovely brew

There are so many imperial stouts out there now that generate buzz within the craft beer enthusiasts community its sometimes hard to tell which is which. More often than not, I find these beers to be good or very good instead of excellent or outstanding as their reputations would have me believe. Thats the case with AleSmith Speedway Stout - a very good imperial stout for all the right reasons. But nothing about it makes me consider it among the craft beer elite.I split a 750ml bottle with a friend. Sent to me from StumpyJoeJr in San Diego (Thanks, Ryan!)Appearance: Pitch black, no red or brown around the edges. Poured into a tulip glass I get a tiny bit of head, but it doesnt last. Some spotting lacing. Beer appears very thick in the pour alone.Smell: Not nearly as potent as youd expect. It smells like a standard American imperial stout with noticeable roasted coffee and red wine-like aroma. Perhaps a touch of chocolate. Next to no sheer booze smell, though.Taste: The first few sips are really amazing. Its coffee from start to finish with a touch of bakers chocolate in the aftertaste. Quite roasty as well, giving it a dry, bitter flavor. Bitterness lingers, but only for a short time which makes it not cloying. I was expecting more chocolate, though, as its more of an afterthought (than again, this isnt a chocolate stout). Pretty tasty overall, but not quite as robust as Id prefer. Vinous quality is perhaps a little distracting, but easily tolerable.Mouthfeel: While this beer looked like motor oil in the pour, it was much thinner in the mouth. It didnt quite coat the mouth the way many imperial stouts of the caliber tend to do. Drinkability: Alcohol is virtually non-existent in the taste and feel. I can take big swigs at first, but it eventually becomes a total sipper with an intense, dry, bitter mouthfeel. Ive had other imperial stouts that were more drinker-friendly than this, but Id say this one is still pretty drinkable for a 12% ABV beer.Overall, another great imperial stout, but not one I would consider among the best of the best. Id of course love to try a vintage with a few years on it as I think it would definitely improve with age.NOTE: watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rEbRwfYGtw8

Purchased about 1 month ago; no bottle date.

Slowly develops a 1-finger dark tan head after pouring.  The beer is a very dark brown, near black.

The aroma has some roasty coffee notes, but also a medicinal note and some green wood.  Its not particular appealing, but not off-putting either.

The first sip is an explosion of coffee and chocolate.  Unfortunately, its chased by that same green, medicinal flavor and a bitter woody finish.  The mouthfeel is heavy and coating, but a bit chalky.  Almost no carbonation.

Overall, this is a bit of an enigma to me, though.  Its better than the sum of its parts and I keep being pulled back for another sip.
Found this is a small shop in Ohio. Glad I bought it. An excellent stout. One of my favorites. Great balance, character, and taste. Yum, Yum

750 ml Bottle. Pours into the glass black as tar with dense chocolate malt head. The aroma is mostly dark roast coffee and chocolate mocha along with roasted malt, vanilla and bourbon. The flavor starts with a jolt of espresso roast coffee and dark chocolate followed by molasses, roast malt, caramel and a subtle alcohol presence in the background that balances it all out. The mouthfeel is slightly syrupy and creamy with soft carbonation and a dry, roasty finish. Theres also a pleasantly mild coffee with a shot of whiskey aftertaste. This is a massive Imperial Stout with just the right balance between the coffee, chocolate and malt flavors.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2011 Bottled. Pours black with an avarage, tan and lacing head. Nose of coffee and roasted malt. Medium sweet flavour with roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and caramel. Flat carbonation. Creamy - oily texture. Full bodied. Ends up more dry and with alcohol notes. A very enjoyable brew.

I drank this from the bottle into a chalice while doing a tasting with dark lord, peche mortel, old rasputin 12, and dfh world wide stout. This one finished in the middle of this group overall. Ok, overall but wouldnt crush it all day or probably get it again. 

It pours very very dark black, no light through at all, dark tan head. Good lacing and lots of carbonation. 

Aroma is very strong of alcohol and burnt wood. 

Taste is light, especially compared to how strong the aroma is. Doesnt really taste like much but coffee, but its light coffee, nothing really sticks out. Mouthfel is bad, almost a watery stout.

75cl bottle courtesy of a fellow beergeek. Pitch black colour. Sharp aroma and laden with notes of alcohol, liqorice and coffee. Some roasted malts. Flavour is laden with coffee, malts and hints of smoke. Also notes of alcohol and liqorice. Medium long aftertaste. Maybe Im a heretic, but this is not the greatest imperial stout Ive tried.

750 ml This is my celebratory beer for being lucky and getting 2011 DLD Tickets! Pours jet black and chunky with a thin brown head that  turns to a ring in my glass. Coffee, molasses big roasted aromas and alcohol. Awesome roasted dark coffee and chocolate. This monster fills my mouth with gladness and coats my tongue with its thick oily mouthfeel. The finish is smooth but long and enjoyable the alcohol is well balanced and doesnt over power any of the coffee or chocolate notes. This beer is everything its hyped up to be. Cant wait until DLD!
Black beauty with tan head.  Coffee nose, coffee and cocoa flavor.  Sweet and roasty.  Yeah, this is super good, top notch Imp Stout.

Bottle. Pours black. Thick brown head. Nose of rich chocolate malt, coffee roast, light peat and vanilla. Taste is rich coffee, burnt chocolate malt, warming alcohol, bourbon soaked cherries and vanilla.

Absolutely amazing. Dark chocolate melted with roasted barley and a shot of espresso. So perfect. The nose is lacking for sure...but I let it w arm up slightly and it was good. 72% dark chocolate. Coffee. Epic brew. This was so. Balanced so smooth...with a slight bitter end. Incredible. Poured dark with a quickly fading head. So awesome.

This is one hell of a stout! One hell of a beer! The only drawback is that the nose doesnt really hit you. The appearance is thick and black with a tan/ brown thin head. Taste is roast malt, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, more roasty burnt, bitterness. Palate is Thick and chewy like I think a good stout should be.
Overall  I am more than a little pissed off that this is above my price range. I could drink one of these every night.

Black with a light brown head. Aroma is hard roasted malt, coffee, light burnt, vanilla and alcohol. Flavor is rather sweet and rather bitter. Dry and bitter finish with warming alcohol. Full bodied and smooth. Brilliant. 181010

11/03/2010- Shared a bottle of this with a few friends; drank in a snifter. Pours pitch black with a thick, rich brown head. Heavy lacing around the glass. My sense of smell is overloaded just sniffing this!! HUGE complex aroma of coffee, earthy cocoa, rich molasses, roasted malts, and more coffee! I love a beer that tastes even better than it smells, and this certainly does! Flavors of dark chocolate and roasted coffee on the forefront, followed by smooth malt characters, vanilla, and even more rich coffee flavors. Ive had coffee stouts before, and the coffee sometimes tastes artificial. This tastes like high quality, fresh coffee, but its not so over-powering that it covers up the heavy chocolate malt characters. Ive never tasted such a well-balanced coffee stout. Mouthfeel is thick, yet smooth. I could drink this all day, which at 12% ABV is not a good thing... or maybe it is? Either way, this is a beer that will broaden your horizons and change your concepts of what beer should be. And I thought I knew what an imperial stout was before this...

Dark brown pour, brown head which increased briefly after I finished pouring.  It mostly dissipated but some lingered.  Aroma of dark chocolate with a hint of sweetness, maybe plum or similar.  Taste is very good dark chocolate with a hint of coffee and still hinting at sweetness without being sweet.  I love it.

bottle from de molen beershop.had high expectations based on the ranking. Smell is coffee,malts and dark chocolate. Taste is coffee, but with an unpleasant and unbalanced bitter finish, like two day old coffee. Mouthfeel was thin. I am disappointed about this beer, not bad, but many many many better ones in the style.how can this one be higher ranked than regular stormakts....

Tasted on 2/20/11 from a 750mL bottle purchased at Sun Devil, I bought this in early 2009, so I think this is probably from the 2008 bottling.  Pours deep, oil black with an average tan head that takes some time to cascade and form, and slowly recedes to fairly thick and even lace.  The overwhelming aroma on the nose is the dark malt with some nuttiness, caramel, milk chocolate, and the coffee has faded significantly, but is still present.  The flavor is sweet up front with tons of caramel and some dried fruit, moving to even more malt with some roast, and once again, lightly bitter coffee.  The body is full and sticky with light carbonation and a super long finish that is just as complex as all of the previously mentioned flavors.

Smuggled back to Australia in a suitcase. Pours black, no head to speak off. Really big, smooth, chocolate and coffee. The alcohol stays back and only shows up as a warming afterglow. This was a real treat, I wish we could get these as legal imports in Oz.

Huge imperial stout with coffee and roasted malts dominating. Dry bitter finish. A little overated I think but this style is so saturated with tremendous beers that this really doesnt stand out. A must try though.

Sampled at Tasting Panel #1. 750ml bottle. Pours black with a thick rocky tan head. Aroma is potent coffee and chocolate. Flavour is magnificent, huge chocolate and coffee notes combined with well worked alcohol. Decent finish. Hard to say this is anything less than great but somehow it fell slightly short of my MASSIVE expectations.

Bottle. Pours black with big brown head. Aroma is  a lot of coffee followed up with chocolate and roasted malts. The coffee falls second to the chocolate when it comes to taste and caramel notes are added to the mix. This is a full bodied, creamy beer with a bitter finish. It hides the fact that it is 12% very well. I would love to have a vertical of this stuff to see how it evolves with age.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2011 750 ml bottle poured into a tulip glass. If you like stouts, this is your beer. Pours pitch black motor oil. Very little carbonation. Im not a fan, but I can see why this beer is so highly rated.

Wow...The coffee and dark chocolate combine to make this beer more of a dessert than anything ive tasted. I would pair this perhaps with a eclaire with strawberries and some thick heavy whipped cream on top. The aroma is thick and full of coffee and dark chocolate. The appearance is oily and black. It pours fairly thick. The taste is very special. I thought it would be too much due to the thickness, however; it is surprisingly well balanced. This is better than north coast old rasputin for sure. I dont know what else to compare it to because I havent had dark lord or anything like that

What a nice stout. 22oz Bomber that pours a pitch black with a nice tan head that fades out slowly. Aroma of roasted malts with big coffee notes. Deep flavors of chocolate, toffee, caramel, coffee and wood. Nice finish, full bodied with a rich roasted malt finish. One of my favorites..

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Edit: Tasted this again from bottle. This is an amazing Imperial Stout. A benchmark stout.   

Tasted @ Fathers Office in may 2010. Pours dark black with minimal head. Tastes of coffee, toffee, chocolate and roasted malts. A velvety mouth feel and a clean aftertaste. The alcohol is very well masked but peeks out in the end.
One of my favorite stouts, and, honestly, how could it get much better than this warm, complex, coffee-tinged brew? Pick this up every time were in SD.

Pours a one finger dark brown head, body is pitch black with no light penetrating. Head retention is good and lacing is above average.

Smell is of roasted espresso beans and smoky burnt malts. Sweet chocolate syrup is also in there mixed with alcohol. Thats pretty much what dominates the aroma completely. 

Taste is heavy on roasted coffee beans and burnt malts. There is also an aftertaste of bitter coffee grounds, its almost like sipping on a double shot of espresso. Hops could also add to that bitterness Im tasting. Alcohol is definitely present at 12% but not overpowering.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, nice and syrupy. Carbonation levels are good, well carbonated for such a big, strong beer. Head contributed some creaminess to the body, just not enough to give it a 5

Drinkability is very good. Would have given it a 5 but at 12 percent, it packs a punch. I love Coffee Stouts and it definitely delivers tons of coffee flavor. Drank the whole 750 ml bottle and could have had another but with the alcohol content it would have knocked me on my ass.

Got this on sale at AJs for $6.99!  Dark and deep color, with a thin beige foam layer.  Smells of coffee, alcohol, caramel, and slightly burnt grain.  Slightly undercarbonated, but appropriate for the style.  Mouthfeel is thick, silky, and luxurious, with several layers of flavor that continue as you drink.  Notes of coffee, burnt nuts, toffee/brown sugar, and a slightly fruity/alcohol finish.  Very complex and layered, a great imperial stout for sipping... or chugging!

This beer sets the bar for all stouts in my mind.  It is special and gets better everytime i drink it.  If you have had it only once drink it again and i guarantee you will have a new experience with it.

Smell is coffee and chocolate with undertones of caramel and vanilla. It smells so good it is hard to wait for it to warm to the drinking temp.  It pours black as a can be and looks extremely viscous and full bodied.  perfect head every time.

Taste is second to none for a year round release.  Coffee, dark chocolate, toasted malts, caramel, with a little bitter taste to it at the end.  A little warmth is present due to its 12% abv and I love it.  Cant say enough.

Overall i use this beer to compare not only stouts but all beers. the quality is outstanding and is consistent year round.  Hands down top 5 year round release for me.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2017 75 cl bottle thanks to sebletitje!On Feb 1, 2011Black color, light brown head. Sweet, malty, chocolate, wheat bread, alcohol, fruity scent. Sweet, fruity, vinous, alcohol, coffee taste. Coffee aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.7/4/7/4/15=3.7RerateBottle at 3 Små Rum, Göteborg. On April 9, 2011Black color, brown head. Chocolate, malty, alcohol scent. Chocolate, coffee, malty, semi-sweet taste. Sort of dry and mineral aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.8/4/7/4/16=3.9RerateBottle at NK Bar, Stockholm, on December 9, 2013.Clear dark red to black color, brown head. Sweet, grainy, malty scent. Sweet, grainy, smoke, alcohol taste. Alcohol aftertaste. Warming alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.8/4/8/5/17=4.2RerateDraught at 3 små rum, Göteborg - Sweden, on April 13, 2017.Black color, dark brown head, some lacing. Malty sweet, coffee, chocolate scent, wonderful! Malty, sweet, hints of raisin, tobacco, chocolate taste, some alcohol. Grainy, sweet aftertaste. Medium full , a bit too much CO2, mouthfeel. Medium bitterness, to the dry side.10/4/9/4/18=4.5
Amazing pour, fantastic appearance, even better taste. A sought after treasure on the  East Coast..

Pours jet black, with no twinges of any other color at all, and with a beautiful caramel/tan head that is ample, foamy, and lacy to another level. Leaves rings of lace that never go away, and a thin cap of fluid foamy head remains on top to the end of the glass. Looks like a cappuccino. Aroma strongly of coffee, dark chocolate, and raw coffee beans, with a tiny bit of booze in the back. Roasted malts are in there too, and the toastiness is inviting. The taste then proceeds to blow everything else out of the water...wow. First sip literally feels like I am sucking on coffee bean. This is an unbelievable mix of coffee with chocolate tones and a smoothness that is all its own. Alcohol is undetectable, and malty sweetness is just about the amount I like to put in my regular coffee - just enough to keep the bitter coffee from being unpleasant. Roasted coffee beans from start to finish make this guy smooth as hell, and the texture of the beer is velvety, with a thick syrupy body that lends itself well to its taste. In terms of drinkability, this one hides its abv better than any other beer Ive ever had, and that is no exaggeration. If you see this beer BUY IT.

Bottle thanks DalzAle. Pour is oily black with a big tan head that fades. Aroma is very roasty and malty with a great coco coffee scent. Taste is sticky and smooth chocolate that feels creamy and a great coffee taste as well really nice. There is some bitter dark fruit too. Palate is full and creamy that has a gentle carbonation and finishes chaulky. This is awesome, and really want more!

Bottle courtesy of JSPrime. Pours black as night nice brown head. Aroma of front terrific black coffee, espresso, chocolate, vanilla and roasty malt. Mouthfeel was rich creamy full body with great lingering coffee bitterness. Big intense coffee taste was the forerunner in this big beer with side notes of vanilla caramel dried fruits espresso and malt. Excellent brew A+

750ml bottle, courtesy of Daknole (Thanks!!  :)), served in a tulip.  Pour is a moonless midnight with two fingers of large bubbled dark beige head.  Nose is big coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, plums, basement, and just a touch of caramel.  Taste is acetic coffee and dark chocolate up front.  As this recedes a touch, the roasted malt and fruit seep in to comprise the finish.  The acetic flavor is quite high in this, almost to the point of vinegar, but it doesnt ruin the beer.  It has a wonderfully smooth body, but the acetic tone disrupts it a bit.  I am not sure if it is the coffee, or perhaps slightly contaminated, but it is still very good.  Without that, I would probably have rated this around a 4.4!

Poured into a pint glass.

4.5 A: Black as night color. Two fingers of thick creamy light brown head with good retention and plenty of lacing.

5.0 S: Wow. This is a great smelling brew. At first, it smells like a thick chocolate milkshake. Sweet milk chocolate, lightly roasted coffee, roasted barley, dark chocolate, and a touch of bourbon. Awesome, truly.

4.5 T: Thick and sweet, but balanced nicely with bitterness from the hops and coffee. More bitter than I would have expected. Flavor profile consists of dark chocolate, espresso, molasses, heavily roasted malt. Alcohol is apparent and some fusels. Burnt flavors and coffee in aftertaste.

4.0 M: Heavy body. Thick and creamy and smooth. Could use a bit more carbonation though.

4.5 D: This beer lives up to expectations. Well done and glad I have another 13.4 oz.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-10-2009 04:15:17

Bomber from ck1 on his Phoenix trip - thanks bro - shared with my other bro.  Pours a quite dark black with a lighter colored brownish tan head.  Aroma is cherries, cocoa and coffee.  Taste is very smooth chocolate, fruit, and coffee beans.  Finishes a bit dry.  I was amazed it was 12% apv, the alcohol is well hidden within the great flavor.
29th March 2008  Rich smoothy creamy stout. Offset by a distinct bitter coffee finish. Initially hard work but it grows and grows as it warms up. Pleasantly bitter finish.

Like most of the reviewers said, "Coffee." This beer is extremely dark and opaque with an amber head on the glass. The aroma of coffee erupts from the glass with some other toasted fruits and caramels. Even with the high alcohol content the beer is very smooth and has a syrup quality.The taste of coffee continues to be very noticeable and could easily sway any hardcore Starbucks customer to this beer. It has lacing that sticks to the side of the glass with an extremely long finish.

One of the best stouts Ive tried.  Prefer this over the barrel aged version.  Everything an Imperial Stout should be.  Amazing texture with a velvet and rich mouthfeel, flavor is heavy coffee, bakers chocolate, roasted malts, brown sugar, some vanilla.  Excellent.

Bottle; Pour is a dark brown/black with a khaki tan head. Average head, light lacing - Amazing coffee aromas on the nose with cocoa and dark chocolates as well. Flavor profile is sweet, roasted coffee beans, espresso, toffee, cocoa, caramel , and Ill admit its on the simple side but WOW this is so palatable. Sweet, very slightly bitter, and more importantly; just amazing .

2009 vintage...

Typical dark brown/black appearance.  Very little head with minimal lacing left behind.  

Aroma is (surprisingly, and somewhat disappointingly) pretty standard - roasty malts, little bit of coffee.  Flavor is a bit more interesting, but still underwhelming - I was expecting more.  Not bad by any means, but just sort of a standard flavor profile in my opinion.

Mouthfeel was a bit thin but this is a very drinkable beer and something I would try again - perhaps it improves with more age on it...

Pours a rich black/brown with a creamy tan head that lingers and laces quite a lot. Aroma of coffee and malt; this bottle had a touch of hotness on the nose, but nothing offputting. Tastes of espresso, dark chocolate with touch of bitterness and a slightly dry finish. Excellent imperial stout.

750-ml bottle. Rich, creamy brown head, small bubbles, coats side of glass almost like egg nog. I drink it on the warm side of the recommended 50-55, which causes some panic at first, then it becomes clear its perfect.

Smell of fresh, sour coffee, some citrus peel, bourbony vanilla. Sure, some dark chocolate, but skews toward coffee. Vegetal, bit of cigarette ash. If you like big beers and coffee stouts, this is as good as it gets. Exceptionally smooth - indeed, velvety, as advertised. Alcohol very present in the aroma, but not as much in the taste. Got to carve out a responsibility-free evening to enjoy this one, but its a pleasure when you can do it.

Coffee, right away smells good coffee, with chocolates, vanilla, toasty, roasty, smells great! Black, black and black. With minimal brownish head. Lacing is present too. So much going on with this beer. So smooth, compared to some other imperial stouts ive tasted before. Coffee, dark chocolate flavors, with some other flavors in it like hints of vanilla, and a little sweetness to it. I dont mind the bitterness because it is very appropriate for this kind of beer. Full bodied, very slick and smooth and clean, especially at the finish. This is a very enjoyable beer, great beer! Cant wait for the next one!

Bottle, shared with Parksy on New Years Eve-- the fourth in a line-up of imperials. This one was brought back from Oregon earlier this year.
Thick near-black pour, red-brown head that forms slowly, like a prairie thunderhead. Aroma is full-on rich espresso bean and chocolate, very appetizing. Rich, full-bodied palate, hugely flavourful, packed with fresh espresso grind, bitter bakers chocolate, fudge, nuances of leather and wood. Balanced bittter finish. Outstanding! Certainly worthy of its status.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Jet black pour, small tan head with little lacing. It smells of chocolate and coffee.  Tastes of chocolate, malt and hint of coffee.  Absolutely delicious, great beer

Extremely impressed with this stout. Dark pour with a light brown head. Coffee bean in the nose with hints of dark chocolate and malts. Very smooth and not a very heavy mouth feel. Malty flavor with coffee bean and chocolate. One outstanding stout.

My favorite stout, hands-down. 

Huge marshmallowy notes and full roasty chocolate flavors make this a very easy bottle to keep to yourself. 

<3

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2012 Bottle. Pours a pitch black color as dark as night with a very creamy tan head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, slight amount of dark fruit and some sweet malty notes. Flavor is very complex with alot of chocolate and coffee, along with roasted malt, cocoa beans, the dark fruit and some sweet sugary taste. The flavors are very well balanced. The body is full with a very creamy mouthfeel. Overall this is one of the best Imperial Stouts i have ever had!

Bottle from 08. Pours big black and dark with a thin beige head. Nose is dominated by coffee but also has big roasted malts. Big bitter front the coffee and the booze dominate. Its a big coffee infused stout. Nice solid roasted malts all ending with a big bitter finish.

I must commend myself on selecting this beer both as a morning beer and as the first beer of Christmas 2010. Aroma is of strong coffee and chocolate. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with less than a finger of brown head. Taste follows aroma, but DAMN is this tasty even after a number of other coffee stouts; AleSmith has got the flavor balance (and quality) just right. Mouthfeel is outstanding; thick, creamy body with soft carbonation... I could drink this all day.

finally found a bottle of this that I didnt think was horribly overpriced. Dark black pour and tan/brown head. Lovely roast, molasses, brown sugar, sticky candy. Earthy, with some pine, most of the dimension seems to come from the vanilla-alcohol. Creamy smooth body. Very tasty, but disappointingly 1 dimensional.

I was lucky enough to find one last bottle sitting on the shelf, wow, the guy behind me sure looked disappointed when I got there first. Now I understand why. While I wanted to just sit and enjoy, I found it hard not to gulp it down like a big ol glass of Pepsi on a hot summer day. Flavorful, however, not too light, yet not too strong. Somehow you get the feeling this is the affect the creators of this masterpiece were going for. Ive never seen a beer foam quiet the way this does, when first poured I thought; where are the bubbles, then after it sat for a few seconds, appeared a nice head, not too overwhelming but just the perfect amount. If I were to craft a brew this would be just what I would hope to have as and end product.

Now as I sit here a watch The Grinch That Stole Christmas, I also find that it has that nice affect Gin has, putting that ear-to-ear smile on my face (Im sure its the coffee mixed with the alcohol). Just remember this isnt the cure for your problems just a cure for life. or as Homer would say; "Beer... Now theres a temporary solution." This should be on any Stout Lovers top ten list.
This is a masterpiece! I had the pleasure to drink it at 4:20 pb in bottle. The taste is unbelievable, aggressive and complex, the body is full: coffee and bitter!

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2011 On tap at the Alesmith tasting room.  Pours black with nice dark tan head.  Smells of coffee, chocolate and burnt sugar.  Flavor is all coffee.  Some vanilla in there.  Strong beer, some bitterness at the finish.

Bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma shows notes of chocolate, coffee, dark fruit and light roast.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of caramel and vanilla.  Major emphasis is definately coffee and chocolate though.  Overall body is full, viscous and finishes with a dark chocolate/roast bitterness.

Pours a dark brown/ black hue with a tan head. Aroma a little smoky with a hint of alcohol. Taste too me overated a little bit, good smokey flavor with a nice crisp dry  malty taste. For the price I paid, I think I rather have bought two more packs of Founders Breakfast Stout.

750ml bottle at Brewdog Aberdeen. Pours near black with decent tan head. Nose; freshly roasted coffee, bitter-sweet chocolate, dark fruits. Taste; rich and complex layers of coffee and cocoa, plums, some liquorice, well hidden alcohol, full bodied with a velvety mouthfeel. Special.

750ml bottle, unknown date.  Pours black with a good sized brown head that leaves nice clumpy rings of lacing and holds a small island and ring.  Incredible aroma of premium coffee, chocolate, more coffee, roasted malts, even more coffee, also some anise, dark fruits, and a bit of alcohol.  Great strength.  Flavor features rich coffee, great chocolate notes of dark chocolate, bakers chocolate and milk chocolate.  Roasted malts, anise, dark fruits round things out but the chocolate and coffee are the headliners.  Some alcohol kick, but not boozy or overpowering.  Some bitterness from the malt and coffee along with a touch of sweetness.  Long, lingering coffee & chocolate finish with a touch of heat from the alcohol.  Wonderful.  Mouthfeel is very rich, creamy and velvety, not the thickest Imperial Stout Ive had but still very full bodied, low carbonation.  Possibly the perfect mouthfeel for the style, thick, but not too thick, so creamy and smooth without over active carbonation getting in the way.Oh.  My.  God.  Every bit as good as I anticipated this magnificent brew to be.  Glad I went ahead and stocked up on six bottles with my one chance to procure this epic brew.  One of the best coffee/imperial stouts Ive ever had!  Amazing!

One more big imperial stout for the evening before i possibly walk in this blizzard.  Pour is black with a small tan head.  Slight coffee aroma, with some smokiness, and chocolate.  I liked the aroma, but the taste is quite a bit better.  The description is apt; this has a velvety smooth texture.  Mildly sweet taste with coffee and chocolate.  Nice sweet chocolate flavor linger.  This is making my possible 30 minute walk seem like it will be ok.
Bottle to snifter.  Pours black with a beautiful dark brown head, lots of lacing.  Nose of coffee, smoke, and chocolate.  Very drinkable, completely balanced with a slight chocolate finish.  Great.
Wow, fantastic stout.  One of the best I have ever had.  Tried a bottle of it from California.  Quite a lot of coffee, dark color and dark head.  Wonderful stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2010 Pours pitch black with a full brown head and full sheets of lacing.  The aroma is full of coffee, chocolate, molasses, and tobacco.  The bitter roasted coffee really comes through.  Wow...the flavor is incredible.  Full bodied beer with an oily mouthfeel.  Loads of chocolate and espresso come through real nice.  The middle of the palate picks up on some of that tobacco.  The finish is complex with sweet chocolate and bitter coffee.

Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Black with a brown creamy head. Vanilla, dark dried fruits (prune stands out) and chocolate on the nose. Roasted notes, sweet, bitter and alcoholic flavors. Full body. Oily texture with a dry finish full of roasted notes. Wonderful.

pours a black coffee color with a medium sized dense mocha colored head...nice retention and lacing!  aroma has notes of dark fruit, tobacco, smoke, coffee and chocolate.  flavor has more prominent coffee with notes of tobacco and chocolate.  moutfeel is thick and silky with a warming, lingering roasty coffee finish.  so glad this came into PA distribution...delectable!

Thanks to azbucfan for this one.

A: Near black with a smallish tan head and decent lacing. 

S: Lots of espresso mixed with very dark malt and some hints of dark chocolate.

T: Lots, and I mean lots, of roasted espresso flavors, creating a sensation of dark, tart cherries. This is paired with some mild dark chocolate as well as pale malt sweetness and a hint of bittering hops. 

M: Very smooth with a medium-full body and a good amount of carbonation.

D: This is definitely a sipper, but a good one at that. Like my morning espresso, only with a lot more complexity and definitive hints of alcohol. Very delicious.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-30-2009

Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is heavy on the coffee with a hint of vanilla. Very smooth going down. Flavor is a mixture of dark chocolate and coffee. The alcohol is hidden very well. Overall a very good stout.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2014 Rating # 2500. Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a huge creamy very dark brown head that produced great lacing. The aroma was strong cocoa, coffee, vanilla and toasty malts. The flavor is tangy and bitter with toasty malts, lots of coffee, dark chocolate and moderate floral and fruity hops. The finish is long and full of gritty espresso and bittersweet chocolate. Thick and full bodied. Excellent.

750ml bottle. Pours black with thin tan head. Thin wisps/streaks of lace. Aroma is very earthy with notes of coffee and molasses and hints of pepper and alcohol. Flavor starts roasty dry up front with a distinct tinge of deep dark chocolate and espresso. Dry finish with bitter cocoa and balancing earthy hops. Sweet and malty throughout but balanced and very dry in the end. Mouthfeel is brisk and dry with a light chalkiness and full body. Overall, very nice.

A bit disappointed, perhaps I need a rerate. Theres coffee there but not mindblowing amounts. Other flavours are all of a decent stout, a good stout even, but not great. Very easy to drink for its alcohol percentage.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de café avec une pointe de chocolat au lait et de vanille. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café avec une pointe de chocolat et de petits fruits. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #3358)

Exactly as advertised. Bomber pours thick, motor-oil black, with an extremely dark, small head. Nose is BIG coffee and chocolate, but deeper whiffs reveal some nice vanilla undertones, as well as dark berry notes. Taste is just out of this world; everythings incredibly up-front, but just evened out very skillfully. Clean finish. Very smooth. Glad I finally got to try this gem.

Aroma has some obvious coffee, but also strong milk chocolate notes. Bourbon balls, vanilla wafers and caramel yogurt as well. Appearance is black with tan head; great lacing on the glass as well. Flavor matches the nose with more coffee flavor apparent; the body is very creamy and somewhat oily. Palate is creamy. Certainly great stuff, but perhaps overrated.

On tap @ Obriens Night of a Million Zillion Speedways. All aspects of this one are very close to the regular version. I got a very light bourbon/oak aroma and flavor. The coffee seemed a bit stronger too, with an acidic edge to it. Another very good, amazing beer, the flavors just dont mesh together perfectly like the standard version. Glad I got to try this.Earlier Rating: 11/3/2010 Total Score: 4.4750ml bottle. Pours a thick, black with a huge tan head that simmers down to a long lasting, creamy cap. The aroma is lots of chocolate, coffee, vanilla and dark sweet caramel. The flavor is semi-sweet chocolate, acidic coffee, bitter roasted malt and a light alcohol presence. Full body with average Imp Stout carbonation and a thick, creamy mouth feel. This is one hell of a beer, the coffee and the base beer work perfectly together. If you want a big coffee beer, then it doesnt get much better than this.

Wow - lots of coffee and soy in the aroma, sweet and smooth. The stout pours jet black with an awesome toasty brown head exactly as they described. The velvety smooth mouthfeel is pleasantly combined with coffee and roasty malts in a perfect refined flavor.
Bottle from Voldby. Huge tan head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich coffee, roast malt, caramel,chocolate and hops. Nice and warming.

Holy smoke. What a beer. Pours dark as night with a foamy dark brown head. Aroma is hoppy, malty, fruit, chocolate and a bit of coffee. Taste is pretty similar with bitter hops, toasted malt, good amount of chocolate and a whole lot of coffee. Clean palate. This is a heck of a beer. Tastes much milder than its 12% alcohol.

1st rating of this brew, and first tick in a long time for me.  Tried this today at Obriens amidst a  sea of people and an unseasonably hot November evening.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nice distinct and different coffee nose.  The taste of this one certainly centers on the coffee, the bourbon is there, but less detectable.  Earlier Rating: 6/13/2008 Total Score: 4.41st rating, yipee, for this is some damn good beer.  Cask at VIP Session 11th Annual San Diego Real Ale Festival my first beer of the day.  Poured black with a 1 finger light brown head.  The nose is big and coffee is right there in the front of everything else and that coffee nose is huge.  Taste is sweet, with coffee and more common speedway characteristics, overall very impressed, and not surprised by its greatness.Earlier Rating: 7/31/2006 Total Score: 4.8Decided to put in a re-rate in the spirit of cracking open my first bottle of 2004 bottle aged Speedway.  Damn it was smooth and delicious.  Pours black almost soy sauce like as others might refer to it.  It has a bubbly almost non-head, there is something half there.  The aroma is divine, smokey, coffee, roasty and rich.  Id say it smells like heaven.  The taste is smooth rich and full of coffee, and chocolate.  YUM!


smells of coffee and malt.  Had my first bottle after priming myself with a bottle of Rogue Hazelnut Brown.  This beer is a behemoth, and I have to say it is fantastic.  The coffee comes through strong and it is as dark as motor oil.  The Alcohol is hidden like other Alesmith beers, watch out, that 12% will hit you like a ton of bricks.  Yummy, and warning do not drink on an empty stomach

Finally decided to rate this one after many tastings.  25.4, the 5th bottle of the night on the path to Darkness.  Whoops, should have had this one after!  Nearly forgot how big this beer was, so much chocolate and coffee with a finish that lingers.  Pours so dark, medium sweet chocolate in the nose with tons of fresh coffee.  Big powerful robust palate, almost a night finisher.  Was decided this one as the beer of the night.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Pours black as the night with a 2 inch nice looking creamy tanned head. Aroma of chocolate, leather,liquorice and coffee. Taste is sweet roasted malts, vanilla also very good hidden warming alcohol. Rich and nice beer

Oh my stars...opaque, as in black-as- night.  Syrupy coffee nose.  Strong coffee flavor and sweet sweet finish but terrific mid and back palate acid....just keeps on giving.   Booya!  Did I just say Booya?  Must be good...

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of toasted, light coffee and dark chocolate, moderate resin and earth for the hops and yeast, with background notes of prune, cream, dark spiced rum and tar on the last pour. Head is average size, rocky/bubbly/frothy, light brown with excellent lacing and good legs and is mostly lasting. Color is dark brown, almost black. Flavor starts moderately to heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then the long finish is moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is full, between creamy and syrupy, and has a carbonation that is between soft and lively, and finishes a bit sticky. Just about everything I expected. Definitely lives up to the hype.

Jaysus. This is a beer. No dickin around. Poured with a decent tan, foamy, frothy, thick head that lasts a while and good lace. Color is as black as my heart (black) and opaque. Aroma is massive dark, roasted malts and coffee. Body is velvet, full, round, a bit chewy with perfect carbonation. Finish is like flavor, relatively short and also benignly brief in alcohol evidence. Killer. Could be a session if you let it. Dangerously good.

Ive split a few bombers of this in recent weeks, just never got around to reviewing.  The stout to which I will forever compare all others.  Obvious aroma of chocolate and coffee, tastes like a mocha with bite.  Very warm in the mouth but smooth and very drinkable.  Im very grateful that AleSmith is in my backyard so I can grab this whenever I want.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Pours very dark brown with a huge light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, sweet and bitter chocolate. Taste is much like aroma with some caramel, toffee added. Coffee not as dominant as one might think from the descripsion. Alcohol is very well hidden, but gives a long lasting warming feeling. Full body with a creamy mouthfeel, long delightfull aftertaste with sweet chocolate and coffee. Great beer, but ill like to see it shipped in smaller bottles, this one is certanly to much for 1 person101023

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 2008 vintage pretty sure, they dont date their bottles so thats an educated guess. Beer is black and has no head but manages to leave some lacing on the glass somehow. Carbonation is moderate.

Aroma is a mixture of sweet and a slight sour lactic aroma. There is also some alcohol in the aroma but not much.

Beer is sweet up front, medium to low body. Finishes slightly dry, no carbonation in the mouth. Drinkability is high and mouthfeel is high. I really liked this beer. I wonder what the barrel aged version is like.

Serving type: bottle
Pours a black color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Sweet start with coffee spice.  Chocolate notes on the finish.  A nice big stout with some bold flavor.

Thanks to Chalsk.  Pours a deep dark black with creamy brown head.  Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate and caramel.  Taste is sweet with the bitterness of coffee coming through.  The alcohol is almost not noticeable.  Excellent stout.

bottle. speedway pours dark as night. small tan head. smells of coffee, dark fruit,coffee, vanilla. just a great stout from San Diego. taste so good. minimal alcohol for such a strong beer, very well hidden. do youself a favor and try it. Enjoy

Pours black with a very tall thick dark brown head. Aroma is very nice lots of roasted malt character to it. Flavour is amazing. Chocolate, roasted barley very thick and dark this is one hell of a stout. it has all the dark malty complexity that Im looking for in a stout. This is a great beer.
