Bottle thanks to polomagnifico. Black pour with a brown head. Nose is coffee, richness, slight vanilla as well as some hop aromas. Flavor is big coffee, nice hop bitterness, sweet malts and roasty. Finish has a nice bitterness balanced with some sweetness. Great beer.

Poured from the bottle into a stemmed glass.

The color is a dark black with about two to three fingers of head and a ton of lacing left on the glass.

The smell of this beer is pretty chocolaty and has some nice dark licorice tones that brings it into a great level of coffee flavored beers.

smell of chocolate. Although this is brewed with large amounts of coffee, the java smell is definitely secondary to the chocolate. Also a reasonable sniff of black licorice as well. So far so good!

The taste is really deep chocolate flavor with coffee flavor and has a nice dark licorice flavor. Some nice heat in the flavor that is really nice with a good kick.

The feel is a good hard stout with a burning flavor that goes into a good amount of even feel and it smooth once past the hard flavor of this beer.

I like this beer and want more of it before the next batch is brewed.

Bottle courtesy of hophead22. Ahh, does coffee, chocolate, and stout beer get any better. Coffee and raisin on the aroma, with just a hint of the large alcohol. Warmth of silken mocha coats the tongue with just a lovely flavor, with a nice lasting bitterness. Wonderful stout.

750ml bottle. Brewed with Ryan Bros. Coffee beans.  Black pour with small disappearing head.  Rich dark coffee roast with malt and mellow mouth feel.  A coffee imperial stout is what it is throughout.

1 oz sample at the GABF.  Got a refill too.  Very Nice!  Deep black color with small bubble carbonation and brown lacing head.  Strong coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, carmel, and a slight cream.  Smooth Slick and creamy texture with full body.  Nice warmth at the end.  Huge aroma of chocolate and coffee.  I wanna fill my cup with this at work and sip all day long!

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2016 Bottle, shared between good friends at Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Pours - as expected - a jet black body with a creamy, majestic caramel head. Nose is mainly coffee, hints of dark chocolate, heavily roasted malts and vague caramel/vanilla tones. Taste is an extremely well composed symbiosis of major coffee flavors, dark chocolate and roasted malts - the classic imperial stout components blended with exquisite craftsmanship. Smooth palate. While this is a rock solid beer, I still miss some of the original "cherry-on-top" elements that separates the awesome stouts from the epic, mind-blowing stouts. In my opinion, Speedway Stout merely reaches the former category, while it seems to be rated as the latter. Having said that, this is a stout that will make anybodys day, without a shadow of a doubt!

This may be my highest rating to date. This beer is simply amazing. Right from the perfect pour of jet black with a tan head to the wonderful fruity aroma. The taste does not disappoint and is quite different from the aroma. Malty sweetness with chocolate, coffee, oak, vanilla, wine like fruitiness, some smoke, on and on. It has a very smooth and light quality despite the huge kick making it very easy drinking. One of the best.

Bottle. Beautiful black pour with full and frothy tan head. Aroma is rich of chocolate syrup and roasted malt. Flavor is loaded with dark chocolate complemented by an awesome roasty, nuttiness and caramel. Silky and full body with potent roasted malt goodness. Im not getting coffee at all, surprisingly. Not the depth I was expecting, but its simplicity is still excellent.

750ml  $11.99
Lucent black, creamy-tan-head, full-body, light-co2.

Aroma: dark-malt alchl §silage §sweet-chclt.

Taste:
Sweet-roasty-malt T1.
Alchl silage-hop roasted-malt T2.
Slight woody §coffee T3.
Balanced, flavorful, second pint is better than the first, a good 1bottle session.
Not as good as Nogne O, (imo).
Black as the night. Strong coffee and dark chocolate aroma, mellowing as it warms up. This beer is thick like motor oil but its all smooth and delicious.
Excellent beer. One of my all-time favorite stouts! Appearance is great. Head retention was good. Lots of lacing. Aroma is amazing; coffee, caramel, toasty!

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Bomber consumed with Jeff. Jet black oil in the pour - rich dark brown head that stays. Coffee in the nose with slight hints of chocolate. On the tongue, major espresso flavors melt into bitter chocolate and leaves a lasting aftertaste. Amazing.

Deep black pour with a thick tan head.  When I first poured this, I was a bit too enthusiastic and the head spilled over somewhat violently, causing me to slurp it off the side of the glass.  The experience was not unlike a chocolate coffee mousse.  This has a big, rich aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate, and anise.  This is rich and creamy feeling in the mouth, with nice mildly acidic coffee and roast with milk chocolate tones.  More anise, tones of fig/dried dark fruits, caramel and toffee, some smokiness underlying everything.  Complex with no element dominating too much.  An alcohol warmth builds on the tongue after sipping, but theres no harsh burn.  This is a brew that can really revitalize my love of beer.

2008 bottle - The statement that this is a huge beer is understatement.  I would not be surprised if you would water this down 50% and have a totally decent normal stout.  The coffee is not as strong as I thought it would be...the flavors are dominated by the burnt grain.  The alcohol does come though and I expect more vanilla and tobacco which is replaced by the coffee...I have to find some fault with it.  I would argue for days that this is not the best beer I have ever had, which by its score on here it (or is close) but this is an amazing stout, worthy of a boring, lingering rating.

Had a bottle last week in California. Man, it was worth the wait. The bottle describes the appearance quite well--motor oil. This is thick and black, and even if you pour it lightly, a big, brown head will form. Taste-wise, this is Bourbon County Stouts evil twin. Where the BCS is all chocolate, this is pure, delicious coffee. As such, the flavors really open up as you let it warm up. Overall, right up there with the BCS as not only the best stouts that I have had, but among the best beers Ive had.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2012 400th rating, had to be something special, so I kept this bottle for some months away, and today at the start of my birthday (30 years, here it was 00u passed at the 26th) It was time to open this bottle and enjoy it together with my wife. Poured it at a "gulden draak" glass, so think that is ok. Thanx to NoiZe for sending this beer to me. Pours out like expected, black with a good head. The head is even very big, and sticks nice to the glass. Medium dark brown coloured, and holds pretty good. Smell is coffee, but with a bit of something unpleasant inside. Roastiness, coffee, some chocolate and hops, and something that goes slightly sour (not overwhelming, but its there slightly). Taste is roasted coffee, an oily body, but less then expected. Some weird, even a bit unpleasant "sourish"- berrys comes up, that changes to a bitter coffee-chocolate aftertaste. Lots of chocolate at the aftertaste also, maybe some nespresso? Its not completely the beer I hoped for, Ive tasted better imperial stouts for sure. In my opinion its overrated, but its still a very decent beer. But to buy it again... specially at this price... no... A bit of a disappointment. It gets a bit better while warming up, but still...  Edit: Need to re-taste one day, maybe my bottle was not 100% ok...

UPDATED: APR 2, 2012 Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on April 1st, 2012.
Appearance:Pours a dark black with light red head.
Aroma: Aroma is coffee and really roasty, some chocolate.
Taste: Some bitterness, coffee, roasty(like the nose), chocolate, faint caramel..
Palate:Medium body, slick.
Summary: First off, thanks Dave for sharing this. This is the second time Ive had it, and it was tasty once again.  Too bad we cant easily get this on the East Coast, as while its high in alcohol its not overbearing in boozyness, and is just quite tasty.

Old rating from 8/25/2010: I love when I can get my hands on some Alesmith over here in the East Coast.  Enjoy each and every one.  Adding notes from last few months, have not been able to comment perfectly on each beer. I blame the beer.

Wow this is a beer that deserves its 100 rating.  Started out good and got better as it warmed up.  Bottle pour gives almost black thick color with thin tan head but great lacing.  Aroma coffee and roast malts.  Flavor coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, a  touch of dark fruits.  Palate thick and smooth with slight stickiness. Finish initially a little bitter but as it warmed up was more brief with great fullness and roast aftertaste.  Alcohol moderately apparent.

Really good, would drink again any day.

This bottle might not get a fair shake, since it was sandwiched in between DBA Zhukov and 06 BA Speedway Stout.  Never the less, big big coffee flavors with a chocolate, vanilla, and roasted malt rounding out the band.  A very good stout, but hard to stand up to the to monsters it shared the day with..

Holy crap. 750 ml. 08.11.10
Pours deep brown (almost jet black) with a thick and frothy and sticky dark tan head. The legs in this beer is amazing as is the sticky lacing on the glass. The carbonation is PERFECT. Equally amazing like Boulevard Bourbon Barrel Quad. The nose is dark chocolate, roasted coffee, nutella, mild hops, roasted barley, licorice, and raisin. The taste is slightly bitter at first with dark chocolate, roasted malt, raisin, and amazing French coffee. This is followed by more chocolate, more malt, earthy hops, and licorice. The mouthfeel is velvety rich and creamy. This stout is absolutely incredible. I think I like it more than Deschutes Abyss, Mikkeler Black Hole, and Bottleworks XI. Goose Island BCS is better but not by much. Amazing beer.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2012 Thick black pour decent tan head aromas coffee to burn liccorice vanilla chocolate very smooth flavours a fizz and a sparkle of coffee grandeur with added ibu of good grade vanilla liccorice malty chocolate smoothness the palate is left with an aftertaste of coffee bean and bitter to last malt so smooth yes mr alesmith
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2011 Bottle. Thanks tarheels! Pours pitch black with a tan head. Big coffee, chocolate, tobacco, caramel.. very full bodied. Slightly boozy. Very good.

This is the type of stout that will make a stout lover squeal with delight  like a little girl at a Hannah Montana concert. The pour is a thick black consistent with overused motor oil. Regardless of how you pour this beer, you are going to get at least a medium sized, dark gray head. The head on this beer is so impressively dark and forceful in its presence. The aroma has a heavy coffee presence that is very apparent in the taste of the beer. The palate is a glorious combination of coffee and dark, dark chocolate. As you drink this extremely heavy beer, you realize that if you drink very much, you will not only be hammered, but extremely full as well. This is probably the most filling beer I have ever consumed.  The only thing left to say is thank you AleSmith for this magnificent brew.

Got to try this thanks to a trade with Snojerk321. 750 ml bottle poured into a snifter. Poured a dark brown to black with a one-finger black head that settled into a spotty large-bubbled coating. Lacing is pretty heavy and lasting. Nose is coffee, vanilla, roasted malt and bourbon. Taste is roasted coffee, chocolate and bourbon up front, with notes of vanilla and dark fruit. Finish is both dry and sweet. Mouthfeel is medium to thick, creamy with good carbonation. Not much that would give away the ABV. Its not difficult to understand why this is universally considered a great coffee stout and I would love another!

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2010 The best american brew I had, so far. Very smooth. Nice balance between coffee, chocolate and caramel. The alcool is hidden. Maybe too sweet to revolutionize the genre, but a very nice brew anyway

Bottle, Dont really remember who traded me this anymore, but who cares. Scrizzz or TheCheeseMan. 09 bottle I think. Atleast Ive had it since summer 09. Pours black obviously, with a thick brown milkshake looking bubbly head. Aroma is mellow when just poured. Milk chocolate, coffee, some slightly sour burnt notes. Some oxidation is starting to take effect. A touch of prunes. No detectable alcohol. So SO creamy in the mouth. On the wikipedia page for perfect_mouthfeel they should show a picture of this brew. No disambiguation. I wish I never gave any other brew a 5 for Palate before except perhaps DH1. Loads of sweetness here, but the coffee bitterness and burnt sourness balances it out well. Some liquorice. Just a hint of alcohol. Overall, this is very well crafted. Very balanced in every aspect. Theres really nothing missing, except for I guess a surprising twist in the aroma/flavour department. Something that would make this brew blow me away completely. Maybe Im asking too much from a beer. This is balance exemplified, and in a massive brew at that. Screw it, Im gonna give it less than a 5 and hope that some day, something will be like this, only with that wow-factor.

Bomber, Have had this a few times but never rated, figured it would be a good one for number one hundo, pours an inky black with some semblance of walnut only at the very edges of the glass, two finger peaty foamy head, aroma is a subtle but complex bouquet of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and light esters, flavor is roasted malt, milk chocolate, and some hop bitterness all enrobed in a delicious silken petina, finishes full but light, with no assaulting roasted or bitter flavors dominating the palate, I really think that is the greatness of this beer: the best flavors of an imperial stout without any of the palate-abrasive flavors that are typically unavoidable in the style, that and the fact that its perfectly balanced, truly a fantastic brew
75ck Bottle @Dahlberg Helsingborg. Pours Black with brown head. Coffee, Roasted malt, Dark chocolate, Licorice,  Great beer

750mL bottle.  Pours a pitch black with a very small dark head, leaving lacing on the glass.  Very strong coffee aroma.  Taste is coffee with a bit of chocolate and a very smooth finish.  Thick mouthfeel.  Very well balanced.  High energy.  A fantastic beer.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2013 750 bottle. Rich burnt aroma with cofee and chocolate. Intense burnt flavor, cofee, chocolate, cream, bread. Noticeable sour tinge with some fruit and soy sauce as well as some gumball. There is an intense burnt bitterness at the finish as well. Impressive. Enjoy it more every time I have it. Lots of umami as it warmed, with something steak-like as well. Deep rich chocolate, light coffee. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Im going to break away from my typical reviewing pattern and just go at... this dark blackbrown behemoth looks great... smells amazing, tastes phenomenal and feels like a champ.... this beer truly unlocked everything that an american imperial stout has to offer

the coffee beans lend its self to a rich, and delicate flavor full of everything dark and grand... chocolate, coffee, caramel, roasted malts, ... smooth like it should be this beer is a king... love it.

750ml bottle.  Almost black in color with a thick, light brown head.  Strong aroma and taste of chocolate and coffee.  A fantastic imperial stout by all means, but for the price, I would go with Stones version.

Nose is roasted coffee, milk/cream, chcoloate, not much alcohol, but more alcohol as it warms.  The appearance is true to style, an attractive deep black, light brown head.  The flavor is awesome, coffee, chocolate, sweet cream, fruit like plums.  Nice thick body, smooth, creamy mouthfeel.  The finish is roasty, moderate resiny hops, leaves the mouth a little dry, maybe the alcohol.  Alcohol in this guy is barely noticeable, given the high ABV, but comes out a little as the beer warms.  Very good overall, but it has not lived up to its hype (not an easy thing to do I suppose).  Important note:  letting this beer warm up to just under room temperature improves the enjoyment of this beer considerably.

Visual: Black and opaque like espresso, quarter inch head that coats the walls of the glass and remains until the beer is gone. Smell: Quite a nose on this one. Burnt sugar/molasses in the forefront, undertones of dark roasted coffee. A bit of alcohol in there as well. Reminds me ever so slightly of dark, aged rum. Taste: Coffee and dark chocolate come through pretty strongly in the flavor, like an alcoholic mocha. Molasses and just a touch of hops give it a lingering, bitter finish that lasts until the next sip. This is surprisingly smooth and sweet for such a robust beer. It looks intimidating, but its actually pretty drinkable. Mouth: To call this full-bodied is an understatement. Thick and syrupy, minimal carbonation. It coats the mouth in the way that only an imperial stout can. Drinkability: Good for the style, but its still so heavy that a glass or two should be enough for most people.

I picked this up while in the San Diego area, consumed with a friend in his backyard in Portland, OR.  I was looking forward to consuming this one, and it didnt disappoint.  Aroma consists of lactose, very milky, with hints of coffee and chocolate.  Appearance is black with a tan creamy head.  This is a beer to enjoy with your dessert...huge amounts of chocolate and coffee, very milky and very good.

Extremely black with a nice creamy brown coffee-like lasting head. The aroma is not that complex, a bit metallic, with the obvious coffee and chocolate notes. The alcohol is rather perceivable. Has a huge full body, you could eat it with a teaspoon, and a rich silky balanced flavour, a mix of coffee, bitter chocolate, with some occasional ripe cherry and prune notes and a certain balancing sourness. A bitter&sweet delicious brew.

Bottle. Quite black pour with a moderate, tan head. Aroma of subtle roast, loads of coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla and berries as well as a little hops. Well-balanced. Taste is huge on coffee and roasty bitterness and has some bitter chocolate, dark berries as well. Medium carbonation, long duration, high viscosity, quite full-bodied. Best enjoyed at about 15 degrees (C), where the whole thing truly unfolds. Very nice!

Shared with svoger and beerbiker at my bicycle weekend debut. Awsome looking bottle, the one with silver cap and opague black bottle. The look is close to opague black aswell with a creamy dark brown head. Perfect. Aroma is just intensly full of roasted coffee notes along with cocoa. After Mikkellers black as hell/coal, this one had a mild and round taste and a balanced sweetness matching the huge amount of roasted bitterness. Great solid brew!

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2014 Pours dark with a nice creamy head. Nice and sweet aroma. I thought this would be more coffee than dark chocolate but it is the bitter and dark chocolate which is dominating along with some very dark fruits, vanilla and a little bit of smoke. Taste has the dark fruits, some liquorce, coffee, dried fruits, vanilla and dark chocolate. Balance is very very good! Really pleasing!

Bottle split among friends in snifters produced a small tan head that settled to a thin lace. The head easily could be brought back with a swirl of the glass. The body of the brew was the typical black stout color.

The first thing I noticed was tha lack of coffee aroma coming from the brew seeing the way they pushed it on the lable I expected something a little more robust. It did have a good chocolate smell and when it warmed got to room temp the coffee was a bit more present. On the flavor the sme thing happened I got some great roast but more bitter chocolate than coffee. The mouthfeel was good and thick with ample carbonation.

It drank well for a stout I wasnt really wanting for more. Maybe it was Hype meeting reality that thru me on this one I am glad I tried it but knowing the price point on this brew. Most likely one and done for me, but having said that I would like to see the difference on tap, and being barrel age brings.

Bottle, 75 cl. Pitch black with a nice and big brown head. Very neatly looking. Nose is HUGE on coffee and roast, little berries, nice sweetness, little alcohol and some hop freshness. Taste is as huge on the coffee as the aroma, rich on the roast, bitter dark chocolate, as it gets higher in tempratures, it reveals some delicious sweet notes with dark caramel and dark berries. It disappointed me a bit when it was about 10-12 degrees C when it was quite one-sided on the roast, but as it reached 15-18 degrees, it was very rich and just amazing.

smoke, woody, raisin, resin, roasty, toast, coffee, chocolate, caramel, 
such a piece of work; manages to give a lot both notes-wise, body-wise, and taste-wise. when all is said and done this is a very broad brew

Pours Jet Black with a nice, large, beige head.  An absolutely gorgeous beer.  The smell is great, coffee and chocolate are the scents that come to mind here.  The taste is even better, coffee, chocolate, roasted malt finish.  I am at a loss of words here.  I am amazed that this beer is so accessible here in southern california where I am enjoying it.  If this were the last beer that I ever drank,  I would feel good about that.

Many a bottle and pour on tap (most recently at Stone).  An absolutely excellent, well-brewed wonder of the beer world.  Huge chocolate and coffee with a roasted malt finish that exerts itself more as the glass warms.  12% ABV so well hidden.   If this beer came out 1 time per year in a limited release of 500 bottles (wax dipped) it would be rated #1 in the world - hands down one of the highest quality/most easily accessible beers.

Pours a deep, dark black with a HUGE froathy tan head. Smells just like the bottle says: Roasty, toasy, and coffee with a subtle sweetness in the nose. 
Sweet up front with an aggressive bitterness in the back end. Very drinkable. Slight alcohol taste in the end, glad I have another in the cellar as it might mellow out with some age on it.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2010 Thanks to DeadGirl for hooking this one up.  Wow, I think this might be the best beer I have ever had.  Pours a jet black with a nice beige head that fades.  Aroma is lots and lots coffee.  Coffee is huge in the flavor as well making this so damn good.  As big as this stout is there is zero alcohol in the nose or finish, its unreal.  Mouthfeel is thick and creamy.  This is about as good as it gets.

750ml bottle in a snifter.  Had at Monks Cafe in Philly.  Pours black with a thin beige head.  Coffee and oatmeal dominate the aroma, with a slight hint of honey.  Full bodied and oily texture.  A long chocolate finish.  What a good beer.

Bottle from Ölbutikken, Copenhagen.

Pours black with a huge brown head. Probably the thickest foam Ive ever seen, could have eaten it with a spoon as chcolate mousse!

Aroma of coffem chocolate, vanilla and malt.

Tast of cacao, rosted malts and coffe grounds. 
Huge and uncompromising.

Bottle. Pours black with a huge latte coloured head. Coffee beans and vanilla notes in aroma. Quite anonymous compared to the taste though. Lots of cacao, milk chocolate and coffee in taste. Very complex aftertaste with notes of milk chocolate, vanilla and some smokiness. A little dry.

Bottle. Poured a jet black color with a creamy tan head. Wow I love this beer. I thought maybe this beer was overrated but no I was wrong. Aroma was milk chocolate, roasted malts, coffee,and caramel.. Flavor was burnt notes. Very rich and creamy. Milk chocolate taste. Very good. Very smooth. One of the best beers Ive had. Very different from other imerial stouts. I need more of this...good beer

(2009 vintage 750ml bottle) Pours nice tall dark tan head. Lots of tiny bubbles coat the inside of the glass. Aromas of bread, cereals and light roasted grains. Normal body. Most prominent flavor is that of coffee. Undertones of dark sugary flavor. Ever so slight warming in the back of the throat. This beer is pretty deceiving for being a 12% beer! If you like big stouts grab a bottle if you can. You wont be disappointed!!

Bottled at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Black color with dark rusty head. Thick roasty, fruity, grassy and coffeish aroma. Sweet coffeish flavor with nice fruity roastedness. Smooth warming palate. Very mellow and tasty, like smooth espresso.

Bottle at the M;ikkeller bar, kindly shared by James the brewer.
Low key chocolate, coffee, other elements lurking underneath. Creamy.
The alcohol is wonderfully camouflaged.
750 bottle....pours pitch black.  medium tan head.  Strong coffee and chocolate smells and tastes.  Very robust also.  Very good.

Bottle from the Beerstore(NZ). WOW, what a big beer. Pours pitch black with a huge tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, roasted Malt. You wouldnt think this was a 12% beer, alcohol is completely hidden. Im loving every mouthful.
From a 750ml,super coffee and chocolate notes,smells like it ,this just a damn good beer find it and drink it !!!!!!! brown head,black in color,a personal favorite

Had this awesome brew with James and pat. Pour was dark thick brown with nice lasting head. Laces. Aroma is molasses, Choc and malts. Flavor is so sweet chocolate. Some minor coffee roasts. Delicious indeed.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours deep, deep chocolate brown with a thin amber head. Aroma of chicory, pepper, spice, chocolate, coffee, milk, oat, barley, roasted malt, and sight notes of hops. Medium to full bodied with a spicy, yet insanely smooth palate. Creamy, peppery finish. Absolutley insane Imperial stout. So well balanced. I love this.

very dark brown, thick smooth brown head.
very balanced and very nice roasted aroma, balanced by hops. powerful aroma. hops and roasted notes blend perfectly.
flavor is very strong, licorice, coffee, brown sugar sweetness, then a lot of roasted grains, some caramel, some sweet malts, some licorice. well blended. aftertaste is roasted and caramelly sweet. alc well hidden.

Bottle looks simple, but really good. Beer in the glass deep black, nice head. Very, very sweet aroma, reminds me of different kinds of sweets. Starts malty-soft, light coffee notes, bitter chocolate, very, very well balanced. Finish warming-malty, soft as velvet, soft coffee notes. Very, very drinkable. Absolutely amazing beer!

Bottle via trade with Blankboy. Many thanks Paul! Is this beer huge? yes it is. Jet black pour with brown head. Aroma is super rich, coffee with also lots of licorice, molasses and also something vanilla about it too. Taste is just awesome rich coffee flavors, with some vanilla smoothness great bitter/sweet mix. Palate is perfectly creamy with just enough carbonation, one of the best Ive had.

Wow this is a great beer.  Pours black with a huge light brown head. Big coffee and roasted malt aromas with a slight hint of alcohol.  Roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee flavors with some hop bitterness and a warming alcohol finish.  Creamy mouthfeel with medium carbonation.  Very smooth and drinkable for a high alcohol beer.

Finally got my hands on this bad boy, and it did not disappoint.  750 ml bottle.  The appearance is jet with a big tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and roastyness.  Taste is much the same, heavy on the coffee.  Just huge flavor, and great mouth feel!

Dark chcolatey syrup pour with little dark brown head. Tastes kind off like a higher alcohol Sam Adams cream stout but with much more complex notes of toffee, coffee, burnt sugar and a nice high alcohol finish.

Obtained in trade from BarZigKin.  Midnight dark pour from bottle.  Coffee and grass on the nose.  Taste is coffee, alcohol and grass, with some bitter chocolate mixed in.  Smooth mouthfeel and finish.  Excellent!

Thanks Kevin for sharing this! Had it before but have not reviewed it yet.

A- Huge dark tan foamy head that is 2-3 . This fades eventually to 1/2 finger and has good retention from there. Body is big, viscous, opaque, and black.

S-This brew smells really hot w/ alcohol. A big roasted malt/coffee presence is also noticeable and dominant. Behind all this are characteristics typical for an IRS such as dark fruit, licorice, dark chocolate, plum, and anise. Nose is pretty complex.

T- Flavor is HUGE and filled with roasted malt, and coffee flavors upfront, and, as with the nose, a lot of IRS characteristics going on like dark fruit, anise, and dark chocolate. The ABV is pretty hot and does not really even attempt to hide itself. It offers a slight bitterness and a big alcohol heat at the end.

P-Medium carbonation, thick viscous body, slightly smooth and creamy but has an alcohol astringency component as well.

O-This is a big,really intense, high octane stout that is full of flavor, complexity, and a lot of booze. Overall-a really good, well put together brew by one of my favorite breweries-Alesmith.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-29-2010 15:19:28
bomber shared at DLD-black pour -aroma and taste of chocolate, lots of coffee, dried fruit-smooth sweet black coffee finish

Big coffee/espresso nose. Huge caramel and mocha flavors, but nothing that simple...roasted malt, brown sugar, licorice, vanilla cream, dark dried fruits, dates, etc. BIG alcohol warming as I progress. One of the very best.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2011 2009 bottle from daknole- thanks, dak! Pours a very dark opaque brown, almost black and darker than the 2006 BA Speedway next to it. Aroma of coffee, cocoa, herbal hops, earth, roasted malts, and just a small dash of alcohol. The flavor has a nice sweetness to balance the roastiness and earthy/herbal hops; notes of coffee, roasted malts and grains, chocolate and cocoa. A little alcohol shows up late. Full-bodied, smooth, and slick on the palate, with low carbonation and a nice sweet roasty finish. Just a slight notch down from the BA Speedway, since they did the barrel so well on this one. Wow, what a beer. Re-Rate, 11/1/11: Had this yet again, this time next to a 2009 BA Speedway Stout. This time, though, the body seemed much smaller in the regular SS, the aroma was somewhat oxidized, and none of the elements of the flavor stood out. I wont downgrade too much, but this doesnt seem to be holding up all that well for a 2009 vintage.

(750ml bottle thanks to BA zdk9) near black pour, deep brown tight bubbles and sticks around a long while. Nice looking stout. Nose of cocoa, yeast, dark chocolate, and coffee. Taste of coffee, raw coffee beans, cream, and chocolate syrup. Very flavorful. Medium to thick body, very long duration, super creamy finish. Great linger on the palate!

Pitch black color with a caramel head.  Aroma is of malts, molasses, dried fruit, plum, coffee, and vanilla.  Flavor is basically the same.  An amazing and full character in these flavors.  Thank you Keith for bonusing this one for me.

Great stout.  The coffee flavor is subtle and not overpowering.  It has all the bitterness and dark flavor I am used to in a stout at a level that is not overpowering.  I think I prefer the vanilla tones of Goose Islands Bourbon County Stout or Southern Tiers Oat Stout but overall its quite good.

2006 bottle opened April 2010.

I guess Ive never rated this one before. Black pour, dark tan head. Huge roasty nose, chocolate and molasses, some espresso. Massive flavor, the sweet chocolates balancing out the alcohol and bitter hops just right, never too ashy. This one always did set the bar for imperial stouts. Its still hot, even after 4 years; the 12% continues to burn even after all this time, and maybe thats my biggest complaint regarding the beer. Still, its a legend and a standard-setter. Classic beer.

Bottle. Pours black with a yellow dark brown head with that laces nicely, one of the best looking beers I have seen. Aroma has notes of coffee, roasted malts, toffee and dark chocolate. Flavor is similar, begins with coffee notes, but dark chocolate and toffee grows quickly. The first couple of sips left me with a metallic after taste, but that went away quickly. Nice an thick on the tongue.

[Bottle] courtesy of kmweaver. Thanks, Ken! Man its taken me a long time to get around to acquiring and tasting this one. Pours a deep, clear brown with a medium tan head that dissipates to a thin ring around the edges and leaves some spotty lacing. Aroma is dark coffee and some grounds, a nice smack of dark chocolate, plenty of roasted malt, and a touch of sweetness. The flavor is very coffee forward, lots of roast character, just a touch of green pepper, moderate sweetness and the finish is moderately astringent and bittersweet. Really, really nice beer.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. Pours black with brown head. Aromas of coffee and roasted malts. Lots of great coffee flavor with roasted malts and some chocolate and toffee. Medium body with minimal carbonation and a soft mouthfeel. Excellent! Thanks Craig.

Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, tobaco, coffee and light dark fruit. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, tobaco, coffee and dark fruit. Round, smooth and wellbalanced beer.

750 cc bottle. Pours black with a small brown and no-lasting head. The aroma is coffee and roasty, the taste is pretty complex: is bitter with coffee, roasty and chocolate flavors. The body is full, with medium carboation. Finish is bitter. One of the best beer of my life!

75cl bottle. Pours a black colour with small brown head. Little lasting foam. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, dried fruits and brown sugar. Flavor is mainly coffe with chocolate, roasted malt, alcohol and hints of rhum, too. Full-bodied beer with little carbonation. Coffe bitterness in the end. Great Imperial Stout!

#200, poured from 750, courtesy of SamGamgee.  Darkest of browns with medium dark tan head that lingered and left a beautiful lacing. Nose is huge, with chocolate and dark fruit  aromas mixed with coffee.Taste of sweet coffee with a dusting of semi sweet chocolate on top.  Alcohol is somewhat  present, but in the background of everything else.  Full bodied with a nice long finish, most excellent!

Bottle courtesy of daknole.  Pours an opaque black.  Moderate dark tan head with decent retention and lacing.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malt and dried figs and cherries.  Flavor is mostly coffee and dark malts, with subtle hints of toffee and molasses.  Nice smooth mouthfeel and very little burn given the ABV.  Very nice.

very deep brown to black color, dark lacing. Aroma is of cherries and oak, flavor is roasted malt, very smooth and coffee. Lots of coffee. More smooth than bitter. Aftertaste hits you  in the roof of the mouth. Bottle from a tasting with Smith4498, Legato, and Cbeers21.

8oz. taster from brewery,Creamy medium brown head, black, black, black colour. Aroma of roasted coffee and malts, alcohol, fruits, licorice and some chocolate. Flavour is full of coffee, roasted malts, sugar, alcohol, rich yet almost too balanced. Thick oily mouthfeel, little to no carbonation.  Very well made brew, well balanced and complex only drawback from my perspective is that it is almost too balanced, with an imp like this one expects more of a punch in the face.

Bottle. Very dark pour with a huge light brown head. Aroma of coffee and bitter chocolate. Mouthfeel is smooth but not overly heavy. Coffee dominates the taste, with some lactose and mild bitterness. Great stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 750 ml bottle. An opaque black beer, with a large, frothy, creamy, lacing, mostly lasting, brown head. The aroma is heavily malty (coffee, molasses, roasted grain, chocolate), lightly hoppy (grapefruit, resin), with a strong note of licorice, other notes of alcohol, vanilla, plum, raisin. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, very lonhg finish with moderate to heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. A masterpiece, no hesitation, from start to finish. Strong coffee aroma, but not overwhelming, since there are many other aspecrs... Excellent creamy mouthfeel and just the right amount of booze. All in all the most solid Alesmith product and one of the best stouts in the world.

Bottle.It dont get  much better then this i guess.Pitch black colour with large beige creamy head.Aroma of tar,coffee,licorice and earth.Full body and strong rosted mouthfeels,nice warming and heavy finish.
A good beer with a decent mouth feel.  I just felt as if the coffee was overbearing and took away from the beer.  Would drink again but definately preferred, Black Ops and KBS over this one.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 270310.
Black with beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is coffee with sweet chocolate and notes of liqourice. Nice palate

19-MAR-2010, bottle with Ulkløbben - @home, from "Fish & Beer".
Sooou smooth, so full...
Not alcoholic. I understand the hype.
6th best beer in the world? No Idea, but one of the best beers in my book.
Very coffee-like, with chocolate, and roasted notes that are just so complex.
Not my first Alesmith. They are really worth seeking out.

Creamy medium brown head, black, black, black colour.
Aroma of roasted coffee and malts, alcohol, fruits, licorice and some chocolate.
Flavour is full of coffee, roasted malts, sugar, alcohol, rich yet almost too balanced.
M: Thick oily mouthfeel, little to no carbonation.
T: Very well made brew, well balanced and complex only drawback from my perspective is that it is almost too balanced, with an imp like this one expects more of a punch in the face.
Bottle at the RateBeer tent at pre-ZBF 2010, thank you gentlemen.  Dark brown, almost black, tan head.  Aroma of burnt espresso.  Taste has coffee, milk chocolate, light smoke.  Nice.

Bottled (@Pikkulintu)
Pitch black color, steady tan head. Aroma of sweetish licorice and coffee. Medium to full bodied. Soft, very drinkable. Lots of (salted) licorice, coffee. Backing alcohol. Very balanced and smooth, not too burnt nor too bitter. Somehow reminds me about Stormarktsporter.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu) Poured black with small and light brown head. Aroma contained liquorice, coffee, roastedness and hint of ash. Palate was full bodied and dry with medium medium carbonation. Flavours were liquorice, coffee, roastedness, mildly sweetness, hops, saltiness and bitterness. Aftertaste contained coffee, liquorice, ash and bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2010 Bottle thanks to giascar pours pitch black with a tan creamy head aromas are of chocolates,coffee,anice,and roasted malts medium sweetness, of chocolate,caramel malts and coffee very smooth and very drinkable this one has over 2 years on it and is very approachable

Enormous thanks to both Durhambeer and Beeronmypants for this surprise trade! Pours a deep black with a nice big tan head and great lace. The aroma is coffee with some sweet baked goods, some floral notes and plenty of roasty malt, there is just an hint of booze in the background. The flavor is mildly sweet and endlessly complex, my expectation of speedway stout was pretty much blown out of the water I expected a ton of coffee which I got but there is oh so much more going on here. The beer is bitter in both a hoppy and a coffee wiay, there is some brandy but not really an alcohol burn with some burnt toast, and some creamy flavors, all of this is really cohesive and balanced. Damn.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, tar, and a hint of lactose.  Poured pitch black in color with a large, creamy, dense, frothy, dark brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of bitter coffee, roasted malt, light chocolate, slight tar, and a hit of alcohol.  Medium to full body.  Coating, then dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Bitter coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and tar finish is lightly dry.  12%ABV is present in the flavor, but by no means overwhelming.

Alesmith
Speedway Stout
Pours jet black with a thick dark brown head and excellent retention. Some lacing on the glass. Oily. Aroma is coffee and something slightly metallic with booze. Sweet brown sugar smell on the finish. Flavor is somewhat muted, but well balanced. Alcohol is well hidden, but overall I have to say I am slightly underwhelmed. Old Rasputin is better. Beer needs to be bigger. Some hoppy bitterness on the finish with the usual coffee and soy flavors.

Not sure of the year, but purchased 2 weeks ago.
Coffee, alcohol and malt fill the nose as this is poured. opaque black with a thick tan head. Rich coffee malty taste with a sweet chocolate malt hint that lingers for the perfect time. terrific beer that i highly recommend to any coffee stout lover

Bottle thanks to Secret Santa 2008. Black pour with a thin brown head. Lots of brown lace. Big chocolate, coffee aroma with a strong alcohol presence. Big, full, heavy palate with low carbonation. Creamy and silky on the tongue. Flavor was delicious dark chocolate and coffee with a hint of vanilla bean. I was a bit worried after reading the commercial description at the top of the page that the coffee would be strong and overwhelming, but it wasnt. Just the right amount to balance with the dark chocolate. This beer was HUGE and many thanks to whoever my Secret Santa was at Christmas 2008.

Flaske: Fantastisk duft af kaffe på en kulsort øl. Desværre er karboneringen ikke overbevisende, hvilket bevirker at der ikke er så flot skumhoved på. Smagen er igen masser af kaffe der tilmed giver den en anelse surhed. Bitter og lang eftersmag. Igen mangler der en lille tand karbonering til at bakke fylden op med. Men stadig en rigtig lækker øl.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2013 Despite the fact the reviews talk this beer up so much, Speedway Stout is one of my favorite beers. Its like a Southern California icon. The pour is the color of asphalt as the name evokes. A very distinctive aroma -- you know this has a ton of coffee in it. Tastes like a blend of roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate. Substantial all the way through. The price is a bit high for me, but you can use a $1 off coupon at Total Wine -- but it used to be $2 off. I wish this came in a 4 pack for $6. At least its not a shandy.
hoppy,brown, hazy, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, lively, bitter, long finish, nice beer

UPDATED: APR 15, 2010 Pitch black pour with tan head light lacing ..... aroma of chocolate, roasted coffee ...... smells and looks great .... taste of chocolate, roasted malts and coffee taste all the flavors balance well and then there is a bitter kick at the end ..... a little acidic but no trace of the 12% anywhere in this stout ..... a very tasty and sessionable beer
Pours a dark brown with a nice full brown head. Aroma is of nicely toasted malt, coffee and hops. Taste is pretty smooth with malt, coffee and hops. Good, but kinda sharp on the taste.

100th Review -- 750mL Bottle -- Pours black with a small brown head.  Aromas of roasted malt,  heavy coffee, dark chocolate, fennel, and barley.  Quite bitter yet smooth, oily mouth-feel, full bodied, long-long finish.  Alcohol is present but not overpowering.

Bottle. Pours an opaque black with a huge creamy brown head. Beautiful lacing in the glass. Lightly roasted malts compliment the rich chocolate and coffee bean notes. As it warms up I get sweet malt goodness - caramel, dark chocolate, roast and port. Gloriously balanced, it all blends together perfectly. Its way too easy to drink, and thats by no means a bad thing, with a smooth bitterness that lingers after the finish. The pick of the night for sure. A wonderful beer. Bottle courtesy of Jonno - cheers!

Black. Brown head, mostly lasting. Aroma is dark, roasted, coffee, faint chocolate, burnt notes too. Flavor is heavy sweet, malty, moderate bitter finish, dark fruit, more coffee. Syrupy texture. Yeasty. Warming alcohol.

Enjoyed at my fathers place in Mesa, AZ. Had wanted to try this one for a very long time, but living in MN made this difficult. No need to reiterate what every else has said, just need to record that this is the best, easy drinking stout I have ever tasted.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2015 Very much a Double Stout. Like a big roast stout x 2. Initially disapointing on the nose as it warms the coffee and chocolate work their way to the top. In the mouth it is a wave of chocolate and coffee with the bitterness hitting the back of the palate. Drinkability is really high. I nfact i could finish off a bottle of this by myself easily. Much more a subtle, complex beast than I was expecting. A masterclass in how to brew a big roasty moreish beer. On tap at the brewery the roast is much pronunced. Great.

On tap at AleSmith Brewing Co. (San Diego, CA): Pours out opaque black topped with a firm pale brown head. The aroma is the real bomber here- pure coffee beans and rich dark chocolate, as well as other rich dark malts. Balanced and pure. Full-bodied with strong notes of black coffee and cocoa, followed by burnt sugar. Drinkability: Simplistic brew with solid flavors. Almost in every way what I imagine a perfect impy stout to taste like. Pairing: Big fat In-N-Out burger (animal style, obviously). Rebuy: Definitely. #289 on 25022010, DG.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2013 Bottle. Almost black body with medium size light brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee with notes of alcohol. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, medium sweet, hops, medium bitter, little liquorice with notes of alcohol.
Black with a brown head. Roasted malts dominate the nose. Tastes like chocolate and burnt coffee. Whats really interesting is that this full bodied beer is feels so smooth. 12%... Really?

Bottle, thanks to Fredrik (and Brill!). Pours a black color with a lightbrown head. Aroma is first all about the coffee, but theres also roasted malt notes, dark chocolate, liquorice and toffee. Flavour is dominated by powerful black coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, liquorice and toffee. Its a bit earthy, even. Fullbodied. Carbonation is soft, and the texture is thick. Finish is bitter. Overall, this is a damn good beer, with an impressing body and powerfull coffee bean taste. Lovely stuff.

#500 - I dont trade for beer and have had a hard time finding this one until I lucked out and saw this bottle at Lillys in Cleveland. Bottle: pours dark black with a thick tan head, aroma of chocolate, coffee and malt, taste is a little boozy, bitter coffee, roasted malts, a bit of chocolate, full bodied and a fairly dry finish.  Worth the wait.

750-ml bottle Napacabs - Aroma: roasted, coffee, chocolate; Appearance: opaque, jet-black color, tan head, lots of laces; Flavor: coffee, dark chocolate, roasty, raisin, caramel; Mouthfeel: full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, bitter finish; Overall: a cleanly fermented and wonderfully velvety smooth big beer that hides the alcohol level with a nice malty bitter finish.
pours a dark brown. semi-smoky nose to it.  almost bbq tasting.  a lot of roasty malt notes.  not bad but too rauchbier-ish for my taste.
Love this well-crafted stout. True in its character. As a bud of mine said..it will make you a wide-awake drunk. :-)

Thick, Rich, and Creamy! With an alcohol content that could put down a horse! It pours dark as night with a brownish head. The aroma has plenty of carmel and COFFEE...of course. The palate is smooth and creamy and lasts well after its swallowed. Impressively balanced, not too sweet, and not too bitter (considering the coffee). Considering the alcohol content, the flavors are so well balanced.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2010 Awesome. Very thick dark chocolate, coffee and strong alcohol percentage (Although the taste hides it very well). Ive had other stouts where the chocolate and coffee tastes just dont seem right but this one is great. I wasnt as big of a fan of the aroma as I was of the flavor, but that may have been unavoidable with such a high alcohol content. Regardless, this is a great beer

Bottle. High creamy and dense thick looking brown head leaving nice curtains. Pitch black body. Light bitter and yet creamy coffee choccolate aroma. Creamy and smooth intensive strong coffee choccolate flavor with a mild bitterness at the finish. Low carbonation. Long aftertaste. Alcohol can be spotted in the aroma but is very well hidden in the flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2010 Bottled. Pours out in an aopque black topped with a low firm pale brown head. Big aroma of coffee, nougat, rich dark malts. Full-bodied with strong solid notes of of dark coffee dark chocolate and rich solid dark malts. Perfect mouthfeel. Long rich aftertaste of coffee, dark chocolate, burnt sugar and cocoa. A stone rock solid brew with simplistic wonderful flavours.

Ah, my first speedway!  Pours thick and oily in the glass and produces a slowly building creamy mocha head.  Fair dense coffee nose.  Strong roast, hint of bourbon, full bodied and creamy.  Great lacing.  Warming throughout.  Solid and sturdy.

To get into this rating you must understand that this rating constitutes from the tastes of this beverage from years back, 6 or so to be exact.  Back then, this was a solid 4.4.  Lately its seemed to me to be much thinner, with not as much of a punch.  Regardless, one of the worlds top brews, the coffee notes are overwhelming in that way that leaves you screaming for more.  YUM.

Bottle. Thanx Ölbutikken and Jeppe!!!! Pours a really dark/black color with a minibeighehead. Aroma is a good blast of coffee and dark fruit with some subtle roated malt and a wonderful caramel touch. Finally lets taste this son of a gun. Unbelievable smooth mouthfeel! Taste is filled with fresh coffee,liqourice, dark fruit and some caramel.  Pretty sweet but not overpowering. Supereasy to drink, dangerous! Great beer!
Bottle shared with Maggi & Colgan.  Pour is black and thick.  Taste is deep espresso, dark cocoa.  Mouthfeel is robust and crisp..  well hidden @ 12%

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Location: 750 ml bottle from NickD717 via trade, 3/24/10, my last beer from our Summer 09 trade


Aroma: The nose has lots of coffee, with chocolate and other dark malt notes

Appearance: Pours a dark brown color with a small, lasting brown head

Flavor: Nice malt dominated flavor, roasted malts, and lots of flavor 

Palate: Full bodied, creamy and enjoyable texture, a touch of alcohol feel

Overall Impression: 
Drinking this one with some friends to celebrate my time living in MD.  The age did this one well, it is rather good.  Moved the rating up just slightly from 4.2 to a 4.3.  Thanks, Nick!  This beer is to you, Rockville!  


Location: On tap at the Brewery, 1/8/10 


Aroma: Lots of roasted coffee, chocolate, and caramel

Appearance: Dark black beer with fine brown head

Flavor: Roasted malty flavor of coffee, dark chocolate, and vanilla, with some nice roasted and chocolaty bitterness in the finish

Palate: Full bodied, smooth brew with a creamy mouthfeel

Overall Impression: 
Ive been holding onto a bottle of this beer for a while, but I was able to try it on draft while visiting AleSmith, and I am curious to see how the ratings will compare between the draft and the bottle (with some age on it) versions.  Here goes the rating for the draft version: 
A big coffee flavored beer that has a really nice overall feel to it.  This is a very good Imperial Stout.  I enjoyed my draft sampling quite a bit, and I look forward to the bottle sampling. (4.2)

Poured into a tulip.  Jet black with an epic mocha head.  Head dissipated fairly quickly into a 1/4 inch ring with a small swirl of foamy bubbles floating in the middle.  Left a nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma was intense with coffee.  Flavor was terrific with coffee and dark chocolate most pronounced.  Dry, slightly bitter finish.  Full bodied with a slightly oily mouthfeel.  Glad I finally got around to giving this one a try.

Huge Beer!  Jet Black like motor oil, with a toast-brown head. Starts with a strong coffee and dark chocolate sensation, then fades to a multitude of toasty, roasty and caramelly flavors. Velvety smooth texture full-bodied.

Bottle @ Hj Hansen, Odense. Pours completely black with a small creamy brown head and lacings. Nose is roasted coffee. Pretty complex. Taste has chocolate, coffee beans and a hint of vanilla. Silky smooth and full palate. Bitter roasted dry coffee end. Nice

Sampled at the epic Boise tasting 1/16/10 
Appearance: Pours pitch black with a nice dark tan head 
Aroma: Roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, dark fruits 
Taste: Dark coffee, chocolate, vanilla 
A very smooth and silky beer, easy drinkability.

2009 750ml split with DarkBeerChick.  Enjoyed at 55 degrees.  Id call the pour imperial BLACK with a 1/2 inch of roasted coffee/cappucino-colored head that recedes into a creamy-appearing ring around the glass.  Aroma of heavily roasted coffee, burnt caramel malt, plums, semi-sweet chocolate and general roastiness.  Initial flavors of roast coffee, bitter chocolate and balanced malt sweetness.  Secondary flavors of stone fruits, red wine sour and lingering coffee/mild hop bitterness--No "bite," just a nice smooth, clinging aftertaste.  Very slick/creamy, oily mouthfeel that leaves a slight coating on the palate.  Ultra fine carbonation with a medium body.  High ABV is well concealed and results in an almost subconcious warming when sipped over a period of time.  Im glad we have three more of these!

750ml champagne bottle from a very good friend in Arizona who shipped it to me and my hubby here in Dallas. Pours black as night with a dark tan head. Gorgeous lacing. Aroma is of molasses, raisins and coffee. Full-bodied with an incredibly creamy texture. Tastes of strong coffee (maybe even espresso) and dark chocolate with a bit of caramel. Starts off sweet and finishes with a slight coffee bitterness. Alcohol burns the tummy just a bit, but I dont detect much alcohol on the nose. NICE!

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2010 Oh boy.  This was my first rating ever and it was in severe need of updating.  Man, I was a n00b.  Well, the truth is I can kinda remember what it tasted like when I had it way back when, but the reason Im updating this is because I just had a aged bottle, and to me, it just wasnt as good.  I was kinda let down, but in truth, I liked it better pre-aged.  That deserved a 5/5.  But after 10 months of aging, something went awry.   All the coffee notes disappeared, and the brew as a whole tasted a bit like bourbon.  The chocolate notes tasted burnt, and it just wasnt as magical an experience as I had hoped.  That being said, I am leaving my rating at a 5/5 because when I had that bad boy on tap @ the brewery in Nov 09, it blew my tiny mind wide open and I have been looking for something equally as good ever since, since it isnt available where I live.  Fantastic beer with everything right, so long as you like imperial stouts, and the flavors of coffee and chocolate.  Otherwise its not your beer.  I will edit this again (more concisely) when I ever get my hands on a fresh one.

Beer pours black with a tan head. The aroma is strong chocolate with a little bit of coffee and roasted malt. The flavor has more coffee than the aroma but the beer finishes with a nice chocolate flavor, which gets stronger as it warms. There is also a bitter chocolate note that really works well with this beer. You get a little alcohol in the flavor as well. The mouthfeel is very creamy and makes this beer absolutely delicious. This is one of the best stouts I have ever had and I will definitely try it again.

I was disappointed in this one...certainly did not live up to the hype. Aroma had some coffee/roasted notes and not much else. Flavor was mainly tart/sweet, with only a background of coffee/roasted malt. Would have thought the mouthfeel would have been thicker. Definitely not worth the hype or the price.

This is a great beer by AleSmith (as I have come to expect from one of the best breweries in the US).  Pours pitch black with a nice tan head, and some lacing.  The aroma is of coffee and roasted malts.  Nice coffee flavor finishing with some dark chocolate, and a very heavy body.  This is definitely something I will buy to put in the cellar if I can find it again.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2011 ke bomba!! questo è veramente un birone!... un bel nero opaco con schiuma marrone.. al naso si sente un equilibrio incredibile di malto torreffato cacao coffee beans e luppoli americani di sottofondo.. in bocca è morbida  e cioccolatosa con lamaro del luppolo ke si miskia al caffè....strepitosa!

Glorious pitch black pour. Large tan head. Chocolaty coffee aroma. Very silky mouthfeel. Taste is a lovely chocolate/malt flavoring but has a ridiculous coffee flavoring. Finish has a little bitter chocolate flavoring. Very good.

Another bottle from the tasting in the christmas days. Thx for sharing this bottle M. This is really a black thing. The beer is all black with some of the darkest crowns I.ve seen - Unfortunately its fading way too quick. Its a shame. The aroma is really nice and multible. Theres is tons of coffee, burned malts, lacorice combined with some mild sour notes like pears . The first thing I think of when I taste this is english sweet and bitter lacorice - add to that som stickin alcohol burned malts and nice and agressive bitterness. 
The palate is full bodied, creamy with a though crispyness - very nice palate.
In every way I find this one much better and way more complex and balanced that its bourbon aged big brother.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 Probably the best stout I have ever had.  Pitch black apperance, smelled of chocolate and coffee and tasted like dark chocolate and coffee beans with an unbelievable smooth finish. Overall this was one the best beers i have ever tried, cant wait to try it again.

Bottle courtesy of DA from Fever...thanks!  Pitch black, smells deeply of coffee and chocolate.  Some dark fruits, but overwhelming coffee and chocolate in the taste as well.  To be honest, one of the finest beers Ive ever had....I cannot wait to drink it again.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 Pitch black with a nice head and lacing all the way to the bottom of the bottle.  Aroma is of strong coffee, with some chocolate and berry notes coming through.  As I got to the bottom of my glass I also noticed some slight boozy scents, but they were pleasant rather than overpowering.  I wish the nose was slightly stronger, because it smells very good.  The taste and mouth feel are absolutely jawdropping.  Dark roasted coffee, chocolate, Dr. Pepper (?) and a delicious back end like a lightly sweetened latte.  Palate coating, sticky, full bodied but not overly viscous.  Insanely drinkable, low alcohol burn.  For the money, for the ease of acquisition, and for the ability to be consumed at any age or level of freshness, Speedway Stout might be the best beer in America.

Huge thanks to Cavie.  Jet black pour with a big, thick brown head.  Aroma is espresso beans, vanilla bean, dark chocolate, roasted malts, and caramel.  Big flavor.  Cream, caramel, toffee, coffee, and blackened malts.  Warm feel with a great aftertaste.  Beautiful.

Bottle courtesy of alagnek. Big thanks for this one! Glorious pitch black pour. Large tan head. Chocolaty coffee aroma. Very silky mouthfeel. Taste is a lovely chocolate/malt flavoring but has a ridiculous coffee flavoring. Finish has a little bitter chocolate flavoring. Very good.
Bottle from Cavie.  Pour is thick with a milky head.  Smell is inviting.  I was very much so looking forward to this beer and it /definately/ delivered.
Very tasty strong chocolate coffee stout. Very drinkable and didnt notice the alcohol that much. Is it the best out there though?

Sterile but seriously chocolatey aroma.  "Serious" black color with tan head.  Very sweet and chocolatey with a light red apple finish.

 Notes: 09 GABF
Poured a nice dark black with mild carbonation.   It had a strong coffee taste with hints of floral and citrus a very smooth taste and the alcohol is well hidden. A must try highly recommended.

At last some Speedway has found its way into my glass. While enjoying this stout I realized I wasnt really blown away by any one thing, and soon understood that what makes this great is simply how well its made. Opaque dark, rich brown body with a diminishing medium brown head and streaky/spotty lacing. Coffee and chocolate aromas dominated by burnt, roasted malts. Exceptional feeling from this beer, drinkable and approachable. Very smooth with a nice dry finish. Flavors mirror the robust aromas. Standard Imperial Stout qualities with an over abundance of quality coffee.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2010 Sampled this standing out in the cold at the ORF release thanks to kp.  It was more like smelling my morning coffee than a pungent 12% imperial stout.  Poured pitch black with little head.  Aroma had mostly coffee with a small amount of the dark chocolate malt.  Taste was overpoweringly coffee to the point that my palate was shot for the day.  Couldnt taste anything but coffee for the next hour.  Definitely complex and nice to drink if thats all youre going to be drinking for the day.  Too in-your-face for me.  Would have like a bit more drinkability instead of one sided coffee. 3.8

Re-rated from my own full bottle.  Had this fresh out in California and my opinion couldnt have changed more!  much more balanced with the coffee, chocolate, roasty malts.  Much smoother on the palate and enjoyable.  Great improvement

Black with good, creamy cappuccino head / Nose of dark roast coffee / Medium body, acidic, with good hop balance and dry finish / Flavors of dark roast coffee with vanilla notes / Very good, but a bit one note for me.

Shared 750mL bottle. Thanks Dan for tracking this one down! Pours black with lasting  tan head. Nose very coffee. Taste of more coffee, not too sweet. Notes of bitter chocolate, liquorice, with nice bitter finish. Great beer!

The pour on this was straight-up gorgeous -- like a prettier and immediate version of the Guinness-cascade with dark red around the edges.  Dark brown/black with an aggressive dark coffee head.  You definitely get the coffee in the taste and flavor, the rest and dark, sticky fruits like some boozy dates/figs.  Slick over the palate but not too coating with a bit of coffee aftertaste.  Awesome beer from Alesmith.

Saved this one for my 100th Rating. 750 served in a snifter. Shortish dark tan head sits atop a coffee colored body. Aroma is roasty and toasty coffee, and dark chocolate with some caramel-molasses sweetness. Also has a doughy quality and even some hints of pit fruit and vanilla. Full bodied, very thick and creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is coffee, roasted malts, caramel and resiny hops which linger on the bitter finish. The big alcohol is cleverly concealed. Im not giving this my highest rating, but its certainly a top-notch concoction. I will see how this develops as I empty the bottle. I imagine the barrel aged version would be amazing.

Shared Bottle, 2009.  Nearly black with a cappuccino head. Wonderful chocolate and malt smell with slight vanilla notes. Smooth and full taste. Taste begins with roasted malt, moves to coffee and ends with a bitter dark chocolate. Great beer I hope to get more of.

Aroma of figs and raisins, with a heavily roasted undertone, smoke, licorice. Pour is brown-black with a sticky tan head. Flavor has lots of dark fruits to it, cherry pits, more figs, floating above a dark chocolate malt base whose sweet spices (licorice, etc.) meld nicely with the alcohol heat. Full bodied, warm and lively on the palate. A very nice impy.

Bottle Courtesy of Senor Wambolt:  Pour is ink black, with burnt toast head.  Head dissipates quickly, no surprise, but laces beautifully.  Nose is definitely a JAVA blast, but I also picked up sweet fruits (like dark cherries or maybe plum).  Flavor is dark roast dominated, with the uber coffee tone.  As it warms to proper temp, I pick up faint vanilla and brown sugar hints.  But this is definitely a coffee bomb.  The malts are bitter, but not astringent.  The alcohol is noticeable, but only slightly so.  Mouthfeel is full bodied with a nice dry finish.  The finish lingers... and here you can pick up some of the more subtle characteristics.  Overall a very drinkable & tasty imperial... maybe too much so.

750ml bottle served in a snifter. Poured a deep brown/black with some red highlights. Sparse tan head. Chocolate in the aroma along with a bit of sourness that had me worried. Also thought I detected some cinnamon. Full bodied, rich and smooth. Roasted malt predominates, not as much coffee as I would suspect. Fair amount of hop bitterness to balance the malt. Long dry malt finish. Also some alcohol in the finish. Not a lot of carbonation.

Bottled 750ml. -from City Beer Store, San Francisco. Black coloured, medium sized brown head, dry coffee nose with touch of chocolate. Roasted malts, dark chocolate and strong coffee with mild alcohol presence. Notes of vanilla. Smooth and deadly drinkable. Pleasant long-lasting roasty aftertaste. Excellent brew.

Wow, #200!  This bottle (presumably 2009) was my first-ever Speedway, and its pretty fantastic!

Smell is surprisingly subdued, but primarily a nice, potent black coffee.  Also contains touches of booze and butterscotch (Im admitted stuffy today, but thats what I smelled).  Pours a thick pitch black liquid capped by a thin bubbly dark tan head that just barely clings to the glass.

Flavor is potent with the Ryan Brothers coffee and warmth from the high ABV.  Fades through to a nice tart fruit flavor and ends just a bit sweet and smoky.  Incredibly creamy and smooth mouthfeel, and very drinkable for such a big beer.

Far and away the most substantial beer Ive had. Theres just a lot going on here. Coffee dominates the aroma, which isnt terribly strong, and dominates the taste even more. Very thick, but not cloying. Coffee, chocolate, smoke, and just a bit of fruit. This is a fine beer, but be careful that you dont overdo it.

overall a very fine brew.  In tasting against darklord and narke stormaktsporter was a little disappointed.  Not quite as complex in terms of flavour profile compared to the others.  Predominant coffee on the nose and flavour.  Also some bitter chocolate flavour Palate sets this beer apart from others, smooth and easy to drink.  Similar flavour profile to peche mortel and founders breakfast.  A fine brew for certain just not as standoutish as I had hoped

A - Pours black as night with a tan head into my Dogfish Head shifter. Not too much lacing left behind with small tan bubbles on the top and around the rim.

S - Milk chocolate, coffee/espresso, and a small hint of the 12% ABV but not too much. 

T - Chocolate covered coffee beans with some alcohol on the finish. I imagine the alcohol would appear less as this bottle ages but really dont mind it. 

M- Medium bodied, rich and thick with some slight carbonation, very nice but I would prefer a fuller bodied. 

D- I split this bottle with my neighbor and I doubt Id be able to finish the entire bomber myself. With a year or more of age, I can imagine this stout will drastically improve.

OMG, this was worth the wait.  What a chocolately, caramelly, coffee delight!  Pours oily dark brown, almost black, the head was small on this one, probably too young, but did leave nice lacing.  Flavor is  rich bittersweet chocolate with coffee and roasted nuts.  So smooth for such a high ABV, with very little alcohol burn.  It warms me up and sends tingles up my spine, what a treat!
Pours black with a dark brown head and an aroma of strong black coffee. Sweet flavor with an intense bitter coffee aftertaste that grows and grows as it is enthusiastically consumed.

31/10 A 0.75 l bottle courtesy of ogivlado, huge thanks for sharing this! It poured oil black body with medium brown head. Weaker, but nice aroma of some caramel and coffee, ranging from roasted to sweet cappuccino. Unbelievably good coffee profile in the flavor, enriched with caramel and toffee. Not overly complex, but it doesnt change its quality. Very slight alcohol noted here, somewhat more in the finish, but at this ABV it should be felt more. Dangerously drinkable, yet full bodied with oily palate. Long and pleasant finish, bittersweet, again with that amazing coffee. I didnt hear for the beer before, so was really objective, coffee things in beer arent really my thing, which makes this even more fantastic!

speedway stout, one of the greats, it is what it is, nuff said. i put a fresh nug in this one and it added a nice dimension to the brew. some extra hoppiness, though it may have masked a part of the aroma.
Pours a dark chocolate brown with a thin tan colored. Aroma i very chocolatey and whiskey. Flavor is chocolate, whiskey notes. Malt flavor present. Palate is creamy with high carbonation.

Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes très complexes de café, de chocolat et de malt torréfié. Robe noire et opaque, peu de mousse et effervescence assez faible. Très ronde en bouche, la bière montre un côté malté très complexe, avec des notes de caramel brûlé et de chocolat. Le café est présent, mais bien intégré aux saveurs maltées. Finale relativement sucrée où pointe une amertume de torréfaction. Très bien équilibrée pour une bière de cette amplitude. Excellent !

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2010 *re-rate* 10/16/10 ON TAP @ AleSmith! wow, this beer is absolutely incredible fresh from the tap that i had to bump up my rating. huge, fresh roasted coffee notes, more chocolate cake notes, smoother, more silky mouthfeel. definitely world class.

750ml bottle from south bay for rating #350! pours a beautiful, oil-slick, black with a big, fluffy, dark beige head and amazing lacing. aroma is wonderfully rich with huge, dark roasted coffee, dark chocolate, massive toffee notes, with hints of marshmallow, toasted coconut, dark fruits, and mild, woody bourbon. flavor is simply outstanding with fresh, dark roasted coffee, espresso beans, and pure, bitter cacao chocolate notes up front joined seamlessly by big flavors of caramel, toffee, and roasted nuts with hints of fig, raisin, vanilla, and charred wood rounding out the sip and leading to an epic, roasted coffee and toasted caramel finish with a hint of warming alcohol. palate is truly full bodied, thick and viscous, but amazingly drinkable. overall, a absolute marvel of a beer.

Bottle shared by MrPickles - So this stuff is pretty good. Pours deep black with a creamy tan head. Smell is rich and sweet, with milk chocolate, light whiskey, cinnamon, and prunes. Theres nice roast in the taste, with sweet toffee and caramel, and coffee that stays through the finish. Its powdery and smooth in the mouth, with a medium-full body. Really well-balanced and easy to drink, and only a little alcohol burn--amazing for a 12% brew. Pretty impressive stuff.

Pitch black, decent viscosity and a medium sized pale brown head that settles rather slowly actually and leaves espresso-like lacings.

The smell is amazing. Rich, powerful and very balanced. Big coffee notes of espresso and freshly ground hard roasted coffee beans. Hints of soy sauce, salt licorice and dark fruits. Delightful notes of dark chocolate. Just a hint of tannins and slightly acidic roasty aromas. This is really impressive.

The taste is dominated through and trough by rich coffee flavors. Freshly ground coffee beans and espresso blend with wonderful flavors of dark chocolate and some nutty aromas. Notes of dark fruits. The sweetness is restrained in favor of bitter roasted flavors. The malty backbone is present, but hard to detect beneath all the coffee flavors. In the middle, the roasted character is accentuated further towards a taste of almost burnt coffee and malts. At this point, the beer actually gets a little too much and doesnt manage to keep everything together. But this is just a minor slip, and hardly of importance for the overall impression. Further, i notice a nice hop flavor that works really well with the coffee character. Notes of wood and fresh earth. The finish has a real coffee- and hop bitterness to it with notes of soy sauce, salt licorice and vanilla. Long lasting coffee notes lingers in the mouth. The alcohol is almost completely absent except for a pleasant warming sensation. This is just oh so tasty.

Very smooth but it still manages to leave a nice sticky sensation in the mouth. The body is not as big as I had expected, but I think this suits the beer well.

This is just a fantastic beer. Great flavors, big complexity and very balanced. Its really nice to come by a beer that manages to hold such bold and rich flavors together as this one does. And as this wasnt enough, its really really easy to drink, I went through a bottle way to quickly.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

GLASS: Snifter 
TEMP: Cellared @ approx 50 degrees 

This pours the expected jet black color.  An easy pour produces a four-finger head of creamy, dense, dark brown colored foam.  Retention is great.  Lacing is thick and very sticky.

Huge nose, full of roasted malt notes.  Loads of milk chocolate notes and traces of some dark chocolates in there, as well.  Mild notes of dark coffee presence.  Brown sugar sweetness and hints of toasted caramels.  A very light touch of booze is detected, but not nearly the amount that one would expect far 12.00%abv beer.

Big notes of roasted malts.  Lots of dark roasted coffee flavors, along with some dark chocolate notes that Id say are somewhere in the 80% to 90% range.  Very dark and with a slight touch of bitterness.  Nice touches of toffee and caramels and a hint of brown sugar give this a mild sweetness that balances the dark roastiness out quite nicely.  The finish, while on the dry side, is long and delicious.

This one is very full-bodied, almost qualifying as thick.  Carbonation level is on the high-end of medium.  This provides a great level of creaminess but, unfortunately, retains a slight roughness around the edges.  If they smoothed it out just a touch more, it could be perfect.

The booze, which made a minor apearance in the nose, is nowhere else to be found in this beer.  That, combined with the great flavor, make this a very tasty and drinkable beer.
Worthy of the hype and worth the wait and the effort to get it.

Bottle courtesy of ogivlado who shared it with me and heavy (huge HUGE thanks!) Poured a black body with a brown medium sized head that went away extremely slowly.  The aroma is fine but a bit weak, oily roasty maltiness, coffee and tasty coffee, light alcohol. Extremely nice coffee notes in the taste, possibly the best Ive ever had in a beer.  Damn drinkable, almost no alcohol noticable. Earthy and, very light hop for a second. Not terribly complex but damn effective and likable. Surprised me. A great beer.
Black body, light brown head that lasts till the end with thick lacing. Toasty roasted notes that remind me of bacon to some degree. The alcohol was masked nicely amongst the complex body. Delicious.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2010 bottle, thanks to zdk09, pours like motor oil with no head, very nice and creamy chocolate and vanilla, sourness is much more muted in this one letting the other flavors be more pronounced and nuanced



2008 bottle, really nice deep brown color with malty brown mocha head, aroma has lots of good roasty coffee and chocolate, flavor is slightly sour with medium coffee, roasted nuts and caramel chocolate, lasting viscous finish

wow! This is the best beer i have ever had, hands down. Since drinking this amazing brew, my goal has been to find its equal. I just cant, so Im left with this wonderful beer. . .this thing is a monster. After pouring into a snifter, leaving the yeast in the bottle, you can smell chocolate, toffee, COFFEE, vanilla, caramel, everything. All these flavors are common in imperial stouts but somehow speedway pulls them all together better than any other beer into a glorious symphony for my taste buds. Do whatever you can to get a hold of this beer. I only wish I had the self restraint to age one of these babies for a year or so. . .

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 I have been aging this bottle for at least 4 years. More integrated and more complex. Musty and foggy coffee, vanilla bean and dark chocolate. Beautifully viscous and complex. Long caressing finish similar to affogato, but with a gorgeous finish similar to red wine. Better than old vintages of Stone IRS? Hard to choose.

Bottle thanks to StFun.  Dark brown, creamy but loose tan head.  Lovely hot chocolate aroma, light coffee.  Taste is more roasty, green coffee up front, some roasted malt, chocolate, light grassy bitter.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with a medium head. Flavor is thick and deep, notes of dark chocolates and fresh brewed coffee. Toffee, cognac, alcohol, coco wheats, this beer is insanely deep and welcoming. Full bodied and well done. Top notch.
Over the top delicious.  On tap at the Neighborhood in San Diego.  Coffee.  But for sure the palate is what sets this masterpiece apart.

Bottle. Bishops Arms Järntorget, Porterveckan. Black colour with a brown head. Aroma: roasted, coffee, coffee beans,  some green/vegetal notes, dark berries. Flavor: roasted malt, coffee, dark berries, chocolate, caramel/toffee, some alcohol, some hop bitterness.

Split bottle with Paulp, drank as a celebration beer as the yankees beat the angels in 13 innings. pours straight black with a little ring of mocha on top. smells of dark chocolate and coffee among other things. tastes roasty, chocolatesque with tons of coffee.

Sampled at GABF 2009 - Pours pitch black with a thin mocha head. Notes of dark spicy chocolate, spice, molasses, leather, and salty meats. Heavy bodied, moderate carbonation. Very thick, complex, and delicious.
One of the best beers Ive ever had. I love the stout, but this one gives lots of chocolate and roast coffee notes, with a very smooth finish and likable aftertaste!

750 ml bottle.  Pours blacker than a thousand midnights.  Like a black hole devouring all light that attempts to pass through.  A thin, small but creamy head forms slowly.  At the onset the aroma is so obviously coffee, but then it begins to divide itself into many different coffees.  Dark roast, espresso, even  mild.  Hints of chocolate?  Can the taste ever live up to its bouquet?  As I slowly tip the glass Im at first leery, and fearful of disappointment.  But then Im taken away and actually get chills across my shoulders and back.  All the complexity and wonderful diversity of the aroma is maintained  no  surpassed as I get near giddy at the sheer joy of the experience.  All the while, that wonderful coffee presence at its core.  Soft carbonation, a bit sticky, it leaves me smacking and licking my lips wanting to make sure that I dont miss a single opportunity for pleasure.  I bought this about a month ago, and it states right on the bottle that its best if aged 6 to 24 months.  Bottled on 8/4/2009 would have meant Id have to wait until around March of 2010!  Alas  I wasnt strong enough.  Then again, if waiting meant it could be even better, Im not sure I could have survived the experience.
Aroma: Alot of roasted coffee.  Appearance: Pitch black with a small tan head.  Flavor: Roasted coffee.  Palate:  Medium to full bodied with a sweet lingering finish.  Overall: A killer coffee stout.
