Finish has a hint of smoke in it and is hoppy.  I can see why this is so highly rated.  Great stout, Great beer.

Nice dark colour with a cool tan foamy head. lots of coffee in the aroma and flavour. This beer is big, dark, and heavy. Fantastic tatse that is on the verge of being overpowering. Im enjoying this incredible beer. Now I just have to find a bottle of the barrel aged stuff.

Pours inky black with a stringy brown head, nice oily lacing on the glass.  Nose is heavy coffee and toffee notes, lots of cream.  The flavor is creamy coffee, caramel, oily, sweet, complicated.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Pretty good stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2007 Poured from a bottle.  I dont know who brought it, but damn! thanks!  Appearance is black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is a ton of coffee and roasted malts, some chocolate and some caramel.  Flavor is coffee, grass hops hiding under the coffee.  Dark bitter chocolate, roasted malts.  Palate is dry, full bodied, crisp.  A bit of alcohol.  I thought the Yeti oak aged is better.  Ive had both tonight, too. 8, 5, 9, 4, 17 = 4.3

Ive sampled this many times since and love it!

holy crap, im from the midwest.  this is 100% like expedition stout with a coffee bean kick.  excellent caramel and burnt sugar roast flavor, with some leftover oatmeal and barley sweetness.  damn, i wish i lived closer to san diego!  my vote is that this is a coffee version of expedition.
Draft. Very small head. Creamy mouthfeel. Alcohol is well masked behind roasty malt, chocolate, and a big coffee finish. Not too heavy, but a (more than) full taste.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2005 On draft. Amazing beer. Just about perfect in every way. Creamy head. Black w/ rich brown head. Great aroma and flavor

Bottle. Dark black hue with large creamy light brown head. Aroma was a heavy roasted malt with strong coffee tone. Flavor was as complex and had long finish. Full body with creamy texture with a light alcohol finish. Very good brew.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2005 Bottle, thanks to my secret santa....Pours out a deep black color, nice and thick with little tan head. The aroma is very nice with roasted malts and some coffee. The taste is very complex with noticible coffee, roasted malts and some chocolate. The alcohol content is well masked and not overpowering.

Bottled. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is dark roasted malts, coffe, chocolate, and caramel.  Taste is dry, full, roasted, and good. Mouthfeel is like soft thick velvet. What a wonderfull stout. Thanks to the brewers at Alesmith for making us this one.
Bottle. Strong, peppery liquorice aroma. Very black colour. Small brown head. Coffee aftertaste.

Bottle.. Poured black as night with a small chocolate colored head.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malts and sweet chocolate.  Flavor is a big kick of coffee and roasted malts and a bit of chocolate with a nice bitter and alcohol finish.  Thick smooth mouthfeel with good carbonation.  This is one I wish I had much more of!!

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2009 From a bottle air mailed from San diego. Had high expectations going into this one and they all were exceeded. Im considering moving to San Diego just to be close to this beer. Unbelievably good. Ill leave it to better writers than I to give the details.

Bottle, just before hugging the brewer Tod in Delirium bar in Brussels for making this great stout. Black with a baige head. Roasted tar coffee aroma and a dry roasted light bitter tar taste. Medium to full body and a long warming light alcoholic finish. !!!!!!!!
Too much going on to break it down, great stout... probably the best I have had to date!  Couldnt find the 12% though job well done!

750 ml bottle:  Thick, black body w/ a thin, but lasting mocha brown head.  Chocolate & roasty initial aroma w/ coffee roastiness dominating.  Herbal hop, sweet alcohol, nutty, & toasty malt.  Hints of date dark fruit, and also a bit chalky & minerally in the aroma.  Well balanced for an Imp. stout.  Coffee dominates w/ roasty & toasty flavors with some chocolate malt playing second fiddle.  Caramel below that.  Roasty & chocolate finish, lightly bitter aftertaste w/an herbal hop flavor.  Thick, full bodied, chewy w/ low carbonation and some alcohol warmth.  Very nice Imp. stout!  Complex, chewy, & tasty that should age well.
Black Coloring with Tan Head.  Malty Aroma.  On the Tongue...Chocolate..Coffee...and Some Vanilla. Dry Overall.  Very Tasty and Enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2006 Tap @ Alesmith AND 750 ml bottle at OBriens. Black with the slightest dk brown hue. Good dark tan head w good sticky lace. Aroma is rich, full, dark roasted malt w dark roast coffee. Flavor is extremely full, thick, potent, rich, very dark roast malt w drk, black coffee. A full, dry, espresso like bitterness permeates throughout. This is an amazing stout for it pushes the upper limits of the full bodied category.  As good as it is I find it to be somewhat monotone, lacking in complexity, not having the pizzaz of intrigue, spiciness, perfumy mystery. I suspect the bitterness was knocking my taster off. I do avoid espresso, I think it has to be an acquired taste. 4/1/06 Im taking this up to a 4.2 from 3.8. It clearly deserves it. I didnt think it was as bitter as last year and there was a noticable rich, creamy sweetness. Very nice sipping stout.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2005 Draft @ San Diego Brewing Co.  Strong aroma of cream and mocha.  Thick tan head.  Dark Brown/Black appearance.  Espresso flavored bitterness.  The high alcohol content was evident in the aftertaste.

had a 10oz glass of this at horsebrass pub. nice dark brown pour with a small lacinjg tan head. aroma is roasty, alcohol, coffee.  flavor is chocolatey,a little bit of licorice/anise, roasty, somewhat bitter, and warming alcohol in the end.  very smooth mouthfeel.  a very good imp stout, but i think the 10oz serving size i had was about the most I would want of it.

Thanks to sdbruboy who traded me this fine beer months ago and I am finally getting around to drinking it!  Black color with a thin head.  Very slight whisky aroma with some raw and malted barley peeking in.  Dry malt and vanilla dominate the taste, with some chocolate and coffee showing up as well.  Well, its not the end-all-be-all of stouts, but it is quite tasty.
Got only a tiny zip of this. And what a zip. Strong coffee notes. Nut flavour. Quite bitter finish. In all ways a great stout with the alcohol very well hidden.

Rating #100. Pours (very slowly) a pitch black body with a small, rapidly dissipating tan head. What few bubbles are left of the head cling persistently to the sides of the glass. Aroma as advertised is basically straight coffee, but a bit of chocolate comes through as well. Flavor is comprised of a particular nuttiness, followed by chocolate and some fruit, ending with dry, roasted coffee. Big but very smooth. A very worthwhile milestone brew.

sitting at my favortie brewery(kuhnhenns) with other ratebeerians, wohlfs, scroff, styles, llgrgg, flemdawg and eyedrinkale. thanks go to eyedrinkale for bringing this in. poured black with brown head. aroma licorice, coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts, dark cherries alcohol.. flavor coffee, malts, plums, raisins. this was good, with just a touch of alcohol. good beer.

On tap in Portland.  Nick Nolte on the tap handle?  This is one serious beer.  Black with a brown medium sized head.  The aroma is mostly roasted coffee, coffee and more coffee with some dark chocolate.  Flavour starts with coffee and chocolate and some toastiness and caramel sweetness.   Ends with a slight bitterness and some alcohol.  Smooth texture and definately full bodied.

This is not nearly as complex in its flavors as some Impy Stouts but its a huge stout that explodes with coffee flavor in your mouth.  Just huge and powerfull.  I was blown away by this beer.  Not a very strong aroma or much of a head is the reason I dont give it perfect marks across the board but If I was stranded on an island and could only have one beer...

Pours a jet black color. Sweet roasted malty aroma with a hint of black licorice and alcohol. Very smoothe. Rich and creamy. Coffee and chocolate flavors as well as a little bit of a sweet cherry like flavor. Alcohol is slightly noticabe. Warming effect right away. Very good seems to live up to the hype.

This beer was hard to rate becaue I happened to get a flat bottle.  This is a very dark stout with a small head that goes away quickly.  A little bit of a coffee flavor with almost an olive like after taste.

Well... Thanks to Jim for sharing this. What  a guy. Poured dark and THICK. Brown head, real nice lacing. Aroma is right alnong with an Impy. Stout: Roasted malts, chocolate , caramel, and LOTS of COFFEE! Taste is an expieience. All the typical stouts flavors, + Coffee, coffee and cofffee.  The Huge  12% is there, but never steps foward till you get up and try to walk. This is my new favoorite! Try this guys.

Pours clear brown and settles black and seems that it will have no head, but it shortly produces a series of tiny bubbles which build a medium sized tan head.  Aroma can be sensed from several feet away.  It is chocolate and coffee up front and hides a fruityness behind the robust malts.  The first sensation is how smooth and creamy it is, very full feel.  The coffee flavor is both roasted and bitter and is followed up with a slight smokeyness.  This beer has a great reputation and didnt let me down.  Such a great presense, this beer carries its weight and is a must have for anyone who enjoys good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2006  Great looking bottle which provides a good presentation.  Aromas with hints of molasses, cherry, currant, vanilla, coffee, espresso, chocolate, roasted nuts, caramel and toffee are most impressive.  Did I say there was coffee in this beer?  Good, because it is used brilliantly.  Taste was very smooth for its strength with a terrific salty finish.  Palate is excellent with coffee, chocolate, cherry and alcohol in the mouthfeel.  Quite smooth, not overbearing with the alcohol.  Drinkability is good for 12% alcohol and all that is in this beer.  Just a magnificent brew overall.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2007 This is a strong beer, a real winner if you like power stouts.  No hops to speak of, lots of malt, dark roast, alcohol is quite apparent, not hidden at all.

What a great beer.  I took it over to a friends  new house a a housewarming gift.  He and I opened it up as we were watching Rugby.  England vs. France if your interested.  Anyways a great pour of blackish liquid into actual English pint glasses (supposedly smuggled from an English pub by my friend).  A great coffee mocha taste.  As we finished the bottle he looked at me and asked if I had more.  I saddenly responded no and said I would try to procur more.

Bottle. No head, sparse lacing, fine sized bubbles, opaque and a reddish brown hue. Malty and coffee aroma. Flavor was malty, chocolate, coffee, roasty and a hint of caramel. Smooth palate. An exceptional and very quaffable Imperial Stout and worthy of a try. Would not mind having this one again.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2010 Poured black with a medium sized brown head.  Sweet aroma of roasted malt, coffe, and burnt tobacco.  Sweet black coffee flavor with a long bitter finish.  Full bodied. Old rating of 9/5/9/4/18 4.5
Big roast and coffee on the nose and mouth, this beer poured a very opaque color w/ deep brown head and good lacing.  The mouthfeel was creamy and well-rounded w/ full body.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2005 Black as night, pruney as Grammas , well its more pruney than coffee thats for sure. All that roastiness and coffee cant seem to hide the overpowering alcohol. Sorry, I really wanted to like this beer but its WAY overated IMO. gave me one hell of a buzz though........

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2005 The aroma is definitely fresh roasted coffee.  Color is black as tar, head is dark brown but not as big as Id expect.  Heavy coffee notes in the flavor, but a good amount of sweetness as well.  Probably the best Imperial Stout Ive ever had, this one is truly outstanding.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2009 750 ml bottle - re rate - Pours a totally opaque black color with smallish light tan head. Aroma is chocolatey, with lightly roasted coffee, vanilla, rum, butterscotch, hint of cherry and grains of paradise. Flavor is malty, fair amount of bitter and dry roasted malts, notable roasted coffee notes, touch of oak and vanilla, hint of cherry towards the finish. Fairly dry finish, with a pretty firm bitterness. Very good, but not truly stellar in my opinion.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2005 Initial rating: 1/29/2005.

GABF 2004.  Upon reflection, I wish that I would have spent more time at the Alesmith table.  This is a great stout, silky chocolate roast that seems like a Dove bar has melted in your mouth and transmogrified into glorious beer.  Full bodied.  The finish lingers nicely, with a touch of roasty driness.  Fresh hops undergird the chocolate, and some faint dusty plum flavors seep in occasionally too.  Looks exactly like an imperial stout should look, so no lost marks there.  Beautiful.  4.3.

Re-Rate: 750 bottle into tulip glass.  4/26/05.
This is still a great beer, but this bottled version is much more claustrophobic, the roast and coffee dominating and the mouthfeel staying sticky and chewy, almost too full.  There are also notes of dry tar in the finish that are less than enjoyable.  Not as great as I remembered it from GABF, so Ive knocked it down a couple of tenths.
it is the best. its like chocolate fudge and dark chocolate covered expresso beans. if you havent had it yet, you really need to.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2005 Rating #200!

Poured jet black with a medium fizzy brown head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma is delicious sweet chocolate and coffee.  Taste is mostly sweet, dominated by coffee with a hint of chocolate, with a roasted coffee bitterness.  The finish is bitter but not overwhelmingly so.  Theres an alcohol burn but the alcohol itself is nearly undetectable in the flavor, making this almost a little too drinkable. Rather impressive considering its 12%.  Not fruity at all.  Overall this is primarily a coffee stout, just turned up a notch.  The palate is nice and thick... not Kalamazoo thick, but thick enough.  Although Im not much of an Imperial Stout person (though I have yet to try the Dark Lord in my cellar), I find this beer to be very agreeable.  I could have this every day, but its too expensive for that, so Ill settle for once in a while.
UPDATE:  Wanna try something thats really bad for you?  Try adding a scoop of coffee ice cream for a Speedway Float!

This is about as near as perfect a beer as I can imagine.  As far as comparing it to other Imperial Stouts its tops on my list.  Tons of dark burtness that is offset perfectly by the coffee beans.  It wasnt overly fruity like the dark lord and has just amazing flavors.  I could sip on this beer every night.  I cant even imagine how well its going to age.  This truly is liquid gold in the bottle.  It deserves every accolade it gets.  My new number 1 favorite.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2009 Thick dark black color, small but distict head, rich chocolate, malt and coffee aroma, The taste is big and full, chocolate and coffee smooth a texture as Ive ever experienced,smooth as silk, alcohol is slightly evident in aftertaste. that velvet smoothness combined with that wonderful full taste becomes more impressive with each sip, a nearly flawless brew. This survived a rough trip to Wisconsin,I can only imagine how good its tastes fresh from the San Diego brewery.

Well, I have been sitting on this guy long enough, I figured it was time to give it a shot. Heck, AFC-NFC championship weekend only comes around once a year. I popped the bottle and poured her in my tulip glass. This beer pours jet black with a fluffy tan head. Sweet chocolate, coffee aroma filled my kitchen as i poured this bad boy.  Sat down on my couch and sipped her slowly. Flavor is big chocolate and coffee, with a long lasting bitter hop taste. Hop kick reminds me of some Storm King. But this beauty is more thick and syrupy than Storm King. So, i finish my first glass, the rest is on the kitchen counter. My dumbass cat decides to sit on me when i have an empty glass. I hate to push her off me when she plunks down on me like that, but damn, i had some Speedway Stout on the kitchen counter. So she got the boot fairly quickly. Anyway, this beer gives Storm King a run for being the best Impy stout out there, IMO. Its more thick, so it may be better, but Storm King is more affordable. eh--- they are both fantastic.

I LOVE CHOCOLATE AND I LOVE BEER, 
THIS BEER GAVE ME BOTH,COLOR WAS JET BLACK , FLAVOR WAS A TOASTY MALT, AND HAD A VERY 
NICE KICK TO IT. TONY T I THANK YOU FOR THIS GIFT FROM THEIR BREWERY.

Bottle.  Many thanks to Marc for trading thisone!  Black body.  Brown head.  Good lace.  Nose of drop (some kind of candy).  Moderately bitter,moderately sweet initial flavour.  Heavlily bitter initial flavour, lightly sweet very long finish.  Heavily bodied.   Lively carboantion.  very sirupy and complex (spices burning to my tongue for minutes) mouthfeel. Although Im not into stouts, I defenitely appreciated this new experience.

01.15.05  Thanks to Dorwart for the sharing!  The usual descriptors for this brew: black as can be, thick, oily, coating, tar-like, pitch.  Despite this, there is ample brown head that lingers.  Amazing burnt and roasty aromas that every other Imperial dreams of.  In fact, the aromas and flavors seem to meld as one, a character of this beer that makes it so intriguing to me.  Licorice notes, caramelized maple sugar, plenty of hops shine throughout.  Retronasal alcohol presence, long lingering roast and palate coating goodness complete the cycle.  Wonderful stuff!

This was great.  Poured off the tap dark chocolate color with nice caramel colored head.  coffee, chocolate, caramel, malt, hops in this toasty flavor that doesnt seem to quit.  I normally have a hard time drinking stouts, but this one was easy to drink.  It was a comfort beer, much like comfort food, it makes you feel all warm and fuzzy while you keep the flavor on your tongue.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2005 Bottle. Deep black, tan head, looks fantastic. Coffee aroma, malt, powerful and pleasant, just blown away by the strength of the aroma. TONS of coffee flavor, even the aroma didnt prepare me for it. Also dark chocolate malt, alcohol bite, earthy, toasty, and the hops come through in the finish which really blew me away -- hops cant stand out in a beer this strong. Thick mouthfeel, coats my mouth with all of its flavors. Probably the boldest and strongest flavor that Ive ever experienced in a beer, Ive had this a few times before and it still blows me away every time.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2006 Aged 1 year.  Deep brown in color with a nice tan head. Nice perfect carbonation.  Roasty flavor with some coffee notes.  Nice alcohol burn.  Smooth and creamy. Full bodied.  Well balanced. Very malty beer.  Nice beer.

THANK YOU TCHROME for this bottle! Aged 1 year give or take. Super deep brown, with a tan head, and rather perfectly carbonated for somethoing of this ilk. Aroma of carmel roastyness and semi-sweet chocolate. Alcohol is there but has taken on the character of the malt so as not to distinguish itself. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Very malty woith a shot of bitterness at the end. There is a noticable alcohol burn there going down, but the flavor again is masked by the malt. Notes of vanilla are present as well. I do not notice te coffee in this at all, which probably faded with age. A true gem of a brew, for sure!
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
Pours a jet black. Small offwhite head. Aroma of dominant coffee, a little licorice and cream(lactose) to it.
Flavor is very smooth, choclate, with lots of coffee/espresso, and roasted malt. Very Nice, much thanks to IMTheOptimator for this bottle!

2004 served in a Pint Glass 55f
Pours dark almost black with a tight rich brown head
Coffee and Roasted grains are riding shotgun, Alcohol and crystal malt
Are in the back seat, the hops are dead and in the trunk. A great imperial stout and 
Quite drinkable for its high strength
Now I know what all the fuss is about and I cant wait to try the barrel aged

bottle shared with my brother DYCSoccer17 that he received from his Secret Santa.  Thanks to both!  Opaque oil black pour with a medium creamy brown head.  Sweet start, with some vineous tones.  The middle is alcohol laden and the most upleasant part of this tasting.  The finish is a medley of flavors...dark chocolate, roasted malt, strong burnt coffee.  Hops are also present for the finishing foray.  This is a definite treat, and the most impressive feature it the long long lasting taste.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2011 Bottle thanks to beerlimey...my 04 SS.  Chocolate milk aromas with some mild roastiness as well as some vinous notes.   Opaque black with drown head that is rather quickly dissipating.  Boozy in the middle.  Start is sweet and vinous.  Middle is an astringent alcohol flavor.  Finishes rather roasted and rather hoppy as well with a long, drawn out coffee flavor.  This flavor just does not resolve.   The middle astringency and ethanol presence takes away from this beer.  Its lingering flavor is an added bonus, though.  (8/5/7/3/15)----- aroma on this is a little faint with some hints of coffee, and some metallic undertones.  Light sweetness.  Gorgeous beer.  Jet black body with light brown head that is large.  Great lacing.  Starts with light, sweet chocolate hints, before this becomes a little coffee-like.  Not huge like Peche Mortel, but still there.  Moderate roastiness later on.  Amazing body and mouthfeel.  Great balance.  This beer is world-class for a reason.  Cant understand why I initially rated it so low.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2005 Lots of coffee taste. Pours out very dark. Hints of nuts and chocolate in the aftertaste.  A very good stout.  However, it should not be in the top ten. It is overpriced, rare, and is in no way better than Stones russian imperial. This beer is good but very overrated. I am glad that I split this bottle with a friend and did not have to absorb the ridiculous cost of the beer.

Deep, dark brown (almost black) with a small tan head. Huge aroma of roast coffee and dark chocolate. Complex palate-ripping flavour with notes of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, licorice & bourbon. Easily one of the highlights of the 7+ hour, 40+ beer marathon tasting session at Dougs.  [Toronto Christmas Party 04]

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2006 Finally, a proper rating.  My first sample was a very small one, this one was split with Hogtown Harry, Blankboy, Jerc, and GregClow.  Pitch black, murky brown head.  Nice coffee, alcohol, hops in mild aroma.  Amazing taste - so thick yet carbonated, tons of chocolate and hops - very bitter.  Had it just after a founders and this one was definitely more of a sipper - and having them back to back, I like this better.  What a stout, if the aroma was a little bit better, this would go through the roof...Original 9/4/8/4/18

Bottle, Dougs Gathering (sounds ominous, doesnt it??  "..the gathering of Doug....), 2004.  Pitch black colour, very little head.  Chocolate and coffee in aroma.  Velvety smooth mouthfeel with lots of chocolate and roasted coffee flavours and nice bitterness to it.  Hides the alcohol well.  A very good beer tasted near the end of a long sampling night.  I just didnt think it had the complexity of some others Ive rated even higher, but that takes nothing away from a very solid beer.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2010 Highly overrated.  This was big stuff with a oily pour and totally black body.  Bitter chocolate and coffee flavor with a touch of alcohol.  I have been dissapointed with just about every Alesmith product I have tried so far.  Not because they are bad, but because they have all been so hyped and I cant figure out why.7/3/6/3/16

I have since come around regarding Alesmith. With some age (to mellow the alcohol) I can really appreciate the craftsmanship of their beers. I had a speedway stout with 2+ years of age and it was really exceptional.
Dark stout with no head. Deep toffee coffee aroma with light hops. Sweet sweet coffee with vodka alcohol with roasted bitter chocolate. Rich oily mouthfeel with creamy body. Nov. 28 2004 at MartinT.

Deep and dark, brown head. Nice full aroma, chocolate, roast, coffee, some vanilla, and even some vinous qualities. Roasty flavor with some big time coffee bitterness, it kind of takes away from the other elements I picked up in the aroma. Big palate but very dry, too dry. Alcohol is hidden well considering its strength. Very good but relies too heavily on the coffee. Thanks rudolf.

Bottle pored black,jet black!! with a creamy chocolate head that ws gone FAST!.
Strong aroma of roast chocolate and alcohol.AWSOME flavor of roast campfire and alcohol, Alcohol is strong but not overpowering,but when you take that first sip you will say WOW!!
Definatly a sipping beer !! you wont be chuging this one!!

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2005 Re-rate @ Liars Club (I was.. uh. unable to really taste this in Toronto)  Huge alcohol, plum, toffee, oil, fish, soy/salt, coffee, dark chocolate flavor.  Bitter coffee/chocolate/toffee finish.  Nose is coffee, alcohol, toffee, soy.  This one goes to 11.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2008 January 2008. Bottle shared by HogTownHarry. Silver foil in a green bottle. 2005 or 2006 Vintage? Black body with a small khaki head. (3+) Sweet rich malt aroma, mild hints of roast and coffee/ (7+) Flavour is surprisingly sweet and rich with malt and notes of caramel and cocoa. Coffee and roast have receded significantly and left a glorious remainder in my opinion. Light muted coffee notes lingers in the aftertaste. Smooth medium to full bodied palate. (4+) Wow. So glad to try this one again, thanks Harry! 7+/3+/9/4+/17 - 4.2

December 2004. Bottle. Black body without much head, a swirl of the of the glass rouses a small chocolate coloured head from its slumber like a lethargic teenager. Nice mild roastiness and a bit of chocolate in the aroma. Flavour is a huge bitter coffee kick in the pants up front. Some malt in the middle is the only thing to snake past the coffee and eventually gives way to more coffee bitterness in the finish. Very warming, leaves the mouth and palate feeling dry like you have just used mouth wash - wow. Drastically thinner body than I anticipated and frankly require of a stout of this magnitude. Alcohol is remarkably restrained aside from the warming effects. Nice in its own way but if I wanted coffee... Thanks for the chance to try this one rudolf. 7/3/6/3/16 - 3.5

A coffee brewed with beer and some spices and nicely carbonated. Thick and medium mouthfeel. Strong overwhelming coffee taste more than anything. Caffeine and alcohol kick certainly puts one on a rush. Ive had more enjoyable of the style.

No head, very dark opaque body.  Alcool, vineous, coffee, caramel and sweetness in aroma.  Roasted flavor as well as coffee sweetness as initial flavor followed by roasted bitterness of average long duration.  Mouthfull, full bodied with an alcoholic finish.  Sampled at MartinTs place with other RateBeerians for the "Montreals Voyager Par Les Papilles first tasting session".

ahhhh - this is great. Pitch black, small frothy head. Toasted coffee bean and also licorice nose. Roasted coffe, licorice and dark chocolate taste, peppery at the end. Long lasting bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2006 On tap. I ordered this and the tap kicked. Luckilly the bar keep gave me the 1/2 glass for free! Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized brown head. Nice chocoalte and subtle coffee aroma and tastes. Creamy and smooth body. 12% well hidden. Very good and top notch.

Pours a black color with brown hues. Appealing aroma of coffee, roasted malt and alcohol. Amazing and very long lasting flavor of coffee, roasted malt, alcohol and chocolate. Full body, soft carbonation. Wow, that was every thing I tought it would be, luscious, sweet and roasty.

Pours black with little head that is gone quickly. Big chocolate aroma with hops barely detectable and just a faint coffe smell. Smooth body mostly chocolate with hints of coffee. I am not getting all the coffee mentioned everywhere which for me is a good thing. (I am not a fan of coffee) Overall very nice stout and I am not a really big fan of stouts.

750ML bottle, with notes on the label about being brewed with ryan bros coffee. This is as dark as it gets, definatly has the old motor oil look to it. Not much carbonation or head to be seen, even with an aggresive pour that was trying to wake it up. The aroma coming of this beer is nice with coffee, chocolate and dark fruits being at that front and notes of slight sweetness and alcohol are present as well. The taste starts with a strong coffee and alcohol flavor that gives way to smooth chocolate and nutty tones. Very rich and complex in flavor with more flavors standing out as it warms. At 12% it hides mopst the alcohol well, you can definatly taste it but it adds to the overall flavor. The mouthfeel is a medium body, definatly thinner than I would expect from such a large imperial stout. Very drinkable considering the alcohol the is present. A excellent all around brew that has a great complex taste. I will lay my other bottle down for atleast a year before trying it to see what other flavors may emerge.

This was a highly anticipated beer for me. However I was dissapointed. Poured dark black with no head and a faint ring of dark brown indicating what the head color should be. Had a strong aroma full of fig, chocolate and coffee, but fig was the most overpowering. The taste was alcoholic and sweet. Had a mild bitter chocolate taste accompanied by some mildly bitter coffee. The warmth from the high alcohol is definately present and noticable. Not bad, but certainly not the beer the ratings indicate.

Roasted smokey nose with hints of licorice, opaque jet black, creamy tan head. Im in love and I havent even tasted it. Sweet raisin tastes amidst a heavy roasted malt bady with a dry coffee bitter on the teeth.  Ends with a bittersweet chocolate bitter (70% or more). Creamy, silky texture is the real highlight of this beer. Great balance and just an incredible beer. This is a well-deserved top 50 beer!

Scary deep dark color, totally knock you on your ass flavor.  Keeps you up for hours.  Chocolatey coffee taste with that reliable Stout olive afterglow.  Scored it at the Encinitas, CA BevMo.  Love those dudes at BevMo.

Bottle @ the VA/DC/MD gathering: An excellent beer, no doubt about it.  Dark black in color with a brown head that diminishes.  Chocolate, coffee, roasted coffee, roasted malts, caramel, with a velvet mouthfeel and excellent carbonation.  Does not seem overwhelming.  Will rate a full bottle of this soon once I trade.

All Im really going to say about this beer is that it deserves the high rating it gets, it is one of the best beers out there.  Good coffee and stout flavors with a high alcohol content.  Truly one of the best.

wow....what a great beer; thank you to silphium for making this tasting experience possible; black in appearance with diminishing brown head; very strong chocolate aroma, with hints of black coffee....sweet chocolate flavors upon initial consumption, then an abundance of roasted coffee as an aftertaste...a wonderful and complex flavor;  everyone should drink this beer..again, and again, and again!
UPDATED: JAN 30, 2005 bottle, black in color, deeply opaque, brown head that dissolves quickly, very strong coffee aroma with big alcohol taste. hops at end,  a little too strong for my liking

Bottle.  Wow.  An all-inclusive Imperial Stout!!  Very nicely done.  Big rich aroma.  Almost winelike with its vinous notes.  Tannish head.  Moderate lacing.  Aroma is big, fat, roasted grains.  Lots of Coffee.  Big coffee flavors.  Damn nice!!!   Cant say much more than what has been said already.  Kudos!!!!

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2006 Appearcance: Dark as sin and twice as thick. Very little melted milk chocolate head that tantalizes you of the richness to come. 
Aroma: Coffee aroma even a coffee hater would love, followed by some premium dry dark chocolate. A hint of carmel?
Palate/Mouthfeel: Similar to the appearance, thick, full, velvety, almost like a melted milkshake. Its pure bliss.
Flavor: Starts with a kick of VERY fine coffee quickly followed by a smooth wave of delicious dark chocolate. Undertones of a slice of hop, a touch of carmel, and some delicious roasted malt. Something else, a touch of brown sugar? Maybe nutmeg? Delicious.
This is the king of beers, perhaps a little too rich to drink every day, but this an experience in and of itself. 
The flavor so perfect, smooth and inviting mixes beatufully with the rich and velvety mouthfeel  to create a truely masterful beer. Ive tried all the greats folks, and this one has no equal.
Cant wait to try the barrell aged!
9/28/04: Bottle. Black patent, chocolate malt aroma.  Black-brown body with a medium tan head.  Chocolate malt flavor with a medium hop bitterness.  Light lactic acid mouth-feel.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 A most excellent beer.  Pours very dark (almost black) with deep brown hints at the edges.  The aroma hits you hard with coffee and chocolate but its more complicated than that.  This is a great beer for dessert.  Great flavors of chocolate and coffee with a bit of alcohol underneith and a variety of other flavors mixed in.  Just a lot of fun to drink and try and pick out all the flavors running thru this beer.  Yum.
What can I say that hasnt been said... This beer is very good, but it isnt all that.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Tried a few times since the last rating. An absolutely solid brew, but each time I had it, it seemed to have a little less coffee. Still, a classic. Shared this in my beer tasting class. Glad I did as a little bit goes a long ways. Pours with no head at all. The body is a very viscous black that cling to the glass liek used oil. The aroms are rich with anise, grape juice and brown sugar. As it warms a little bit, it also has ome mushrooms. the mouthfeel is very thick. There are many flavors to pull out here. Has coffee and brown sugar. Also hints of vanilla and oranges add to the sweetness. The finish is dry like a cognac. Also has a warming alcohol presence. Very nicely done. It is big but not overwhelming.

#300  750Bottle Pours a deep black with a very nice DARK tan head that leaves thick heavy lacing.  Aroma is a terrific blend of Coffee, molassas, chocolate and dark roasted malts. Flavor is mostly of the Espresso, and then less of the cohocolate.  Very smokey as well and a noticeable alcohol taste.  Feel is very smooth and silky. Carbonation is quite lively, but fine and soft at the same time.  Yes, quite strong dark smoke and coffee flavors as I continue to sip it.  Aftertaste is more mellow than I expected and short lived.
A Brew worthy of the top 10 and a great milestone rating.   Thanks to Footbalm for this one.

750 ml bottle, 2003.  Viscous black, opaque, tiny dark foamy head which disintigrates quickly into a small lasting ring.  Surprisingly subltle, mellow nose containing milk chocolate, coffee and brandy.  Mouthfeel gorgeously decadent at first, but underdone somewhat later by the too-sharp coffee bitterness, aided and abetted by tobacco ash and woodsmoke.  Alcohol fairly strongly present throughout, mostly welcome.  A light creme brulee character at the beginning is the only mediation of the tarry heaviness...I was a bit underwhelmed by this on the whole; its quality stuff, but I definitely think it could stand some aging to bring the mellower flavors to the fore.  As it is, a slightly above average example of the style as far as Im concerned.

Pitch black in colour, completely opaque with no head at all. Some brown bubbles-but thats all. Aroma of coffee, caramel, toffee, roasted malt, chocolate (66% cacao), figs and some nuts. A great aroma, but thats what Id expect! Full-bodied; Sweet full chocolate flavour with some pungent coffee bitterness. Amazing how it rolls right off though-no offensive flavours at all!! Sweet, then alcoholic then roasty. A great aftertaste with no bad tastes. Overall, truly a great top 50! Well worth the long wait. I had wanted to drink this on graduation night from college, but it waited until now! An imperial stout that everyone should try-people could learn a few lessons about how a beer should be crafted! I sampled this 75 cL bottle recieved from rodolito (Dave) on 09-October-2004 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia with my good friend Jon[R888710]. Thanks again Dave for this rare beer on the east coast!

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 Dec. 10th 2006 Re-rate of a 2006 Bottle.

Still a beautiful beer, but it definitely seems to have lost some of its grandness to my more educated palate. It was newer so hotter than I recalled which does detract a bit and seems to thin the brew. The coffee asspect is still large and well integrated, but it seems like the more beery stout asspects such as chocolate, roasted/burnt notes are less pronounced than I recall and overall it seems to lack the range of flavor of the first batches I had. Bottle. This is the eptiome of a stout in apperance. Rich black color with a frothed dark brown head. VERY strong coffee aroma. This looks like an esspresso writ large and the taste is similar.

Original rating was a 4.8

Alcohol is present, but well balanced. Very satisfying drink. Excellent mouth feel. Every bit as good, maybe better, than youve heard.

I love this beer.  As black as a blackhole with a muddy tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and roasted barley.  Silky mouth feel but full body.  Taste of coffee with cream and choclate.  Even starbucks couldnt create something taster.  With a warm alchol finish this is one of the best stouts of all times.

Finally got my hands on some. I love it when a beer lives up to its hype. Gorgeous looking beer. Totally black with
a medium sized tan head. Unbelievable
aroma of roasted chocolate malts, coffee and malt vinegar. Flavor of coffee
starts off strong, hides for a while then comes right back on the finish. Lots of 
chocolate and roasted malt flavors in between. Luscius mouthfeel. Silky smooth texture. Seems to attack all taste buds at once. I cant believe there is 12%
in here. Awesome!

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2006 Bottle:   Great aroma.  Nice blend of chocolate malt, coffee, cream, licorice, and slight alcohol.    Pours a very dark brown, virtually black, with a nice tan head with fair retention.  Great flavor as well.  Very nice strong coffee presence with some sweetness.  Roastiness and chocolate  make their presence known rather nicely, but the coffee is the dominant flavor.  Not a real strong alchohol presence in the finish that Ive had in other imperial stouts, which I strongly prefer.  Dont get me wrong, it is there, but never overpowering.   A very nice combination and balance of the flavors.    Very impressive.  There have been plenty of beers that Ive had that I dont feel totally live up to their reputation on this site, but this definitely does.  Have to get my hands on the Barrel Aged.

Pitch black with some mahogany/ebony dark brown tones. Bubbles are sandy colored, medium-large and refract light like diamonds. Smell is rich and strong of molasses, dark honey, coffee and chocolate malts. Taste is big but not obtrusive. One of the most evenly packed huge palates Ive ever encountered. Massive chocolate, maple, dark roasted espresso beans, sweetened condensed milk, pipe tobacco smokiness and alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium-thick. Aftertaste burns a little from the alcohol but still exudes an even balance of sweet chcolate malt and roasted hops. This one is truly a rare treat. Thanks so much to Jeremy for sharing this wonderful bottle with me. It had been originally queued for his graduation but I think it fit well on a fantastic night on the Eastern Shore of Virginia!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2009 i FINALLY get to try this....
this i.s. filled my pint glass with no head at first,but foamed up a little brown head that soon vanished..BLACK as halloween with no light  to be seen at all.nice thick and creamy dark brown head that leaves huge webbing on the glass.the smell gave off hints of coffe/nuts.
now for the taste.......
WOW!
LOADS OF COFFE all the way through this one ending with a bit of alcohol for that imperial bite.although it does not taste anywhere near 12%.
this is like redhook double black stouts older,bigger,and better brother.
overall i must say this beer kicks ass!
i even let my lady have a sip,she is not the biggest beer fan,but likes some porters and stouts.she says "this is the best beer you have ever let me try"
if you get your hands on a bottle.save it for something special!!!!񢉔 BOTTLE RE-RATED ON 11-20-2006.OPENED IN CELEBRATION OF THE END OF COTTON SEASON)nice black body with brown highlights around the rim.small head that faded fast.coffee is a little less subtle on this 2 year old version than in a fresh batch.alcohol is still pretty upfront and i expected it to be calmed a bit.chocolate really stands out now as does dark fruits and fudge.body is very smooth and silky.well balanced and awsome overall.񢉕 BOTTLE OPENED ON 12-18-07)black as night with a brown head that tired to form but didnt.nice balanced aroma of fudge,chocolate,coffee,and just a hint of alcohol.flavor is much of the same with the velvety smooth texture they talk about in the description.this is simply awesome with 2 years on it. (RE-RATE ON 5-5-08 OF A 2004 BOTTLE)black body with no head.the aroma is out of this world.chocolate,coffee,cherry,roasted malt.i could smell this for hours.the flavor is not quite as good.the mouthfeel is a bit thin and watery,but you still pick up all the characteristics of the aroma.this may be a bit past its prime.
re-rate.january batch was infected.this beer does not deserve a perfect rating now.

Pours a jet black beer with small beige head.  Smells of deep chocolate, hops, and alcohol.  Thick mouthfeel, tastes like black patent malt and unset chocolate pudding.  Awesome beer, best Imperial Stout Ive had.

GABF: 2004
Others have already said it better than I could.
My 2 cents...best damn Impy Stout Ill probably ever taste in this lifetime.

Best regards,
Bill

Sampled at the RBESP 2004 alongside the barrel-aged version
Chocolate, wood and raisin nose.
Black, succulent brown head.
Good chocolate flavors, also  licorice and salt.
Relatively light body to my surprise, creamy mouthfeel.
Very slight burn on the back edge.

Solid black color. Dense tan head. Strong aromas of coffee, toffee, cocoa, plum. Oh so smooth for such a huge beer. I think the previous reviewer got it right with the milk chocolate/tobacco/ coffee combo. A truely exceptional stout.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2007 This beer was unbelieveable. 

It poured pitch black. The head: light tan in size with a mostly diminishing head that left some lacing.

Nice nose. Molasses and lots of toffee and coffee but mostly a sweet milk chocolate covered pot leaf that I loved.

Starts out with vanilla, toffee and tons of cocoa. The mid-palate was full of chocolate but not the usual chocolate but more of a melted milk chocolate. The finish was amazing and hard to put into words. It was a tobacco laden coffee bean dripping with chocolate and it was very lingering. The coffee beans served there purpose, molding all the flavors together and eliminating a lot of the alcohol flavors. This was a 12% beer and I could barely taste any alcohol and I think it was the coffee beans than eliminated it. 

This beer was amazing and the past few days I have been sitting in the middle of class and I could swear that I tasted the tobacco laden coffee bean dripping with chocolate finish.

Rerate:  Ive had several bottles since my first review above and each bottle still blows me away.  One of the best Imperial Stouts in the world.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2005 Fantastic!  Super black oily looking with a cocoa head that oddly seemed to get larger, and tan oily lacing.  Coffee, chocolate aroma - Im not sure if it was complex, but there was plenty to smell here - intensity.  Plenty of roasty chocolate malts, dark fruit/prune juice - big flavors balanced well with generoius hops.  Excellent palate - silky smooth, sometimes vinous, sometimes thick soft malty.  I think Ill try this again - I was maybe hoping for a little more complexity.
I love this beer.  Its two of my favorite things: beer and coffee.  Its like mixing the two just right.  Black as night and dark as my soul.  Love it.

(Thank you to DarkElf for the hook up!)  Pitch black pour that initially is flat, but then....the head starts rising and forming.  Eventually, the mocha colored settled out into the thickest, densest head Ive ever seen.  It would win my "most resembling a milkshake" award.  The aromas were of chocolate and roasty malt when I first poured this, but as it warmed, the coffee started to emerge.  It was never overpowering enough to make me think of this as a coffee beer, but like it was just touched off with a little bit.  A very nice accent to this monster Imperial.  Silky smooth body.  Lots of cocoa, crystal malt and bitter hops fill out the palate.  Dry finish, with notes of the coffee and hops.  Damn good.

Finally, it made its way to good ol Ohio.  I was afraid I was going to have to visit California for this one.  Anyhow, as for the beer.  The smell reminds me of the WWS,  but slightlyless sweet.  There is the obvious.  Coffee, roasted malt, alcohol and a whalop of molasses rounds this out.  There is quite a chalky feel to it at first, mainly from the alcohol.  But then there a whole lotta malt, a whole lotta coffee and a whole lotta roasted feel.  Good beer, but not the greatest.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2005 My second visit to this fine beer, which I believe is the same vintage 5 months later, was somewhat more fruitful a venture... Literally, the strong coffee flavor were backed up magnificently by a fruity raisin and dark chocolate backbone. Much more complex and even more drinkable. My compliments to this beer still stand. My criticism does not.

Original: So here it is, direct from Hi-Times wines mail order, the legendary Speedway Stout. Though, I find myself questioning why its so  legendary. Yes, its huge. Yes, its loaded with coffee and good old fashioned imperial stout flavor. Its quality sipper for sure--big, warming, well-covered alcohol, silky smooth mouthfeel, well-balanced--an expertly brewed beer. Trouble is: theres just not much going aside from coffee and a little bit more coffee. Its an excellent beer but it leaves me in a bit of a bind to rate it as its a bit--for the lack of a better word--boring. Ok. Simple might be better. Really, how much you like this beer is gonna depend on how much you like coffee. I like coffee a lot but I like beer better. High marks but not top marks. Good day.

My first rating in quite some time, and well worth the wait.  Appearance: darker n a black steers tookus on a moonless prairie night.  Head: frothy brown, the color I associate with Bergmans -Passion of Anna-.  Oh, and is it frothy.  Silken.  So its action is beautiful.  Flavor: like a rich cup of coffee, stronger than normal coffee taste, cappuccino maybe.   Palate: O the palate.  Smoother n rose petals flowing from Cindy Crawfords posterior.  Overall impression: this is some top-notch shit.  To paraphrase a prolific internet movie commentator: Every beerfully literate person should experience this.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2004 Thick dark black brown liquid with a deep medium brown thick head.  Nose is chocolately and hints of a deep roasted malt.  Flavor is a warming mix of roast coffe and dark chocolate.  Bearutiful finish.  Thick satiny body.  A stunning beer.

many, many thanks to mwsf for cracking a bottle of this. thick and black and oily. huge coffee aroma with some licorice allsorts, whipped cream and chocolate. lovely rich mouthfeel, plenty of coffee but also a light hint of vanilla custard. long finish, feels like i can still taste it now

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2006 Pours thick and rich with a dark brown beautiful head that looks like melted chocolate ice cream...smells very malty, chocolate, coffee, and a hint of alcohol...as it warmed the alcohol seemed much more apparent...rich roasted flavor...coffee, malt, caramel, alcohol...finish is hoppy, coffee, and alcohol...I have to agree with Blank...the alcohol was too much...if it was maybe 9% or 10% or if it had a little more coffee it would be utter perfection...the alcohol is the demise of it...fantastic none the less, but I cant help but realize what a fat alcoholic bastard I would be if it was a little less overpowering on the back and sides of my tongue...still this is goddamned good!!!

#500----Finally! Speedway Stout. I drank this with a friend at one of my bonfires. We were both waiting a long time to open this one. It poured a dark and rich brown that was almost black. It looked like used motor oil. Very small and thin tan head that didnt last. Huge roasted coffee aroma. Full and thick mouthfeel. Coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, dark fruits, roasted nuts, vanilla, and hops on the tongue. Long dry bitter finish. Was this beer worth the wait? Yes. This is an awesome beer.

#1000
As a tiny little tear rolls down my cheek and I reflect on the previous 999 beers, the caffiene kicks in and I am jolted to lucidity by the utter wonderfulness of this beer. The head was practically purple and faded fast. Nice coffee arome- to be expected with all the damn coffee in it. Very smooth, hides the 12% quite well. But damn if I am not gonna have to take an Ambien tonight to get to sleep with all this damn caffiene running through my blood now.
Heres to another 1000. Cheers.

Bottle. Black beer with a medium beige head. Huge roasty aroma with coffee and chocolate. Thick, rich malt flavor that also includes: big coffee, huge chocolate, a touch of fruitiness, and a slight roastiness. Smooth creamy mouthfeel. Very easy to drink depsite alcohol content.

Thanks to CaptainCougar and DrunkAsASkunk for making trades of this!
This pours black, pure and simple. Not much head as expected, huge aroma however.
Coffee, chocolate and toasted marshmallows. Smooth coating palate is delivered to the tongue. Dark roast malts provide the bitter dryness and the caramel sweetness counters it to make a beautifully balanced brew. A tad bit smoother than the Barrel aged version, although it too will have those who prefer that touch. A really great over the top Imperial Russian Stout.

Bottled. 
Near black, thin tan head. Big aroma from cocoa, licorice and vanilla. Warming flavour with notes of vanilla, chocolate, tobacco, plum to name a few. Velvetty palate with a bittersweet finish. This hits you with a PANG! Fullbodied is an understatement...

A big thank you to Lord Gorlock for this one.  As the brew ejaculates itself out of the bottle into my tulip glass it reveals a deep obsidian color, with a substantial tan head.  The aroma wafts hungrily toward my olfactory glands, revealing itself with coffee, chocolate, cabernet, prunes, nuts, licorice.  The first sip reveals a plethora of flavors which drive my taste buds into orgasmic nirvana.  Tastes of the above aromas, and revealing velvety chocolate syrupy, cinnamon, hazlenut flavors after the repour.  This one had some elements of Brooklyn BC Stout, some elements of Stone RIP, and some elements of Old Heathen...even a tad of DFH Worldwide.  This beer is big, with well hidden alcohol, and perhaps the best aroma, complexity, and finish of any stout (or any beer for that matter) that I have ever had.  You must try this stuff.  I gave Stone RIP a 4.8, and had this one side-by-side with the Stone, and this one edges the Stone RIP ever so slightly.....but thats sort of like choosing between banging Carmen Electra and Pam Anderson.

Got this in a trade with DarkElf. Wow! Pours a deep BLACK with a small brown head. Aroma is smokey and has a lot of coffee. Good thing I like coffee. Taste is of roasted coffee, mocha, dark fruit, molasses, smoke and plenty of hops. Mouthfeel is very full, round and creamy. Light carbonation. Alcohol is well-masked. A classic Imperial Stout. I wish I had a cigar with this.

Sweet nose, toffee, vanilla, coffee. Vinuous, vapory. Tons of great aromas, filling the room. Black liquid with thin tan head. Silky palate, warming, light carbonation. Great tastes, sweet, raisin, smoke, plum, coffe, tobacco, chocolate, vanilla, etc.  Finish is warming, light bittersweet chocolate. After is pleasant roasted bitterness. Great stuff.
yummy, yummy , yummy.  the heavy alchol and harsh palate kept this from prefection.  Pours like motoroil, with a daaaaaark brown head.  Solid coffee and alochol flavors... harsh yet gloroius

Pours like used motor oil. Zero head. Aroma is all coffee and malt. Flavor is much of the same but with enough bitter finish to play off the maltiness. Frickin crazy ass full flavored stout. Is it worth the 13 bucks I paid for it? You bet. Did it take me half a day to drink the whole thing? Yup. And I cant wait to drink another.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 Rating for Alesmith "The Shit" from RBSG 2008. Looks like Speedway, that black mass, but the aroma has an extra kick of coffee. I don’t know much about coffee, but what this added gave a beautiful nose. Adding a smooth coffee icecream flavor over the original speedway’s coffee bliss, just built this to be floral all around.  Thanks Peter for building this one. 9/5/9/5/18


Pours a thick black with a small brown head. Strong coffee aroma really gets this thing in a league of its own. Flavor is very rich and malty. Smooth and thick with tons of roasty coffee flavor and caramel. Very amazing brew that rivals the best imperial stouts.

Pours nice and dark with a caramel colored head. Smells rich coffee, chocolate, and malt. Thick early mouthfeel that quickly dissipates into a soft finish. Starts by tasting malty and sweet and ends with a nice smooth coffee and bitter chocolate mix. It masks the 12% very well and lives up to the hype I keep hearing. Glad I got to taste this one. Aquired on trade... Thanks Darkelf!
Nice aroma, light head, great appearance, very dark. I tried this for the first time, and its nice and sweet, hints of chocolate and coffee I think. But I recommend trying this one.
Chocolate aroma. Light head and lacing. Bitter chocolate taste, hints of molasses. Strong alcohol finish. Overpriced at $10 US.

Very pleasant aroma, with coffee notes, wood, roastiness, port. Pours an opaque black, thin brown head. Sweet chocolate in the flavour, oak, coffee, alcohol in the finish. On the down side the finish is quite harsh, an tough to get past. Perhaps thats why the barrel aged Speedway is so highly rated. It seem like all you have to do is write "imperial" in front of a beer and its in the 100th percentile. This beer was alright but Im not raving about it.
Loved the heavy taste of this beer and the coffee flavour. Also loved the dark look and the fine frothy head. Nice beer.

Dark black and thick pour. Small tan head that rims around the glass. Flavor is very bitter/hoppy with some roastedness. Aftertaste has a lingering coffee taste.  Better as the bottle lowered. I was a little disappointed in this; it taste like a Expedition Stout with a little coffee added.

Absolutely one of the best beers I’ve ever tasted.  The pour yields little head, but what is there is a tan/beige hue.  The aroma is heavily laden with dark, dark roasty malt and coffee.  The color is black as night.  The smooth texture is great, and the initial taste of choco-espresso coffee is nothing short of fabulous.  I wanted to sip this glass forever.  The bitter hop aftertaste was a nice finish to each mouthful.  Make no mistake, there’s a definite alcohol prescence, but it’s not a bad thing.  It’s just warms you a bit.  As the glass warms in your hands, all the wonderful quailities seem to be magnified.  I’ve got to get more.  I’m not sure I’ll be able to let my last bottle sit for long.

imperial stout tasting, march 04:  black, tan head.  super roasty coffee aroma with chocolate, anise, dried fruit and a bit of alcohol.  flavour is rich, full and chocolatey, finishing very roasty and bitter.  Ive never had a beer go better with chocolate than this did with the dark chocolate tarts dougshoemaker provided for the tasting.  an excellent beer.

What a marvelous, well crafted brew. Probably one of the best stouts out there (hence the reason for it being on Rate Beers Top 50).  An excellent blend of chocolcate and coffee gives it a nice balance of sweet and bitter. Pours deep a soft black color with a tan head, and is extremely soft and smooth on the palate.

Alesmith tap room.  The rating lives up to the hype!  Pitch black, thick brown creamy head.  Complex nose of bitter coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, toffee, and light berry.  Flavor adds to the above with roasted mocha notes, anise, and a bit of dark fruit.  Hop bitterness shines midway through to provide balance.  Very rich, full-bodied, soft carbonation, silky, dry bitter chocolate finish.  World class is an understatement!  One of my favorites of all time....

Black with a creamy brown head. Aroma is coffee and anise. Flavour is thick rich chocolate and coffee. Finish is bitter dark chocolate and salty. Really good, but nowhere near as complex as Dark Lord.
Beautiful black body. Not much carbonation. Very roasty, smooth, and silky. Lots of coffee flavor!  This is a great stout. I bet the bourbon is something great... Maybe someday.

Had with an Ashton cigar.  Overall it was very good, but I personally like the Moylans better.  The coffee is not as nearly as present as I thought it would be.  Chocolate, hops, and alcohol were dominate.  Coated the glass nicely, and was better as it warmed.  Mocha head was nice too.

This is worth its high rating.  Pretty much everything could be described as being "Huge."  The roasted malts, coffee, toffee, chocolate, hops, alcohol were in grand amounts.  However, instead of conflicting and becoming muddled I found this to be balanced quite well, even with the higher ABV, which was noticable but not distracting.  Had to sip on this one for a while.  Appearance is dark, thick, with a chocolate colored head.  Even with the coffee/malt flavors it didnt come off being too sweet with a nice balance of bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2005 Dark pour.  Small medium brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee.  Very rich.  Flavor is huge of coffee and chocolate.  Some mild alcohol presence as it warms.  Ridiculously smooth and silky palate.  The flavor is just fantastic.  Absolutely decadent and delicious.

Bottle served at 55 degrees.
This stuff is dark! I held a flashlight up to the glass and no light penetrated.
Medium sized dark brown head that disipates quickly and leaves behind a patchy, chunky lace.
Aroma was rubbing alcohol and coffee. maybe a little prune juice in there.
Flavor is milk chocholate, coffee and dark fruit with a sweet caramel finish. 

Surprisingly soft and smooth for a beer so high in ABV. kind of went down like a kahlua and cream. or a chocholate milk with chocholate syrup, heavy cream, coffee and a shot of everclear.
This was a great beer.
I am buying a bottle tomorrow to put in the wine chiller/beer cellar. This is  definitely   the Padron Anniversario Maduro of beers.

Bottle, thanks to mwsf. This was a great relief, ive often been dissapointed with a lot of top 50 beers, but this just kicked arse. Full mouthfeel, mocha, chocolate. Sweet at first, but balanced by a rich roasted bitterness. Rich, with plenty of guts, but really balanced where it needs to be, top notch.

Thanks edward (brooklynboy) for this great find. Man is this stuff good. Dark dark with big tan quickly discipating head. Nose is smooth creamy malty and chocolaty taste is first smooth chocalaty and bitter, later the alcohol vapours come out. top 10 easily.

Impressive.  Black as motor oil with a dark tan head.  Nose had coffee, anise, dark chocolate.  Body was full and creamy and robust.  Flavor was big and bold and coffee and coffeee and coffee.  Excellent stout.

black body burnt umber head that is thick & creamy.  super thick lacing.  coffee and light chocolate notes.  super strong coffee flavor, then burnt/toasted malt, alcohol, and DRY finish.  salty like ompher has said.  NO fruit detected.  agree with austinpowers that its a little overpowering.  I like more sweet & dried fruit, but this is a perfect dry coffee stout.  alcohol well hidden for 12%!  bitter hop aftertaste is there every sip.  I love coffee but the dryness/hop wallop took over.  blackstrap molassess flavor (a very strong taste).  a world class stout but this is not for me. I had some raisins with it to get what I wanted.  soft carbonation.  super cool label, but why does this come in a green bottle?

Sampled from bottle. Deep, deep black. Vinously sweet up front, huge mouthfeel. Coffee and nutty notes. Surprisingly dry given all the maltiness. This dryness was only slightly present as it showed up as a flatness for lack of a better word. Truly world class though...high expectations met. Wow!

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2004 750 ml. bottle (2002):  this beer is sooo dank.  oh my.  smells of nice espresso, and roastyness.  oof, little to no alcohol aroma.  jet black with a caramel thick creamy head.  its incredibly smooth and aromatic as you sip it down. Theres been a bottle in my cellar for 3 months, and it is UNBELIEVEABLE.  The coating is clean, smooth and flavorful. The feeling is euphoric...im sooo down with this beer.  pure bliss. .. The velvet carpet has been unrolled.  I want the barrel aged.

great brew, my first rating and what a beer to do it on.  Poured out very dark, darker then anything i can remember pouring out before.  Smelled of dark coffee with small hints of chocolate and malt.   Taste was somewhat of a sensation, coffee very strong coffee.  alchohol, also very strong.  lots of flavours to trip your taste buds.  very highly recommended from a newbie rater.  this beer is definitly something special

On tap at Pizza Port, Solana Beach.  I havent been rating too many stouts thus far, but this is impressive.  Beautiful solid black color with tan head.  The aroma is definitely coffee and a bit of alcohol.  When tasted the first thing you get is deep rich chocolate flavors and alcohol.  These flavors are followed by heavy coffee flavors in the finish.  The flavors are just so well defined and apparent from start to finish.  This is a well made beer.

There is a lot of alcohol in the aroma of this beer, but also coffee and prunes. The color is pitch black and it has a fine disappearing head. The flavor is lovely; coffee bitterness and hops on a sour background. It ends on a very dry hoppy note. Really a good beer.

Bottle.  Pours thick and black with a hint of dark brown around the rim of the glass.  Medium sized brown, somewhat foamy head rises with a vigorous pour, then diminishes rather quickly.  Remaining head leaves some lacing on the sides of the snifter. Aroma is huge and rich - dark, dark roasted malts, bitter chocolate, coffee grounds and some hoppiness with overt alcohol smell.  Flavor is also huge, thick and chocolatey, figs and currents, coffee, an alcohol kick and a nice bitter finish that lingers.  Thick body, soft carbonation and smooth despite the massive ingredients.  What a treat!  Im glad I live in Alesmiths hometown.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2017 Pours jet black, with a tan head. The aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt and some coffee. Chocolate and coffee taste as well, with a nice body, not too thick or too thin. Finishes with espresso and hop flavors.

I'm glad to have finally had this brew. Deep black pour with a thick tan head. Coffee aroma. Some chocolate as well. Nice balance in the flavor. A hint of alcohol, thick chocolate and coffee flavors. Very well balanced and very impressed! Had this on tap at O'Brien's in San Diego.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2004 A beer I had really looked forward to taste! Thanks to Jacob Lövenlund for sharing!Pours a tar black body with nice brown head - nothing less than beautiful! Aroma hits you instantly with a very strong and delightful odour of chocolate. Also coffee, sweet dark roasted malt, mocha and a fine balance of alcohol. Yummi! Flavor is just as delicious. Extremely soft, complex and full-bodied with notes of chocolate, fruit, malt, hops and lots of coffee (espresso). A thick mouthful but not as cloying as Dark Lord. Strong and warming and simply EXCELLENT!! One of the best beers I have ever tasted!!

Special Thanks to Gusler for this one, the positive beer karma around that guy is probably swirling like a cloud of fresh hops!

Poured absolutely pitch black with very, very little carbonation and an oily like pattern of film residing on the top of the glass.

Aroma is heavily roasted with chocolate malts and definite java notes. Also some distinctly rich notes of nuts, so rich in fact its like peanut butter. Slightly peppery leather also.

Flavor starts off heavy with roasted flavors which subside for a time to rich chocolate notes. That rich nutty tone that I detected on the nose also comes into play in the middle part of the experience. It's a really intriguing nutty flavor too, something like a warm unsalted almond. The finish is distinctly dark roast coffee grounds.

Mouthfeel is maybe a touch thin but is cool with a slick, oily sensation which I enjoyed.

Overall feeling is that this is a tremendous brew worthy of much praise. I am thankful to have received it, and will be looking forward to the next time I have an opportunity to hoist one of these, Thanks Joe!

UPDATED: APR 21, 2004 Nice sweet aroma the finest I have ever come across in a stout. No head, black as night, very low carbonation. Yum neither overly sweet nor overly thick considering how big this monster of a beer tastes. Coffee, alcohol, molasses, bitter chocolate pleasant bitter finish. The finest Imperial Stout I have ever had move over Fish Tail

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2004 Re-Rate:  Poured like used oil, no head.  May have been a little cold.  Aroma is hella coffee and alcohol.  Flavor comes across very as unidemensionally coffee,  some alcohol burn, but hidden very well.  I didnt notice any chocolate in it, but again I think I had it too cold.  Nice and thick feel, very full.  Warms on the way down.  Out-friggin-standing.

An Imperial stout that's also brewed with coffee? This must be the beer designed just for me! 
Dark as the blackest night, with a head that, on this pour, stays small, but lasts for the duration as a fine, brown-tinged ring.
Aroma is thick and viscous, a twisted, motor-oily smell, wrapped up in licorice, molasses, dark rum. Deeep, dark, delectably intoxicating. Potent stuff, wicked, but delicious: I love it!
Taste: an intensive barrage boards the senses, thick, chewy, immense, the flavor quickly dominates the senses, slays any opposition, rearranges the furniture, makes itself completely at home in the mouth. There's a new King in the Castle! Devastating! Amazing!
Coffee flavor is there, for certain, but isn't dominant, rather it seems to be the skeleton that holds this incredible flavor together. And a never-flagging flavor it is, too, every element continue to roll luxuriantly in the mouth. I was in a state of beery blissdom, brought on by this bottle.
Alcohol is so well-concealed by the flavor, it's largely unfelt until halfway through the bottle. And I made a mistake, not realizing that it's a whopping 12%, until I was well into it. My sobriety took a definite hit in this sampling!
A most impressive stout. If I were a very good boy indeed, I'd love to sink into one of these every night, as my reward

Good dark appearance balancing the bitterness and malt flavors. Finishes with an alcoholic rush that's dry to the tongue. As the beer warms up the wonderful chocolate aromas emerge as well as the toasty coffee flavors.

Damn good, but unidimensional - COFFEE. You don't like coffee? I don't see you liking this. Excellent flavor, nothing off, nothing foul, the coffee flavor is from a very fine source. Deep, rich, roasted - coffee. Did I say coffee? Would like very much to see what the bourbon barrell adds .....

Aroma:  smokey, burnt coffee, strong alcohol, vegetable, creamy/milky, chocolate/coco aroma.

Appearance:  Dark brown with small tan head.

Flavor:  Milk/cream, dark chcolate/coco, strong alcohol, smokey burnt wood flavor, bitter coffee, and  earthiness.  Drinking this beer is like drinking chocolate syrup--very thick and sweet.

Palate:  Smooth and creamy with a slight burning/woody aftertaste.

(Bottle)  Had this one the same night as Dark Lord.  It is really a toss up to which beer is better.  They have a lot of the same qualities.  Thick black, motor oil thickness with a thin brown head.  Has a powerful coffee and chocolate aroma.  Great flavor of chocolate, roasted coffee, malt, and caramel make this a real treat.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2004 pours out like used motor oil.  no head.  completely black pour.  strong smell of coffee and chocolate.  coffee taste galore.  this is 12%? damn i never would have known that if it didnt say.  slight taste of alcohol, but mostly coffee and chocolate. this is an AWESOME stout.  has a nice hop presence too.  i believe this is the best dark beer, if not beer i have ever had.  wonderful.  update- i had to give this a 10 on flavor.  i believe it was a little too cold, now after sitting out for about 15 minutes so much flavor is coming out of it its rediculous.  this IS the best beer i have ever tasted.  i cant believe i am drinking something better than stone ipa.
black gold, texas tea,  very complex but with the coffee and choc. notes in the foreground.  Plenty hoppy, a plus. Oily mouth feel in line with the black gold/texas tea visual.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2004 Pitch color and 100% opaque.  The richness and depth of flavors is indisputable--coffee and roasted malts, deep flavors, in a rich concoction.  I had this a couple of beers after having the Dark Lord, and I dont think this gives away much to it (and very possibly, just the opposite). (first rating: 9-5-9-4-18; December 2003) // re-rate, December 2004: All the regular dimensions of stout-hood are here but in the aroma the deep roasted quality is really massive.  Coffee.  Coffee.  Such an accomplishment.  (2004 Christmas Party, my #1, groups #3)
The aroma reminds me of a belgian ale, but the flavour is standard amazing stout.  Strong roasted, stout flavour.  Very coffee, burnt.  Thick.  Black.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2004 What an experience, it's not just a beer it's an experience, pitch black in color, thin brown-ish head, little head retention and no lacing but that's kind of to be expected with a beer of this strength, sweet malt & coffee in the nose, full bodied, thick, syrupy, coffee flavors with subtle hints of chocolate, lots of roasted & burnt flavors, sweet & coffee-flavored finish, definitely want to take your time to savor this, absoutely excellent imperial stout!

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2004  Blind Tasting, Thanks tiggmtl  Pitch black pour with almost no head. Aroma consists of an hazelnuty malt profile with coffee and dark swiss chocolate notes. Very intense grapefruity hops also come into play in here. Palate is dry altogether. Taste is very hoppy, grapefruity although alcohol shows more and more as it warms, then it becomes more on the vinous side. Medium to full bodied, silky, round mouthfeel. Warming for sure, but definitely not close to my expectations. In fact, in the blind tasting, I never came close to guessing this was the speedway. I expected it to burst in my face with coffee flavors and frankly, this doesnt have so much coffee flavors, its in fact only in my notes regarding the aroma and I insisted far more on the hazelnut. That being said, after the 10th imperial stout, I was sure the last one (11th) would be the speedway, it passed that anonym. It remains very well done though with all the elements you look for in an impy including a big roasty character, but youve got to be in the mood for alcohol and a very long west-coast hoppy aftertaste. My friends, without being chauvinist, this aint no Péché Mortel. In fact, next time I have the Péché Mortel, I expect to raise its rating some..  Resample many months later. This is a bit better than I remembered. I got a bit more coffee flavors, but its not particularly expressive, not so complex, but very well made for its size, good full body, firm roastiness. Quality offering. Rising from 3.8 to 3.9.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 Affable coffee spreading onto a roasted pie crust...An elegant chocolate topping with interspersed hops is decorated with a red wine splash and dark chocolate bitterness...On tap, I still prefer Péché Mortel, but in the bottle, I have to say Speedway wins for me...World-class Coffee-infused Imperial Stout...

Dark, sweet chocolate and espresso bean with some dark fruit (raisin) in the aroma. Vinous & Ropey.Black with a thin dark brown ring of head. Bitter, dark chocolate up front. Plenty of alcohol apparent and a prominent burnt roastiness. Alcohol becomes more and more noticeable throughout. Smooth mouthfeel and medium-full body. Definite alcohol warming. Bottle. Blind tasting #4.

Bottle pours absolutely pitch black!   Head is minimal, but from what was there it was dark dark dark...   Lacing is very slick, not leaving much trace.   Heavy aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and light chocolate.   Taste is forwardly bittersweet coffee, followed by some mild roasted malts and major semisweet chocolate near the end.   Mouthfeel is smooth, but not as velvety as I would have liked.   Slight tinge of alcohol on the finish, but otherwise the 12% is well hidden.   Definately a good Imperial Stout, could have used a bit more carbonation/livelyness,  but I still prefer Great Divides Maverick Imperial Stout over this one.   Thanks goes out to TChrome for the trade!

A sweet, under-carbonated mess.  The aroma was nice, but the sweetness and body were too much to support the light CO2 level.  Looking at these other ratings, I wonder if my sample was atypical?  I will try again, and re-rate if needed.
Thanks the SDBruboy for this fantastic beer. Poured oil black with litte head. Great roasted coffee flavor all the way through. Alcohol was not hidden very well and that's not a bad thing.

To be honest, the pour of this beer, as well as the aroma, made me excited.  However, the taste was dominated by overwhelming coffee flavors that were not what I expected.  Worth a try but a bit overhyped.

Deep dark brown beer with a vague redness.  Not much of a head at all.  Sweet, chocolatey aroma of dark cocoa.  Prickly on the tounge, yet smooth and creamy at the same time.  Thickness, tarry complexity of mocha and chocoate flavors.  Alcohol strength is noticable, but subdued to a degree by huge flavor.  A real champ, rich throughout and finishing bitterly.

I was baffled as to why they put this in a green bottle. Pours insanely black and oily. Virtually no head. Coffee aroma with notes of malty chocolate and slight alcohol. Coffee flavours, mild fruit background. Alcohol warmth. Some smoke and nutiness. Very warming. Wow was this super hyped. It was good, but there nicer examples out there (sigh, with less alcohol.) This is a monster out of control.
It pours black with little head. Aroma is roasted coffee and malts. Coffee is definitly dominate. this beer finishes big and with a warming feeling associated with the high % alcohol.

An absolutely amazing concoction. Combining my two favorite beveredges in such a perfect way! Unbelievable body, fantastic taste and bite. Not for the weak, this is a serious brew. Bitter, warming, and as full flavored as any beer ever made. Spend a night with it, you won't be sorry.

Coffee, chicory and treacle in the aroma. Dark brown, red around the edges. Bitter coffee flavour, with some liquorice and chicory too. Full bodied, salty, oily and bitter, so smooth, You'd never guess it's alcohol content. Wonderful! Thanks jcalabre via mr._kimchee!

Well this one was the capper to a great night of Imperial Stouts at mr_kimchees - thanks so much again Jess! I am amazed that after a night of big beers I was still as wowed by this as I was. On a fresh palate who knows how I might have rated it. Anyway the rundown: Rich black with oily tan head. Mild coffee layered with wine and chocolate. Thick and creamy coffee and smooth chocolate aftertaste. Had enough left for a sip with a bite of chocolate pastry and holy %$@& was it good. Deserves high accolades for sure.

Deep black in colour with a tan coloured head.  Huge coffee aroma, along with chocolate, malt and a nice roastiness.  Flavour of chocolate, coffee, espresso, some sweetness, rich, roasty, smooth.  Huge body.  Finishes incredibly smooth for a beer that's 12%.  No hint of alcohol anywhere.  Perfect finish to a great night of imperial stouts.  Thanks mr_kimchee.
smell of hershey's syrup.  black in color.  slightly bitter with a nice combo of coffee and chocolate.  very smooth.   nice dessert beer.

Sample glass, RateBeer Southeastern Gathering, 2002 bottling.  Big chocolate, coffee and molasses malt.  Darkness!  Body is just black, black, black.  Flavor is constructed with beautiful tones of dark roasted coffees and succulent chocolate.  Slight alcohol presence doesnt really detract.  Heavy body, oily texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: simply spectacular; many thanks to Mike (BBB63) for bringing this one; what a show stopper.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2004 2002 vintage. Black, no head. Burnt raisin toast aroma. Flavor is bread, earthy and ever so slightly sour, grapes, salt and pepper, and coffee, of course. Finishes Dry,and crisp, surprisingly so for how sweet it starts. Excellent.Sampled at Ratebeer Southeastern Gathering, Atlanta, 2004. 
Re-rate, August 2004 - trade from Drunkasaskunk. Not to change the rating, but continuing the secrition. I noticed as the beer warms, there is a pronounced sweetness that crops up. Not obrusive, it provides a nice contrast to the coffee flavors. This remains a very, very impressive beer.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2004 Re-rate  Still astounded my how such a strong coffee taste and aroma can fill my interest. 750 ml - 2002 edition My, oh my!  This was the highlight of the Southeastern gathering in Atlanta (thanks Mike!) The espresso-laced goodness was the favorite of all three at my table (out of dozens of world class beers) Coming from a non-coffee drinker (typically too bitter for me), this is a high compliement.  It poured pitch black with no head, and had a smooth, but thick viscocity.  The caramel sweetness gave it the edge that made it just perfect for me.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2004 Pitch black appearance with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and raisins. Flavor is chocolate covered raisins, coffee, and caramel. Very complex and rich. This is one amazing stout deserving of its reputation.
First sample at the Atlanta tasting...Oustanding beer.  Lovely roasted flavors of exspresso and chocolate.  Can't really say much new about this beer...Definitely World Class.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2007 Extremely strong stout with a vast quantity of coffee and alcohol.  The alcohol is a little too much for me.  This is one powerful beer, but too much over the top for me.  It was actually smoother than I expected, but also too many esters for me.
